Imagining an ancient Egypt that never existed where gods and men live together, this effects-driven CGI extravaganza pits the benevolent if slightly flirtatious lord of the air Horus (Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau) against the nefarious desert god Set (Gerard Butler) who usurps his throne of Egypt on the day of his coronation. As with most such power tussles, there is a familial dimension – Set is in fact Horus' uncle, who isn't just resentful that his father, the sun god Ra (Geoffrey Rush), had given rule of Egypt to Horus but also seemingly banished him to a bleak and barren wasteland. So Set kills his brother Osiris (Bryan Brown) and blinds Horus, exiling him to some faraway dune to wallow in self-pity and eternal misery.

That opening sets the stage for Horus to embark on a journey of self-discovery on his way to reclaiming the throne, with immeasurable help from a mortal thief Bek (Brenton Thwaites). It is Bek who returns Horus one of his eyes after breaking into Set's seemingly impenetrable vault, who also subsequently accompanies Horus on his quest in exchange for passage for his one true love Zaya (Courtney Eaton) back from the underworld. And so begins a series of razzle-dazzle action sequences, including a thrilling chase by two evil goddesses Astarte (Abbey Lee) and Anat (Yaya Deng) atop two giant fire-breathing serpents and a near-death escape from Set with some help from Elodie Yung's goddess of love Hathor inside the chamber of a towering Sphinx.

Oh yes, there is no such thing as subtlety here. The chariots are pulled by giant scarab beetles. Sedan chairs take flight with hundreds of birds. Gods transform from their 11, 12 feet in height human form into glistening animal-headed robots and bleed liquid gold. Ra lives in a spaceship hovering above the Earth, bursts into flames at will and spends each night doing battle with the Lovecraftian ancient Apep by shooting fireballs from his spear. Indeed, as far as being gaudy is concerned, Proyas isn't shy at all about flaunting every single dollar of his significant US$140 million budget that went into creating the sheer visual spectacle (or excess, depending on how you see it) that you'll get to see on the big screen.

Yet its silliness certainly isn't lost on Proyas; indeed, along with his writers Matt Sazama and Burk Sharpless ('Dracula Untold' and 'The Last Witch Hunter'), Proyas gleefully embraces its absurdity with campy humour. For one, Bek is never too far from an amusing quib usually directed at Bek. For another, the god of wisdom Thoth (Chadwick Boseman) is a ball being haughty and all full of himself – and we mean that literally in the context of the hundreds of copies he has made of himself to serve him in his lair. It never does take itself too seriously, nor too flippantly to be completely dismissed, and the levity is a nice counter-balance to the elaborate kitsch on display.

Credit that too to Coaster-Waldau and Thwaites, who sustain a lively bickersome chemistry as a pair of mismatched buddies forced to work together rather than apart. For the ladies, Coaster-Waldau also oozes sheer masculine charm, while Butler often chews up the scenery with pomp and swagger. Both actors are no stranger to the swords-and- sandals genre – the former from the HBO series 'Game of Thrones' and the latter of course from '300' – and have no trouble convincing us of their place in Egyptian mythology. Rush also lends his trademark eccentricity to Ra, looking just at home on his solar barque.

And so like last summer's 'Hercules', 'Gods of Egypt' rises above the ashes by delivering two hours of solid sword-and-sorcery entertainment with dashes of self-aware humour. There is swashbuckling adventure, romance, epic battles and plenty of visual grandeur to meet its mad ambition with lunatic conviction. That it is overstuffed is part of its excessive nature, but you can't argue that it doesn't fill you with a sense of awe and captivate and delight you more than you expect it to.

review_title: Miserable computer effects combined with bad cast and non-godly gods.
review_detailed_main:
I love stories about myths, history and fables. I was disappointed.

An antagonist looking like a Caucasian pretty boy that has not yet hit puberty (think boy-bands) supposed to be Egyptian. He is for some reason able to outsmart the Gods.... Talking about the Gods, the Gods are puny, especially in their behavior and powers. A blind God that can't even kill a human boy.

The worst part of the film was the CGI. The fight between Horus and Set looked horrible. Some would argue that it is fantasy, not real. But it looks really bad. I happened to notice the mass of people in the background of the fight, supposed to be humans but they moved too animated.

This is like a badly made superhero movie with effects from the 80's.

This movie was a journey that went to a lot of places but still didn't go anywhere. There were good actors in this movie but the dialogue was just comical. The CGI was also in some places like Play-Doh stop motion. It was such a mess this movie that it ended up being somewhat entertaining. Watch it just so you can have a giggle that they spent 140 million making it and have just this to show for it.

review_title: Horus teams up with a thief to defeat the evil Set from unleashing chaos in all realms

review_detailed_main: This movie is the worst thing I have ever seen, excluding The Fanatic (2019). The plot sucks, it's not original or compelling. The cinematography sucks as it not only does nothing original or unique, it somehow manages to be below the standard level. The lighting is so flat, it's lit like a bad TV show. The special effects are god awful, it was released in 2016 and has a 140 million dollar budget so it has no excuse to look like it was made in 1 week. The green screen is so awful you can literally see the black outlines of the characters in some shots. The acting is horrible and not convincing. The characters are all bland and uninteresting. The dialogue is full of clichés and is total cringe. The score and sound mixing is so bad you sometimes have to raise the volume to hear what the characters are saying then BOOM one shot later there is a shooting projectile creating an explosion that makes your ears bleed. Also, all the characters are whitewashed and not Egyptian and they all speak fluent English. In conclusion this movie was a critical and financial flop and the entire human race should be ashamed this abomination exists.

The movie tells a meaningful story while showing the beauty of Ancient Egypt and the richness of its culture. You get to meet great characters with amazing personalities and gods that change the way they think, because of their "mortal slaves". The setting of the film is created to take your breath and take you on a journey across the desolated deserts, going into the deepest jungles and then through the most populated parts of ancient towns. The beautiful relationship between Bek and Zaya will make you rethink what you know about the limits of love. Set's desire for power and his attitude towards his own nephew Horus will show you that times change as well as people's standards. The movie is definitely a must-watch even for viewers that are not into action or fantasy, because they will be left speechless by the personalities that they would meet during their 3D visit to Egypt.

I usually go for movies like this but.... whatever happened to practical effects? You lose me with too much blatant CGI. This movie, it seemed like it was only CGI.

And not just CGI, but the kind of CGI that looks like a video game.

It honestly lost me right away, I gave it about ten minutes and just stopped.

review_title: This will be a CLASSIC 4 years to come. Compared to Jason and the Argonauts
review_detailed_main:
Of course it's for kids .But Adults will Enjoy it also . It's a Great mixture of Greek and Egyptian Mythology. I Really liked the love story intertwined and the fact that the GODS were bigger in visual size then the human's throughout the film . The film had nothing that a family could not sit down and view together . No bad language no sex and nudity something decent for a change.the colors of the costumes were magnificent .Music lite and not over the top . The way the movie spoke about gods we all waited for DONALD TRUMP to make a cameo.

We shall see whatever the out come it shall be ENTERTAINMENT for us all . The Greatest reality T.V. show America has thus produced ,,,,,,,,, Because the end result will enlighten those of us Who seek the truth . We shall see whatever the out come it shall be ENTERTAINMENT for us all . The Greatest reality T.V. show America has thus produced ,,,,,,,,, Because the end result will enlighten those of us Who seek the truth .

review_title: This Abuses The Right to be Awful
review_detailed_main: Ignore anyone who gives this film more than 1 star, or who has literally ANYTHING positive to say about this abomination of movie making - it is truly appalling on every level and your time would be better spent cutting off your own ears and sewing them over your eyes. Absolute garbage from the very start and actually manages to achieve the near impossible by getting exponentionally worse, to climax in one of the worst endings in cinematic history,, and from a director who actually has the temerity to defend this rubbish. Gods of EVERYWHERE help us if they ever make a sequel. Avoid at all costs.

The entire film industry has always had a fascination with sword- and-sandal action adventures. They're like the Velvet Underground of movie subgenres, they may never be popular in their own time but they inspire countless film professionals with their bountiful style, unorthodox special effects and simple but effective story- lines. Where would the world of special effects be without Ray Harryhausen's work on Jason and the Argonauts (1963)? Would we know the name Sergio Leone without the famed director first cutting his teeth on the peplum film The Last Days of Pompeii (1959)? I dare not put the ghastly Gods of Egypt in the same category as Conan the Barbarian (1982) or Clash of the Titans (1981) but I do put it a head above the 2010 remake of Clash of the Titans.

Mortal thief Bek (Thwaites) and his love Zaya (Eaton) are trusted into a web of palace intrigue after benevolent God Osiris (Brown) is struck down by his brother Set (Butler) in a public display of brutality meant to keep mortals and other Gods in line. Osiris's son Horus (Coster-Waldau) attempts to take vengeance but his magical eyes are plucked from his skull and he's banished. Bek steals one of the eyes from Set's newly constructed vault thus turning the wheels of the plot, ultimately resulting in a rematch between Horus and his uncle.

As garish as the sets are and as conspicuous as the computer generated effects may be, the movie is not without its inner-logic which works if you forgive some minor missteps. The characters are weak and uninspired but they all have perfectly respectable character arcs. What's more the precious moments of mirth are genuine in a cheesy Flash Gordon (1980) kind of way. The first act borders on self-parody and the last act is a-clutter with mindless action yet in-spite of all this, I think I caught myself actually enjoying the movie a few times. Yes, believe it or not Gods of Egypt is not entirely irredeemable.

Don't get me wrong; it's goofy, it's dumb and it's loud; it's whitewashed to the point of cultural insensitivity, and it surrenders to some occasionally unsettling themes but none of these factors are important when faced with the film's endgame; it's here to entertain, that's it. With a bar set that low, it's easy to find a lot to like. Those with a thirst for blood and sinew will be glad to know that despite a PG-13 rating, the film showcases a lot of gleeful violence and action. They get away with it only because the blood of the Gods is gold not red. I personally enjoyed the application of certain Ancient Egyptian mythology, especially moments involving Ra (Rush), the granddaddy of the Gods, pulling the sun across the sky in his celestial catamaran.

Gods of Egypt cannot compare to the middling mythological epics of Italy circa 1950's. Heck, it can even compare to 300 (2006) which provided the template for so many of these goof-ball celebrations of male bravado. Director Alex Proyas knows the script for Gods of Egypt isn't exactly Shakespeare and maximizes all the points of entertainment while still telling a cogent tale. The results are crude but effective.

review_title: A low-rent script with a high-stakes pricetag
review_detailed_main:
"If I were even to try to explain, your brain would liquefy and pour out your ears." - actual line from "Gods of Egypt."

Such a quote is so appropriate for a film like "Gods of Egypt," a two-hour long raucous ride through glorious production design and mediocre everything else. Rarely do I find myself sitting in an action film silently begging it to transition from scenes involving never-ending dialog and flat character relations to something more lively and harrowing. Fortunately, "Gods of Egypt" packs a wallop in its plethora of action sequences, but in order to get to the visual goods, you must sit through, in total, over an hour of monotone dialog spouted from beefy, hulking Gods that wears on the mind so quickly you wish they would just morph into chrome-coated creatures again and begin dueling until something meaningful happened.

Consistent readers of my work will take note that I usually do not possess such an attitude when watching action films. Normally, I like my action/epic films with a lot of characterization and dialog; even if it's poorly conceived or lackluster dialog, I usually acknowledge the film's ambition to try and turn Gods and mythical heroes into characters modern audiences can sympathize with. With "Gods of Egypt," my admiration began to breed contempt after I saw what the film's visuals were capable of; after that, sitting through endless, rote dialog by characters who are just mythical cut-outs of Egyptian Gods, was just not what I was in the mood to do. The visual effects in "Gods of Egypt" are extraordinary; a commendable mix of modern sleekness with the pulpy aesthetic of a medium-budget epic, the production design in this film is truly something to behold.

The film is centered around a mortal named Bek (Brenton Thwaites), who aligns with the Egyptian God Horus (Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau) following the death of his lover Zaya (Courtney Eaton) in efforts to dethrone Set (Gerard Butler), the God of Darkness who has just seized the empire. What entails is a brutal struggle for Bek and Horus to get through numerous different traps and roadblocks in order to get to Set to reclaim the throne of the Egyptian empire and try to resurrect Zaya.

I spend so little time introducing the plot for two reasons: one, if you're going to see "Gods of Egypt," the plot is probably the last thing on your mind, and two, it's convoluted thanks to the overabundance of characters and the lack of clarity in the respective chronology and period when this is occurring. The latter issues make it difficult to sink into "Gods of Egypt" and become invested in it on a personal level. This is precisely what led to me simply wishing for more action sequences than anything in the way of character dialog.

The characters here are so archetypal and flat they might as well be hieroglyphics. They are fearless, immortal (even the mortals, it seems) beings that never seem to be in any real danger regardless of the circumstances, and they're played and written in a manner that doesn't engage. Thwaites and Coaster-Waldau are not very engaging screen presences at all, and for the umpteenth time, neither is Gerard Butler, who keeps getting cast in these films as if he truly bring some layeredness to the table. I'm convinced that all three of these actors, with the appropriate script, could be extremely convincing performers in a film, but once again, especially in Butler's case, Hollywood seems to have a lack of confidence and conviction in them as performers and throws them into a film with a low-rent script with a high-stakes pricetag.

To be fair, the high-stakes pricetag results in some of the most visually eye-catching effects we're likely to see this year. The entire film is gorgeously photographed, largely thanks to the sun-soaked cinematography by Peter Menzies Jr., who has helped shoot everything from the "Lara Croft" films to "Kangaroo Jack." Menzies Jr. and director Alex Proyas direct this film with a series of sweeping shots and nicely paced sequences of peril, my personal favorite being a scene where both Bek and Horus are challenged with outrunning two gigantic, fire-breathing serpents on a maze-like floor. And let's not forget the suspenseful sequence involving Bek trying to obtain a glowing gem on heavily booby-trapped floors, which accentuates everything one has come to love about modern action filmmaking. However, as stated before, these scenes only come interjected between the incessant amount of droning dialog we have to endure over the course of a terribly long-wined two hours.

The epitome of irony is "Gods of Egypt" opening on the same weekend as the 88th Academy Awards premiering on TV, which is being criticized for the second year in a row now for a lack of diversity, and the film featuring a cast largely comprised of Australian performers. Not to mention, the country of Australian apparently gave the film a 46% tax break if it shot on-location in Australia, which continues to add to the question; was this film made by the people who have their names on the credits or simply made by the circumstances that keenly fell into place for the filmmaking process (no-name actors in the biggest roles resulting in lower pay for talent, tax writeoffs, an ethnically challenged cast, etc)?

review_title: Not just Awful. It's God Awful!
Seven for the fun. I am not a historian
review_detailed_main: So I get why people pan it for historical inaccuracy and political incorrectness. I am neither a historian nor am I politically correct. I found the movie entertaining. If you're looking for deep meaning or oscar acting, this ain't your movie. If you just want some mindless fun and reasonable CGI, dig right in.

review_title: Overblown CGI spectacle masquerading as a proper movie
Dumb as a box - or plague - of frogs, but hugely entertaining

review_detailed_main:
Reading the past reviews that rate this movie as 10/10 is laughable. Clearly the studio's minions desperately trying to resuscitate this dead corpse of a movie. I actually signed up with the sole purpose of posting a review for this movie. A task that outshines the level of effort put into the making of this joke of a movie.

It failed to hold my interest for more than 30 minutes by which time I felt I wanted to pour bleach on my eyes. A colossal failure of a movie adding insult to injury by associating itself with a great ancient civilization. The Pharoahs are puking in their dead mouths as we speak.

This movie could exterminate rats who would die from boredom and frantically claw out each other's eyes. It helped me appreciate other movies I thought were bad. Clash of the Titans, I am sorry.

It's success lies in it's ability to turn $140 million into an audiovisual disaster.

review_title: In the tradition of The Mummy and Van Helsing
review_detailed_main:
Gods of Egypt was widely reviled for its casting choices before and after its release, and I think at least half of all bad reviews stem from that controversy.

Most other negative reviews point out the rampant CGI and "silly" story.

For my own part, yes, I do think more authentic casting would have benefited the movie. I am not politically upset by whitewashing. I just think it damages the quality of the film. Even though the setting is heavily stylized and barely historical, the single element of the movie not reliant upon Egyptian motifs is the ethnicity of the leads, and it just feels like a cynical movie executive choice that is difficult to ignore.

Just imagine a movie about Norse mythology where almost all of the actors are black or Asian. It wouldn't be politically significant. It just wouldn't feel right, and that's the weird out-of-place feeling we get while watching Gods of Egypt.

As for the CGI and story, I thought both were perfectly adequate. The movie reminds me of Stephen Sommers' Mummy and Van Helsing series, and it's just the kind of fantasy/sci-fi movie we haven't seen very often since Marvel and DC have pretty much taken over that niche with comic movies. Gods of Egypt is old fashioned adventure movie, and that simply does not appeal to everyone these days.

I gave it a 7 because I found it to be entertaining and interesting (I love mythology), but I deducted 1.5 points for the inauthentic casting, and I deducted another 1.5 points because I prefer my historical / fantasy media to be R-rated in the tradition of 300 and Spartacus, and Gods of Egypt definitely plays it too safe in the sex and violence department.
Mmmk.... so this flick would've passed if it were 1950 because there would've been an excuse to not use your imagination with all the money that goes into a production.

review_title: Giant Production And A Giant Movie Too.
review_detailed_main: In this spectacular action-adventure inspired by the classic mythology of Egypt, the survival of mankind hangs in the balance as an unexpected mortal hero Bek (Brenton Thwaites) undertakes a thrilling journey to save the world and rescue his true love. In order to succeed, he must enlist the help of the powerful god Horus (Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau) in an unlikely alliance against Set (Gerard Butler), the merciless god of darkness, who has usurped Egypt's throne, plunging the once peaceful and prosperous empire into chaos and conflict. As their breathtaking battle against Set and his henchmen takes them into the afterlife and across the heavens, both god and mortal must pass tests of courage and sacrifice if they hope to prevail in the epic final confrontation.

review_title: A lot better than the reviews had me believe
review_detailed_main:
I saw the trailer for this movie and thought "Oh that looks good" then I read a few reviews and comments on various web sites and a lot of people were bad mouthing it so I was feeling a little reluctant to watch it. But I also knew from past experience not to trust some reviews.

The movie was a lot of fun with action all the way. The effects were excellent and the story was compelling and made me want to watch until the end to see the outcome. I find in a movie if I am either rooting for a good guy or against a bad guy then the movie is doing something right and in this I was certainly doing the latter.

I think maybe to improve the movie I would have started and finished in modern day Egypt with some reference to past legends or something - maybe finding some ancient artefact or similar.

But on the whole a good fun movie that is worth watching

review_title: Massive images and Egyptian mythology not enough to save this film.
review_detailed_main:
I love Egyptology and as such I was super excited to see this film and wondered how I missed it when it came out...but now I think I know. I can't begin to tell you how horrible this film was...lots of talking and crazy nonsensical action. And when were Egyptian gods turned in to the robots...or metal encrusted beings depicted here? There were some beautiful images, but probably not enough for me to recommend this big action film to anyone. Lots of well-known actors, but I think they could have used a better script to tell the story... which ultimately is the power struggle between two gods Horus and Set to rule the kingdom of Egypt...which a mere mortal has to teach Horus how to do so.

As a woman I just want to say that the actress who plays Zaya is beautiful enough that it doesn't have to be all about her chest. I thought the actress who plays Hathor was equally lovely, but was more tastefully showing off her assets in a way you noticed how lovely she was and you didn't just notice her chest.

I would say give this a pass.

Personally while I feel there were a great many flaws in the movie. I still found much enjoyment in watching it. Yes the CGI was fairly poor. But it was not so horrendous as to render it unwatchable. I also like Gerald Butler and the guy who played Horus. I would like to see a sequel where Horus goes after the Goddess of Love Hathor. It is in my opinion a worthy buy when it comes out on Blu-Ray. I hope that if they do ever get a green light they fix a few things but in general keep the same flow as they had in this film. I wouldn't mind seeing some of those characters return. Anyways I love Egyptian Mythology and even though this was not something you'd want to base your term paper on. It was still something to eat some popcorn invite a chick over and have a nice evening while watching a action/love story. I may seem to be all over the place but that is because I just finished watching it myself. I wasn't disappointed in the film. Nor did I care that most of the main actors were "White". Personally if you look back in the history of acting it really didn't matter the color or sex as most actors who even played women were men dressed up. So I don't hop on this senseless PC race train. I just watch for the story or the plain entertainment of the film. So I say bring on another one. Or write some cheap novels based off the screen play I'd read it.

It Started well and I was beginning to become interested until the dreaded shakycam kicked off. Quite why they have to relentlessly shake the camera when ever there is a fight or action scene is just plain annoying. I gave it a miss ...

I personally thought the movie was pretty good and has a lot of potential. It contains wild & thrilling actions that keeps audiences excited. It also has a pretty good ending and story structure.

What led to so many critics? There are several reasons to that. 1. It is silly. Not all actors did a great job on their role. Many characters don't seem to be emotionally affected during intense scenes. For example, at a scene were the main character's girl friend died. He seemed sad at first, and seemed to fully recover 30 seconds later... It is just too dramatic for an action movie like this. There were some scenes, where they are trying to be funny; however, it backfires by making it more silly

2. Bad scripts. The wording and the things said in this movie are weird. It just seems weird that in Egypt there is a silly man talking with British accent. The way they talk are too modern. It shows no Egypt culture at all. For example, in one scene; they used the term "pirates" & "ions". Those things didn't even exist back then. There are many more modern term used such as lettuce. It seems to that the characters are 21st century people with costumes on.

3. Bad character/costume choosing. Many actors did not fit well in the movie. Almost 90% of the gods in this movie are white people. No racism here! But they are suppose to be Egyptians; NOT Americans/British! The costume was also do not fit. Set, the fire god was dressed up like a Spartan in 300. Beck's girl friend was dressed up in a typical modern 21 century dress. The sun god Ra, was dressed up like a Pope. The god of knowledge was dressed in a Chinese style silk clothing. Silk didn't even exist back then! That just makes the movie even more silly!

4. Plot with some flaws. There were some scenes or mircales that just happened without any previous explanations.

5. Bad Special Effects. The special effect wasn't as bad as the movie "Kingsmen", but it isn't close to realistic. The special effects did show the 3D background. However, the lighting just seems weird and unreal. To me, it almost seemed like the stones were reflecting light.

The only actor that did a great job was Gerard Butler. He was like the only serious character. I already expected that, since he did a great job on the movie 300 too. This film had a lot of potential, but was ruined by bad casting. Don't blame the director, he did a great job. If it wasn't for the bad casting, I thought it would have earned at least an 8/10 on IMDb.

Of note, I adore this type of silly romp and Gerard Butler is one of my absolute favorites. With that said, could they possible have done a worse job of casting the leads in this movie (It was as if he reprized One Two from, Rocknrolla, but wearing "godly" armor)? There are many excellent actors out there that would have been able to pull off the leads: take Oded Fehr for example; while not from Egypt, he's at least from the same continent and has the look, talent and comedic timing, sorely missing in this movie, to make an excellent Horus (Amr Waked would have made an wicked Set). Pretty much any decent actor would have filled the role of the young hero better than the insipid portrayal by Brenton Thawaites.

Visually this was enjoyable and I wanted to like it. The $17.00 for the (3D) ticket was the only thing that kept me from walking out.

I enjoyed the movie. I found the antics of the character Bek to be mildly annoying yet his total performance was on par. The special effects were impressive and since I am an ancient aliens fan I think the movie was as close as it could get fact wise based on the cast available. Discount the historical inaccuracies, it is an enjoyable movie that will have you doing research on Egyptian mythology. I will say this, the humor and one liners will have you thinking, yet it is the eye candy and fights that will keep you anticipating the next scene. Now the story line is as old as time itself, it worked for me because of the way the story line was presented. Give the movie a chance and remember it is just a movie , not a remote viewing of history.

When this movie came out in theatres I didn't go as the trailer looked awful and critics demolished the movie. Recently I was bored and wanted pass time by watch a movie I hadn't seen and decided to watch this. To summarise I want my 2 hours back. Worst movie of 2016 by a long shot. Please don't watch this if you don't want your IQ level to drop.

review_title: Much better than you have been told
review_detailed_main: So, this is a big budget action and special effects movie about Egyptian gods battling each other to rule the world, right? When you go to a movie like this, you have certain expectations--its not likely to be on the Best Picture short list next Oscar season, and everyone involved with making this movie knew this. But from the very first breathtaking camera shot, you can tell The Gods of Egypt was crafted with enthusiasm and a spirit of fun and unrelenting inhibition. For what this movie was striving for, it is absolutely on target. I saw it on IMax 3-D with my 5th and 7th grade sons, and we loved every minute! Visually dazzling, a soaring musical score, satisfying play-to-the-back-row acting, interesting and somewhat unfamiliar mythological characters, amazing costumes and set pieces--I think this film delivered on all fronts. In a way, Gods of Egypt is more original than many similar films of this genre in that it is not a prequel or sequel or reboot of a franchise, or a comic book adaptation. For instance, while it shares its episodic and implausible plot and style, it is a far more original film than the beloved Episode VII (but without decades of nostalgia and anticipation to paper over its weaknesses). It introduces and creates characters completely new to us in a fascinating and beautiful imaginary world. You will not forget the striking image of the stern but grandfatherly sun god Ra (Geoffrey Rush plays it large here!) circling the disk of the world with his space craft/chariot, sun in tow, as he daily battles a hideous chaos monster in defense of all humanity! The judgment of souls in the underworld is another well-presented scene. Horus has a nice character arc. It ends with a worthwhile message from the gods to humanity. More importantly, it literally offers a thrill or two every 5 minutes for its entire duration. And unexpectedly, this film has no mummies whatsoever! I feel the culturally inaccurate casting issue, while perhaps regrettable, brought an undeserved sense of negativity about this film. In any event, these actors appeared to be 100% invested in making this film work, and they got the job done, in my opinion. We recommend that you set this concern aside and enjoy the many pleasures The Gods of Egypt offers--a no-expenses-spared B movie that presents striking and immersive visuals, appealing characters, and a clear understanding of its limitations and aspirations. I seriously don't understand the horrible reviews, and suppose that people who hated this film probably brought a preconceived negative expectation in with their popcorn. Give it a chance, there is much to enjoy in The Gods of Egypt!

Let me start but saying the obvious that haters going to hate.. You know that its hate when you read"the worst movie ever seen" in a movie with butler and 140m budget.. Don't get me wrong the movie isn't Oscar material or breath taking but surely not 5...

The movie was enjoyable with some good fighting action and nice scenes.Its all about love and that being kind matters(good point if u ask me)

My complaints are that the story is rushed at the beginning and doesn't give time for the audience to like the lead mortal actor "bek" his beloved one zaya.It would make a big difference if the film gave us 10-15 minutes more on just their story of how their love began and where it lead them.

So we have 1 enjoyable movie that makes 2 hours pass lightly. My score is 7/10 just for the "poor" character development of bek and zaya.

review_title: No spoilers because the movie has nothing to spoil.
review_detailed_main: If you have 2 hours to kill and nothing else to do, I would suggest plucking hair from sensitive body parts over seeing this movie. Just plain dumb! Not an Arabic looking actor in the film, the Egyptian God was , I don't know, Scotish? The only redeeming quality the movie had were some very pretty actresses, none of which were or looked Arabic. The plot was inane, Geoffrey Rush was so out of place it was laughable, almost, but not quite as laughable as the set-up for the sequel at the end...don't worry folks, there won't be a sequel. The CGI was over the top, as was the premise. I don't know what the director was trying to achieve other than launch a franchise, in that he failed and failed miserably. I read the movie cost $140 million to make, they will be very lucky to get back 10% of that, and the 10% includes overseas and home sales.

Ridiculous. Six good movies die each time turds like this get made. Ridiculous and tragic.

Apparently, I haven't written enough lines for this to count as a proper review. Fine...

The whole thing is a god-awful mishmash of so many other movies that it gave me a headache just thinking about it: Young Indiana Jones - the thief bits (only Indi wouldn't be caught dead wearing a loincloth), Dune - for the flying sand snake mounts and also for the giant space worm(hole?), 300 - Gerard Butler just won't let it lie, will he?

Anyway, I originally gave this a '2', but because I had to put so much thought into a review I'm reducing it to '1'. Thanks, IMDb!

review_title: Oh God Its Another God Movie
review_detailed_main: After reading several reviews regarding Gods of Egypt, i resigned myself to have a look at the film. I first saw it at the sundance film festival in Honolulu, Where i was cavorting with my pregnant secretary Imelda, this is of course without my wifes knowledge, Anyway back to the film, the Gods of Egypt is a film on par with such other films about Gods and God like things, Charlie Chaplin has a Cameo role playing Charlie Chaplin, the most impressive quality i found in this movie was the lighting set up, which i thought was a unique way to use a torch on a stick, the sound quality was miserable, so was the acting and the dialogue was less engrossing as hearing a potato being peeled. Above all i would recommend this film if you like God and God like things 6/10.

review_title: Like a two hour video game

review_detailed_main:
I am - as quite a few other people - quite a bit surprised by the low rating many gave/give. This is a rather decent entertainment movie, not much more, but also not less.

After I am growing somewhat tired of endless sequel/prequel Starwars, X-men and all the Marvel-stuff (...-men and alike), the turn to Egypt and it's mythology provides quite some freshness, some humour included, and surely a setting we did not see that often in recent years.

So, if I may advise: general rating on IMDb are often rather misleading and you should give this movie sooner or later a chance - it is clearly nice to look at... ;)

review_title: Someone let the special effect team into the candy store.
I mean, what do you expect
review_detailed_main:
Temper expectations, understand the numerous obvious problems, sit backs and enjoy.

Leonidas err, Set (Gerard Butler) takes over Egypt, kills many of the gods and almost kills Horus (Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau). Horus must then get revenge with the help of some mere humans. This is a world with huge gods, magic at every turn and giant monsters. Fine, I accept the world. Now, if you cannot accept the world, if you say, "hey, Egyptian gods were not like ____, and Horus was ____." Then this movie is not for you.

What this movie is about is beautiful women, fun fight scenes and lots of action/humour. Think Indian Jones meets Egypt.

One thing this movie did get flack for was that none of the cast was Egyptian - and this is a very fair criticism, but one for which many more movies than this should feel the heat for. Countless movies with Greek/Middle Eastern cast almost entirely British cast for some reason, yet escape. Why is Butler an Egyptian god? Well, why is he a Greek king? If this movie is taken at all seriously then it falls apart. Sit back, turn the brain off and enjoy a family friendly action adventure.

review_title: Sadly watching this is not a godly experience
After reading the reviews, I thought I was going to waste my time, but...
review_detailed_main: My expectations were clouded by other reviews because there were so much downsizing this movie, I even postpone my trip to the theater to see if this was a razor's edge or if it was dull as a old beat up sword. Long story short, I must admit, I was pleasantly surprised by this movie. The storyline was very well put together. A lot of thought went into this movie and that includes the 3D and special effects. I remember reading about the Gods when I was very young. My parents brought home books that told stories of Gods and Goddesses. So naturally, I was all hyped up about this movie. I can say with this is one of those guilty pleasures of a movie and I plan on watching again and again. I really enjoyed this movie. I am in hopes that this movie will have a sequel with the same level of intelligence, stamina, 3D and special effects to bring the characters to life on the big screen. I gave it an 8 because there were a few places where the story sort of got off track, but not a deal breaker in my book. If you enjoy fantasy and have a thing for Egypt, then this movie may be right up your alley. Just one question, when is the blu-ray going to be released. Sign me up.
I am never going to get those moments back in my life. A complete waste of my time. The original idea was to make a franchise out of this movie. Thank god that did not happen.

I sat through this film mainly because I'm a fan of Gerard Butler but after leaving the cinema I'm not to sure about this fact as the last 2 films I've seen him have been utter rubbish.

More about this film now, Okay I give 1 star for effects and cinematography but the story is so far out there that I got totally bored after 30 mins but just hoped it might get better (it didn't.)

Set in ancient Egypt with over sized gods and mythical beasts of old just didn't do it for me, acting wasn't all that great, and the way in every film Gerard speaks through the side of his mouth with the same accent (Bit like Sean Connery making sure by the end of the film they remember he's Scottish) is getting a little boring now.

So if you like Mythical beasts and gods, give it a go, you may enjoy it, but if you want to see a decent film that's gripping and enjoyable, get a DVD and watch something else.

review_title: It's not as terrible as I thought it would be

review_detailed_main: For some reason I felt guilty giving this movie the "2" it deserves, so three it is. The movie was bad, on all facets. I went into the movie knowing what type of movie it was going to be, so I was not surprised or disappointed by the weak story. It is expected in this genre. The acting was not good. The CGI was bad... My 11 o'clock news' weatherman does more convincing green-screen work. The acting was meh. The Egyptians all looked British and/or American (this was more distracting than it sounds). The tall gods were distracting and Lord of the Rings did a better job with creating the illusion of one 5'9 man being a drastically different size than another 5'9 man, and they did it FIFTEEN years earlier. This was a bad movie, plain and simple.

I wanted to give this a 6.5, but I had to choose between 6 and 7 and so I rounded up. The best way for me to describe to someone who may want to see the movie what they are in for is to compare it to a Transformer movie. It's full of visual effects and a good amount of action, with a very simple plot. The movie has more humor in it than I thought it would. However, it does run a bit long and at times I just wanted the plot to move forward a bit faster. I try to keep my reviews short and to the point. If you are looking for a mindless action flick with lots of special effects, then this would be it. If you don't like action for the sake of action, simple plots, and iffy acting; then I would pass on it.

this has nothing to do with Egypt - just because a few (God) names are borrowed from Egypt doesn't make this an Egyptian story. The clothing may be remotely Roman but certainly not Egyptian. And the only way a son became Pharaoh was after his father's death. The behaviour of people (towards the Pharaoh) is maybe Hollywoodian but again has nothing to do with Egypt. The story in itself is a amalgam of unbelievable and unrealistic scenes whose sole purpose seems to be distraction rather then meaningful entertainment. Save yourself two hours in a movie theatre wondering where this happenstance is going and literally praying for the end.

review_title: From the jaws of death itself
review_detailed_main:
The Australian cinema turned out a real gem of a fantasy film with Gods Of Egypt. Other than references in a lot of Mummy films Gods Of Egypt is the first I know to incorporate the ancient Egyptian religion and mythology in the plot itself.

We're going way back here even before the time Charlton Heston liberated the Hebrew children to a time when Egypt was ruled by their deities who walked among them and took human form. They also could take the shape of some ferocious creatures if need be.

Set and Osiris divided up Egypt back in the day, both sons of the sun God Ra. But Set who only had the desert while Osiris had the good real estate of the Nile and it's cities got tired of this arrangement and slew brother Osiris. He also fought and gouged the eyes out of Osiris's son Horus leaving him a blind and pitiable figure and a living reminder of what it means to cross Set who is played by Gerard Butler with Bryan Brown playing Osiris.

While the Deities are in their turf war mortal Brenton Thwaites gets caught up in it and his girlfriend Courtney Eaton is killed. He wants to get back at Set and would like to team up with Horus if Horus dare permit himself an alliance with a mere human. But Thwaites has some moves and proves to be an unusual and resourceful ally.

If you recognize it the elements from Alexander Korda's Thief of Bagdad loom large and clear here. The chemistry and scenes between Nicholas Coaster-Waldau as Horus and Thwaites is very good and the parallel of the two films is unmistakable. Korda only wished he had the computer graphic technology available when he did his spectacle masterpiece.

Korda's film was shot in Arizona both for the vast scenery and for the fact that Great Britain was at war. The great vast interior of Australia has and will be a choice location shooting spot for a lot of films as travel is now easier to that still remote part of the world.

I liked Brenton Thwaites character very much. In a cynical age where romance is not usually portrayed his was one of the best romantic characters I've seen on the big screen in years.

In fact the very romance of the film made it a winner with me. See this one by all means.

review_title: Utter nonsense but a lot of fun
review_detailed_main: Strangely, I enjoyed this movie. The film itself lacks any real plot line, the script is awful and at times you wonder where the $140 million budget was spent. However, I found myself waiting for the next scene. Butler is by far the stand out performance in this tale of Gods, Mortals and Chaos. He is his charismatic self and although it feels as though the rest of the cast struggle in delivering the lines, Butler adds some 'Earth' to the film. There is not a lot to say about the film itself. Very predictable, yet entertaining. Would I advise anyone to see it, yes I would. If nothing else, the script will make you feel better about yourself.

In truth, I was expecting a horrible movie. And in that way the movie definitely did no disappoint. But to be honest I kind of didn't even expect it to be this awful. The acting is just....oh my god. I just felt awkward. Direction was complete horror. Story was not at all interesting, and the CGI was just so bad it's ridiculous. But if you want a movie to make fun of and cry your eyes out of pure stupidity, than you should definitely watch it. Otherwise, just... Don't. If you have any kind of a good opinion on Nikolaj and Gerard. And Geoffrey Rush. Any of the actors in it. Just avoid it. For the love of god, run away from it. Many people were trying to defend it in a way that it's a ''fantasy movie is supposed to be that way''. OH MY GOD THAT IS NOT TRUE. Cause that just says that every fantasy movie is supposed to be bad?! Come on people..... Wow.

review_title: Gibberish, so bad it can't even entertain
review_detailed_main: Don't get me wrong, I love a CGI fuelled action / adventure film where you can switch off your brain but this was dreadful. Random scenes barely hung together and made no sense. Some great actors but shockingly bad. Avoid.

Ten minutes into the movie, I was certain I was going to hate it. 12 ft gods walking next to 6 ft humans like Snow White and the 7 dwarfs, and all the shiny golden decoration - it was so ridiculous for a first impression. Half an hour later, I had somehow slipped into a mode of enjoying it. It's a tough start, because everything is so far fetched. Dare to open your mind, then it gets more interesting.

In the making-of on my Blu-ray disc, someone says it's rather Planet Egypt than Ancient Egypt, this pretty much nails it. Once you accept that you are in a fantasy world, and also accept its miracles and that gods are weird dudes with golden blood, it's possible to get into it. The world of 'Gods of Egypt' requires some kind of innocent child-like imagination, totally unlike historical dramas such as 'Gladiator'. But isn't that somehow suitable for a mythology from a more innocent age? Some scenes were showing an amazing creative vision, for example Ra's barge floating on water - in space! Pulling the sun over the horizon with a chain of steel! Making the audience believe something like this is a damn hard task. This movie is asking the audience for a lot of imagination, because it is so far from reality, but I'd like to watch it again. Last not least, Coster-Waldau and Gerard Butler were great opponents in the lead roles.
I swear if Hollywood makes one more damn movie full of white ppl based in Africa/Asia/Middle East I'm gonna go crazy

review_title: Gods of Egypt is so laughably bad that it's for sure entertaining
review_detailed_main:
Gods of Egypt is definitely an entertaining movie, but in all the wrong ways. Almost everything about it is hysterically awful. You will laugh your ass off throughout the movie, not because of the "jokes" in the film, but because of the dialogue, the CGI, the acting, etc.

The setting for the movie was to be it's strongest asset. When was the last time we got to see a movie set in Egyptian mythology? However, the movie does not do it's setting justice and people who like the mythology would be ashamed by how the movie interprets it.

The dialogue for the movie is horrendous. Every single line is either an exposition line or a horribly unnatural and forced line. The characters are are all so one-dimensional, each seemingly having only one personality trait, and only a very small amount of characters undergo the tiniest bit of development. Because of this, we're given no reason to care about anyone. A good portion of the lines are so hilarious, not because they were funny, but because they're entertaining in the sense that people actually came up with this dialogue and others approved of it.

Being a huge, high-budget, blockbuster action movie, you would think that it would be at least cool to look at. To be honest, the CGI and special effects are a mixed bag. Most of the time, everything looks awful. There is not a single shot in the movie which looks real and everything is so obviously green-screen. However, there are still a few CGI moments that don't look terrible. However, it doesn't make a movie good, it just means that there are some decent-looking effects in an otherwise garbage movie.

I can't believe the talent behind the movie created such a piece of garbage. I would give it a 1, but the movie is so entertaining because of how bad it is, it gets a 3 purely because it's entertaining. Watch the movie if you're drunk at a party with friends but don't watch the movie because you want to watch an awesome, action-packed movie.

It is a very good action movie to pass your time but not to pay a ticket. For TV movie, it worth your time because is not letting you to be bored. Many battles, good story and nice cast is all you need. Don't inspect much and you will have a great time!

review_title: All Star Cast...... One Star Rating!
review_detailed_main: I usually love movies like this, but the acting is horrendous, the script is terrible, and don't even get me started on the CGI. Not a good movie. The end.

review_title: "If I even tried to explain it your brain would liquify and flow out your ears."
review_detailed_main:
The above Quote in the Movie from "Thoth" says it all.

But here's a Try, Nonetheless...

Outrageously Over the Top may be a Redundant way of Describing Director Alex Proyas' Vision or Version of another "Gods" of Mythology Film that have come "Fast and Furious" to Movie Screens in Recent Years. But this one is more "Fast and Furious" than any.

It Works so Well because, unlike those others (You know who), this Beautifully Garish and Gaudy Movie Never for one Nano-Second takes itself Seriously. It is Presented for Your Consideration as a Dreamscape of Pre-History. The Golden-Age and Speaking of Gold.

In this Fantasyland the Gods actually have Gold Pulsating through Their Veins instead of Blood and that Really-Cool Twist is Reflected in the Template of this Eye Popper at every Turn and every Level.

It is a Film Designed to Push, Stretch, and Reach for the Limits of Current Capabilities concerning CGI in Modern Movie Making. What it Lacks in Thespian Talent, it makes up for in a Grandiose Vision filled with a Colorful Vibrancy.

It's Artistic Scheme of Things Reminds of Comic-Books, Pulps, Heavy Metal Magazine, Computer Games, Poster Art, and other Pop Culture Splashes of Loud, Lurid, Luscious Displays that Attract Attention, if not Praise from the Cultural Elite.

The Tweaking or Embellishment of Egyptian Mythology is Clever and done with a Wink and a Wonderment from a Director that's Not Afraid to Take Chances, Tilt the Windmill, and Challenge the Film-Making Status Quo. Not Everything Works to Perfection but this Piece of Modern Art cannot be as Easily Dismissed by Uppity Critics and Knee-Jerks so Quickly.

This has all the Aspects of a Cult-Movie and while it is Currently Dismissed by most as "God-Awful", Future Reflection and Reaction to this Entertainment will be just the Opposite.

Proyas will be Redeemed as Time Passes, because this is a Timeless Treat for Anyone who can Enjoy Pure, Infectious Eye Candy that has No Pretensions of being anything else.

Watched without any expectations. The special effects were strong and interesting. I didn't feel any connection to any of the characters, didn't feel there was any story arc. The movie seemed to me the equivalent of a firework display; not bad, but just held my interest for the attractive parts.

review_title: Put Aside the Racism Claims, This Movie is Still Really Bad

review_detailed_main:
Nothing too much of noteworthy entertaining in this film. As expected did not enjoy the film and seeing its rating after watching this film, am not surprised at its current 5.4 IMDB rating.

Not particularly too fond of these Greek/Egypt mythology, ancient historical type films but have enjoyed a few. Seeing comparisons with this film to Clash of the Titans, but even though that film isn't great, it is easily more entertaining and enjoyable than Gods of Egypt.

This film as a whole was quite generic, bland and overly long. A story that is predictable and doesn't really offer much of anything new or fresh. Decent visuals but that is to be expected considering its large budget. This was a massive box office flop (noticeable domestic wise) and after viewing this film, one isn't surprised in the slightest.

I've just watched recently on Blu Ray Gods Of Egypt, it was a very enjoyable ride. If the production were using more sets construct it could it been an epic, but that i leave it to the filmmakers. The story is part accurate part fable.It is the time of Zep Tepi (The Fist Time) when the Ancient Gods ruled over men, and how they found them self's in troubles,and struggle by learning their mistake they have learned their lessen through the human beings. The story folows based on the true myth of the Ancient Egyptian Gods, how Osiris was appointed ruler of Ancent Khemet with his sister Isis.
