The movie is very good It could it been an epic if they used more real sets construction and incorporated those elements above. They have spend a lot of money on their costumes that were breathtaking and on the wizardly, not so much on the production sets. But I don't want to ruin the imagination of the Director, everyone is entitled to their own opinion.

review_title: The worst film I have ever watched
review_detailed_main: I can not tell you anything that happened in this movie, as I was just not able to retain any such info. It is clearly the most boring movie I've watched in years and years. I have to admit I did not watch the ending, it seemed many many hours long, and I'm sorry, I just could not finish watching the whole thing. It's difficult to say much more about it than this, I guess it's one of those films where you're better off having a look at the trailer and save yourself the agony of watching

review_title: Even with very low expectations, this turned out to be just okay...
review_detailed_main:
I watched it with low expectations after watching the general score, but after reading the user reviews, I decided to give it a try, unfortunately.

The plot was very expected, and there really wasn't much to it:

SPOILER: - Good guy is becoming the king, bad guy prevents this and becomes the king instead. Defeated good guy mourns in self-pity, until an unexpected nobody comes cheering the defeated good guy back on his feet. Together they fight against the bad king and defeat him, and everyone lives happily ever after. It just couldn't be no more a typical bedtime story, with no whatsoever plot twists. - /SPOILER -


The acting was mediocre, if not pretty bad. There were many new and unfamiliar faces, and I understand why (they were not remarkable). Some of the better ones (Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau (Game of Thrones) and Gerard Butler (300, P.s. I love you)) were average, but otherwise, meh. Okay, if you get past this, you could expect at least a decent and fun action, right?

Well, that didn't go so good either, as the fights were in fact most cases fun to watch, if it wasn't for the, occasionally even horrible, CGI. Most of the movie and fight scenes looked more like a video game, than a movie. Although the choreography could have included some surprises, it'll pass.

Okay, it wasn't probably as bad as I made it sound there, but overall is was okay, and watchable - have seen worse movies. However, there really was nothing new for a fantasy, or an adventure or for an action movie.

It's okay movie for a random movie to watch from Netflix when you are having a hard time making up something else to do. But I wouldn't recommend to pay for it.

review_title: In the span of two hours of dreadful script and forceful plot, any glint of opulence can't save "Gods of Egypt" from being mindlessly numb.
review_detailed_main:
"Gods of Egypt" asks an age old question, "Does flashy sparkle outweighs written words?". Unfortunately for the two hours movie, its visual is inconsistent and the story has so many illogical flaws, that whatever gorgeous scenery it has would feel bland. Furthermore, the acting is sloppy, having less-than-charismatic characters mumbling cringe-worthy monologue for half its time.

This is the tedious story of Horus (Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau), the supposed king of fictional Egypt where gods and mortals live side by side. He then finds opposition from his uncle Set (Gerard Butler). He then forms unusual alliance with Bek (Brenton Thwaites), a human thief with a single-minded drive for juvenile love.

Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau and Gerard Butler are not bad, they have experience on this type of epic saga as Jaime Lannister and Leonidas, respectively. However, this also feels as though they are just going through the motion. Here they are shades, less appealing and more brooding version of their famous roles.

Bek as the other main lead is your typical charming hoodlum without the charm. His characterization is too rigid and any attempt to romanticized or deliver witty humor is instead annoying. The two leading females are too over zealously created for flamboyant melodramatic romance. There are a couple decent supporting cast such as Rufus Sewell as Urshu and Chadwick Boseman as Thoth, but they merely have small portions of spotlight.

The script feels forced to create any chemistry between the characters, however it often sounds like soap opera. Not to mention story line is plagued by awful plot devices. Being gods doesn't exemplify them from having sudden illogical and convenient twists, a few of these might be fine, but after half dozen times audience would appreciate more explanation than simple magic.

Visual is arguably pretty. At its best the movie offers some aesthetically pleasing scenes and the costumes worn as well as the set are very easy on the eyes. Still, among these beautiful people and vistas, it's not often to see it smeared by strangely subpar CGI, as though these are Transformers made from low budget production.

Tainted by shady narrative, corrupted visual and barren script, "Gods of Egypt" is mindlessly numb.

review_title: Bad bad cgi and tolerable storyline
review_detailed_main: Rewatched it (second time). It was actually not bad at all. Storyline was solid, cgi was bad (but tolerable, at least for my eyes). I dont like the idea of changing forms into big messy cgi beasts but its okay (still not a big fan of the ugly transformations). Love few elements from this movie, like the adventure/action reminds me of treasure hunt rpg gaming scenes. Sound scores are okay (just okay!), casts were okay (some miscasts....), world building/fantasy aspects were great. Need better cgi next movies if they thinking of continuing this franschise. Watchable (high rewatching value) and totally recommended.

Yet another mixture of all the famous tropes that you've already seen in a hundred different movies, veiled in a somewhat interesting setting that just doesn't work.

It was an interesting concept, that fell completely flat due to lack of originality in every thing the movie tries to do. Action scenes couldn't convey any emotions, dialogues and plot felt completely bland with a number of low-effort comedy scenes and a cast that simply didn't fit.

But what about the visuals? Well, the movie tried to put special effects in every second of the movie. That resulted in half of them being noticeably terrible and unconvincing. Some of these could be called more or less spectacular, yet certainly hard to appreciate considering how most of it was gibberish.

In case you're still considering going to the cinema: my only advice is to watch the trailer carefully to see if you don't get put off by some of the special effects. If you do, there's much worse to come and you'd better save the money.

Okay, this might not be the best movie ever, or even mediocre in any possible way. So many clichés, too much CGI, not that good acting, etc etc.

But I still enjoyed it very much! Just because sometimes it's nice to entertain yourself with content that's easy to digest. I enjoyed every minute of this dumb fantasy movie and I'm proud to say it!

I wanted to watch this movie in the first place because I wanted some ancient Egypt vibes, Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau and Gerard Butler of course as well, and I got it all. So I've got to just give a tap to the shoulder for this movie and say: you did well.
The story is very good, but the making of the movie was bad I guess. Screenplay was quite nice, emotions are engaging but the bad making did not create impacts.
Egyptian Gods, Set & Horus, clash with eachother over who rules Egypt. Way too many CGI was used, makes watching like a videogame.

I think I was expecting some sort of variation on a superhero movie and I suppose in that respect I should not have been disappointed. Unfortunately I was. It looks very much like most of the budget was spent on the well made but somewhat overblown CGI effects leaving nothing much for hiring actors. I sure I must have seen all of them in other movies but with a couple of exceptions none stuck in my mind and I felt that the film needed more acting gravitas than the cast could muster. There are better mythological epics out there and I'll probably be watching a couple to get the taste of this one out of my mouth. A lot of people will love it but I'm afraid I'm not one of them.

This movie is nothing spectacular But it's Not absolutely horrible as most say. It's simply a fun movie night movie that you won't remember the next day but it's good enough to watch if your bored. The plot is weak and the acting is ok, if their were other actors less skilled it would be much worse but the acting isn't half bad. So to put simply one last time it's an OK Movie you'll watch one time for a brainless movie night and never watch it again lol.

review_title: Gods shouldn't be ashamed, but at least try harder to convince us of their existence...
A good movie but it tries too hard
review_detailed_main:
Yes, it's epic in every way, with a sterling cast, stirring music and more CGI than you can shake a stick at.

And that just might be part of the problem 'cause there's more CGI than actors and, well, heck, don't you just get sick and tired of scene after scene after scene which you know isn't anywhere near real. When you can do absolutely anything, the anything you you do must be truly original and outstanding and that's a far harder trick to pull off.

Not singling out this movie - many blockbusters that rely on CGI hit the same problem. Oh well...

The often-dim lighting, yellow (sand/Egypt - geddit) cast and fast edits don't help with clarity, either.

But it's not a bad movie, sadly it's just a bit of an average one. If you like mythological themes and epic action, go for it. You'll enjoy it.

Well they would have to have theatres to play them in too of course. But I derive and this actually has many flaws. It's way too easy to take this apart on many things. Gerald Butler is overplaying it, the CGI, the story and much more. But why get mad, when you can have fun. And there is a lot of that to be had.

Just dive into this movie and watch it free of all, if you can. Because this is how this wants to be watched. And if you can do that, then you are in for a very fun and entertaining ride. Most of it doesn't make sense and it's more or less one sequence paired with another, but tries to encapsulate the Harryhausen feeling. And in some regards I'd say it did. Before you cry sacrilege (especially because it was real tough work that was put into those stop motion films back in the day), I'm talking about the general vibe. If you can appreciate that, roll with it.

review_title: This is adventure fantasy set in egyptian mythology
Some of the Worst CGI I've Ever Seen
review_detailed_main:
There are many issues with this film. We can start by the fact that yet another Hollywood blockbuster whitewashes what should have been a diverse cast. But even if you can get past the whitewashing, the film itself is pretty big mess. On its premise alone, it borrows from plenty of films we love including Hercules and The Lion King, but the execution is something else entirely. Sadly, talented director Alex Proyas never manages to create something entertaining or thought provoking out of Gods of Egypt.

The films stars Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau and Gerard Butler as Horus and Set, two gods battling it out to be the king of Egypt, Brenton Thwaites as Bek, a mortal who possesses untapped courage, and Elodie Young and Courtney Eaton as the main love interests. As I said, the story isn't all that terrible, the performances and execution of the story is horrific. For a 140 million-dollar film, Gods of Egypt may be the worst looking film I've ever seen. I'm not sure who is in charge of controlling how the budget is being used for this film, but it was not a good job of properly distributing the time and money. Whether it's watching Butler fly through the sky or a halfway decent action scene, the green screen is blatantly obvious.

After a good portion of the 2 hour and 7 minute film, my eyes began to drift. That never happens to me during an action film. I just never found myself caring for the characters. Not necessarily to the fault of the actors, but they didn't do all that much to help their cause. The performances were subpar at best, and even the one really great actor, Chadwick Boseman, was completely wasted. I'm not sure whose idea it was to have Thwaites yell like Tarzan or George of the jungle every time he fell or jumped off rocks, but that was not the best decision to make. Even Jaime Lannister couldn't save this one. I hope to god that London Has Fallen doesn't make it back to back horrible Gerard Butler films.

Alex Proyas went on a social media rant over the wretched reviews the film has received. Even after I went in with even lower expectations because of this, I wasn't impressed in the slightest. I never saw Clash or Wrath of the titans, but I can't help but think the sword and sandal epic is officially dead. The best bet for studios is to stick to what works, and that's disappointing, because this genre has turned out some of my favorite films of all time in Gladiator and Braveheart.

+Some of the action and story potential

-Horrific CGI

-Weak and uninteresting characters

-Boseman wasted

-Whitwashed

3.6/10

review_title: Where as this little gem been
Way too much CGI but spectacular.
review_detailed_main: Can you have too much CGI's in a movie? After watching Gods Of Egypt I came to the conclusion that yes you can. I won't say this movie wasn't entertaining because it was but at one point too much is too much. The problem I had with some of the CGI's was that they looked like CGI's and that's not a good thing. A lot of scenes if not all were shot in front of a green screen and it showed. The things I liked about this movie were the monsters and other creatures, they looked good, so credits to the makers for their vivid imagination. The acting wasn't bad but considering names in the cast you could expect better. The story itself wasn't that great unfortunately. After watching Gods Of Egypt I was wondering if I really needed to see this popcorn movie? Probably not but I guess for a one time viewing it was good enough.

review_title: Marty Stu and the Gods of Egypt
review_detailed_main:
This movie is not well written. The character of Bek doesn't fit in with the rest of the characters. It felt like the writers wrote themselves into the story through Bek. Tagging along with the gods and saving the day. It was like a really bad fan fiction. Not only the writing was bad, the acting as well. All throughout the movie, while Bek is walking around with Horus, he has an absurd smile on his face. He's too happy to be there. This was so distracting from the rest of the movie.

There are several scenes where Bek has to run and dive. It looked like a bad video game. After a while I caught myself thinking in PlayStation buttons while he was running and jumping. XO <- -> XOX

I saw the movie in 3D and it was a mess. At times it was hard to follow what was going on on the screen. If you do decide to see this, watch it in 2D. I would not recommend the 3D version of this.

Too bad though, the director has made some movies that I really like and the actors are usually good in other movies...

review_title: Cheap and cheerful mythology hero movie
review_detailed_main: Fun movie, tongue in cheek lines. Not a classic by any means but everyone in it seemed to have fun. The story is very loosely based on Egyptian mythology. Cute love interests which lead to a predictable end do not ruin what is pure escapism fun. The main characters follow up on the characters they have portrayed in other films or series mainly Game of Thrones and 300. CGI although not cutting edge was OK. The "brainy" god was played with good humour and the sphinx was a bit "Monty Python" not that that's a complaint. Its not Shakespeare or Gladiator..its not even 300 but it was "take your brain out, open a bottle of wine and enjoy!" I would not want to see it at the cinema but as a cheap DVD or sky download its certainly not the worst I have seen!

I can't really speak to the entire movie, because as soon as I finished my medium popcorn I got up and left. Another patron must have purchased a small size, because she left before I did. And, as there were only four of us in the theater, in a small town in the afternoon, that was half of the viewers! Nothing was engaging. I'm not normally a sci-fi, mythological, special effects, solid action type of movie-goer. I went to see "Thor" because it was all that was playing and LOVED it, because it was a good and very entertaining movie, snappy dialogue, etc.

This movie was just plain awful. I couldn't believe the crappy special effects, especially in light of some of the amazing movies out lately (like Thor). The dialogue sucked. The big-God/little-mortal thing was creepy.

I believe I've only walked out of two movies in my whole life: The Leopard with Burt Lancaster (yes, back when dinosaurs roamed the earth) and Wild Hogs (but I rented that, so I it doesn't really count). Of course, I try not to go see crappy movies in the first place. Gods of Egypt - my bad.

review_title: What you would expect it to be.......
review_detailed_main:
If like me you have been around a while you start to see patterns in genres of film. Gods of Egypt is pretty much what you would expect from a action/fantasy film.

This flick takes a basic myth based framework and tweaks it to present a passable, predominantly exposition based, eye candy orientated film with a small side order of morality tale.

That's not to say Gods of Egypt isn't entertaining. I'd argue its light weight, simple fun, thats probably going to look good on a large screen LCD with a surround sound system. Don't for a moment consider taking this film seriously, it might have a reasonable cast and not half bad acting but it is, what it is, an action film first and foremost.

I enjoyed Gods of Egypt, its well paced and quite watchable. A good one to share with friends and family over some chips and popcorn. Six out of ten from me.

review_title: What in Ra's name was Gods of Egypt supposed to be? It's so bad that it's kind of enjoyable
review_detailed_main:
Three years ago, I was at the California Science center in Los Angeles where I got to see an exhibit on Ancient Egypt based on the pharaoh Cleopatra. The experience featured several artifacts from the era that have been collected below the Mediterranean Sea and showcased a time full of gods and a collective tribute to the afterlife. This was one of my favorite museum pieces and reminded me that I used to really enjoy the history of ancient Egypt back when I was a kid. I think it was the fact that the Egyptian world was both beautiful with its pyramids and gold and disgusting with its obsession with death.

Ancient Egypt has been present in a lot of biblical based features like The Ten Commandments and The Prince of Egypt. The fascination of the country grew upon even more with the discovery of King Tut and the curses supposedly set upon those that opened the tomb. Presenting it in film is nothing new, but I can honestly say I have not seen anything about the Egyptian gods like Ra and such. Gods of Egypt does this and is a throwback to classic sword and sorcery movies like Jason and the Argonauts.

Though the setting is ancient Egypt, the story is set in an alternate world where the Earth is flat and the gods rule over the mortals. In fact, King Osiris is about to hand the throne over to his son Horus (played by Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau), but a surprise visit from Set (played by Gerald Butler), one of the sons of Ra, changes everything. Set kills Osiris, takes Horus' eyes, and takes the throne. A year passes under the new rule where mortal Bek (played by Brenton Thwaites) is a common thief who is looking for his love, Zaya.

Zeya gets killed and Bek decides that exiled god Horus is the only one who can bring her back. He takes her to him, but Horus says that he needs his eyes back in order to bring back the dead (and to be able to change into a god-like animal). They strike a deal to get the eyes in exchange for saving Zaya's soul in the afterlife. The briefly receive help from Ra (played by Geoffrey Rush) in his floating vessel above the Earth before returning to finish the quest. They are racing against the clock as Set is obtaining godly items in order to increase his power.

Gods of Egypt is so fascinating! Not that it's a good movie (not at all!), but this is an example on how one can take an intriguing idea for an adventure and do almost everything wrong with it. The script is wrong, the castings wrong, the effects are wrong, and the overall direction is all over the place. The movie has gained controversy for having no Egyptian actors and it's weird how not only are there no Arabic people of any kind, but the majority is white (its even more embarrassing with Gerald Butler doing his thick Scottish accent in an Egyptian world).

I have no idea how lazy the director was, but you'd think he would have taken another look at the computer effects and realize that maybe their not done yet. It's obvious that the majority of the film was made in front of a green screen. The lighting never convinced me once that they were outdoors. While some of the background shots look cool, most of the monsters and magical elements seem more like out of a video game then a Hollywood movie (I had this problem with Maleficent). These people need to learn from Guardians of the Galaxy and Star Wars: The Force Awakens with how proper effects are pulled off.

I'll give this two Egyptian Ra's out of ten. I cannot recommend this as a genuine good movie, but I can recommend it for something else. Like how Battlefield Earth and The Room were made, Gods of Egypt is so bad that within its demented sense, it's actually kind of enjoyable. I could easily see this as an easy target for comedians to point out all the problems. So if your looking for something to laugh at and not with, wait for this to come out on DVD and put yourself in an strange Egyptian mind frame.

HOW DO YOU HAVE AN ALL WHITE CAST FOR A MOVIE ABOUT EGYPTIANS WHICH EXIST IN Africa. Americans make me sick . horrible movie just shows the continuous racism in Hollywood and in life .I hope filmmakers get it together. cultural appropriation at its finest . if you want to see a move about the history of BLACKS portrayed by and all WHITE cast this is the movie for you. Can't believe there's even 5 star ratings for this film. lions gate needs to get it together and so do the reviewers . The fact this movie was even created makes me want to vomit . It's like casting a black man as the role of Hitler . Seriously sickened by this . only reason I haven't finished is because of the stupid IDBM guidelines

review_title: Spectacular visuals and a clever story
review_detailed_main:
I enjoyed this over the top extravagant adventure set in Ancient Egypt.

Good points: The script cleverly uses the legends of the Egyptian gods. It's fun to see the god brought to life and transform into various birds and beasts. Now everyone can visualize the gods instead of imagining them from a 2 dimensional painting on a wall. The tale of Horus avenging the murder of his father Osiris by fighting Set is brought to life. There is quite a lot of dialog and humor for a movie of this type.

The visuals are spectacular dizzying and fantastical. You get some pretty impressive cities temples caves tombs pyramids and the underworld. It's true they have gone a bit overboard with the sets and scenery that border on gaudy and crowded to be distracting. Egypt is just made to look too colorful, and there are too many massive heights to plunge down cliffs and waterfalls. Egypt is a pretty flat country and it just seemed a bit too much. But in the end even if it was too over the top at least it felt grand.

Weak points: The cast was hit and miss. Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau as Hathor looks more like a bad guy than a good guy - he should have been the villain Set instead. As Set, Gerard Butler's Scottish accent was jarring. Australians Brenton Thwaites and Courtney Eaton make the cute young mortal couple. Again their clipped British accents were out of place. It would have been better if they spoke with more neutral slightly Middle Eastern accents so as not to be so incongruous. This is tied in with the controversy that the cast was not ethnically correct. This is partly right with the very blonde actresses in various supporting roles and Geoffrey Rush as Ra is out of place. Chadwick Boseman is the only actor of African descent in a major speaking role. But this mistake in casting isn't a fatal flaw. At least Elodie Yung as love interest Hathor looks a bit more ethnically suitable and she is quite beguiling.

Some of the fighting was a bit dizzying and formulaic. A bit headache inducing.

Bottom line - this is a grand blockbuster with it's clever story using Egyptian legends. Worth a watch on the big screen.

This movie could have been so much better. The ideas were there, the entertainment value was there, the visuals, the cast... but yet somehow the script looked like it had been written by someone who had no idea of how to finish on the same high note as the ideas on which the movie was based. And a number of moments in the movie, where simply waiting a few seconds longer, before delivering a line or switching to the next scene would have made all the difference between epic moments or stupidly rushed parts with resulting lost effect. And this last bit, they did a number of times during the movie. It was pitiful to see such potential go to waste. Alas...

So, should you see the movie? Yes. Even though they missed and or simply messed up various opportunities for greatness, such as cobras as scary as and about the size of Godzilla dying way too easily; the movie has entertainment value. Just make sure you disengage your critical mind long enough, it'll work. And pray, that the high school teen who was lucky enough to have gotten his first draft made into a movie, has learned how to clean up his work, and that the weirdness between the directing and various badly timed delivery of lines which ruined what could've been epic moments, is figured out and solved by the time this crew puts out another project...

review_title: Big Screen Popcorn Movie, Not Cinematic Gold
review_detailed_main:
Amidst the current climate of unrest regarding the issue of racism in Hollywood, Gods Of Egypt hasn't escaped scot-free. Similar to the film Exodus: Gods And Kings, which was also set in Egypt, there has been much talk about the fact that there are non- Egyptians playing Egyptian characters. To me, I don't think this was necessarily a conscious decision by the casting agents to directly exclude Egyptians out of sheer racism. I genuinely believe this was just a case of hiring the right people for the job. I don't think it'd be right for a studio to deliberately seek out actors of a certain racial background and ignore others who might actually be a better fit. I could be wrong – there could have been a multitude of tremendous Egyptian actors and actresses who auditioned and subsequently weren't hired. Either way, I don't think this should affect the success of a film and the level with which we enjoy it.

Okay! Now that the serious stuff is over and done with, let me get to the fun stuff this movie was shot in my hometown of Sydney (yay!). It's great to witness the generation of local jobs in the film industry, so this is something I'm super proud of. We were able to showcase our range of extremely talented Aussies, both in front of and behind the camera, including the likes of Hollywood heavyweight Geoffrey Rush, legend Bryan Brown and starring up-and-comer Brenton Thwaites who already has several big films under his belt, such as Maleficent, The Giver and Son Of A Gun. He had his first big break in Home And Away, which has been the stepping stone for many a successful actor (ahem, did someone say Chris Hemsworth?). Also starring in this epic feature are international talents Gerard Butler (looking great in a skirt and why wouldn't he, he's Scottish) and everyone's favourite incest Lannister twin, Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau. The film was also directed by Egyptian-born Aussie Alex Proyas who has directed a range of hugely popular movies, including I, Robot, Knowing, and the cult-hit – and one of my all-time faves – The Crow.

From the opening scene until the end credits, the set design was phenomenal. Everything was on such a large scale, with intricate costumes to boot. This, along with the great cast, was unfortunately the only highlights for me. The dialogue was often stilted and unnatural and the visual effects were hit and miss. There were many similarities between this title and the 2010 remake of Clash Of The Titans, which won't bode well for some. In saying that, when they got it right, it was amazing to see on the big screen and I believe this is definitely a big-scale film made to be seen in theatres if you're willing to pay the inflated cinema ticket price, that is.

motherofpopcorn.wordpress.com

review_title: A poor film but an entertaining one
review_detailed_main: 8 out of ten for creativity, 8 out of ten for action, 6.9 out of ten for acting, and an 10 out of ten for being a cheesy but fun ride. This ins't an art film, this isn't like a film you win Oscars for. Its for a fun ride and it delivered in an epic way. This film is better than a 5.3 and a 25 Metascore. If i could rate this film with decimal points i would give it a 6.3 if i was going to judge it on them movie itself. But an 7.9 to an 8 on its genre It fits into the blockbuster film genre. To be honest its not film its just a movie. So stop treating it like its trying to be a good film and more like its trying to entertain and make money as a movie.

First of all: why are all the actors white? It's like making a movie about the founding fathers of the USA and casting everyone with Chinese actors. Or doing a movie about the second world war and casting Winston Churchill and all other English with black actors. At best, it's just weird.

Rarely does one come across a movie that fails so miserably and completely as this one. Horrible in every respect: the acting, the story, the visuals. Most of all, it's a completely soulless and boring movie.

If you love ancient Egypt - you will hate this movie. Don't waste your time.

review_title: Gods of Egypt is a typical fantasy based on Egyptian mythology with good VFX but poor writing and clichéd dialogues
review_detailed_main:
Gods of Egypt (2016): Once in a while,Hollywood always have a movie on Egyptian mythology which fail miserably(most of the times). Gods of Egypt is such a movie which repeated the same fate this year too.With huge casting and budget,Gods of Egypt has lot of features which has disaster all over it.

Plot: In the ancient Egypt, the god Ra (Geoffrey Rush) has split Egypt in two: the fertile part with the Nile would be ruled by his son Osiris ( Bryan Brown) and the desert by his son Set (Gerald Butler) . During the coronation of Horus ( Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau) by his father Osiris, Set betrays his brother and kills him. Then he withdraws the eyes of Horus that are his source of power and exiles him in the desert. The mortal thief Bek (Brenton Thwaites) and his beloved wife Zaya(Courtney Eaton) that worships Horus become slaves of Set. Zaya, who is working for Set's architect Urshu (Rufus Sewell), convinces Bek to steal the eyes of Horus from a well-protected pyramid designed by Urshu to give them back to Horus, the only one capable to defeat Set. Bek succeeds but retrieves only one of the eyes; however Urshu discovers the theft and Bek and Zaya need to flee. Urshu kills Zaya with an arrow and when Bek reaches Horus' shelter, he proposes to help the god to retrieve his other eye. In return, he demands that Horus bring his beloved Zaya back from the underworld. They team up and soon Horus' lover Hathor (Élodie Yung) , the goddess of love, leaves Set and joins them in their quest to defeat the evil Set. Did Bek help Horus in defeating Set and did he get Zaya back???

Plus Points:

1)VFX: God of Egypt has good visual effects.Even though there are less 3D effects,others are eye feast.Egypt locations and sets are well made.

2)Performances: Everyone gave decent performances.Brenton as Bek,Nikolaj as Horus and Courtney as Zaya gave good performances.Gerald Butler as Villain is weird but good.

Minus Points:

1)Story: Gods of Egypt has typical plot where fight against evil brother by an abandoned family member:( Used since ages

2)Duration: This movie has duration of 2hr 08min which may not seem long but felt so long.

3)Dialogues: They are so clichéd that I got confused to watch it as either an adventure or a comedy...

So,Gods of Egypt is a typical fantasy based on Egyptian mythology with good VFX but poor writing and clichéd dialogues

My rating 5.5/10

Nikolaj, Nikolaj... How could you tarnish your reputation with this movie? :-D

The movie had potential, not a bad story, not a bad cast, not a bad cgi team etc. Problem is, it just doesn't work in this case.

There is so much cgi in this movie, so the acting suffers from Star Wars I-III syndrome. The story is actually not bad, for a "fantasy action" movie. Unfortunately, Gerard Butler speaking with his thick Scottish accent as an Egyptian God, diverted my focus from the story. Don't get me wrong, he's not a bad actor per se. But a Scottish speaking Egyptian God...!? At some points in the movie, it felt a lot like watching a sequel to 300. Yeah, that's actually perhaps the best advice I can give...

If you liked 300, you will probably like this movie!

(Gorgeous women in it too!!!)

I usually don't watch this kind of movies anymore - if you check my ratings or watch list; you'll see they are either classics, independents, award winners or more artistic films mostly from Europe.

Since my wife loves Egypt history, I got this one to just watch movie for making fun and probably not watching until the end.

The first minutes of the movie seemed as I expected, especially the American characters and accent was kind of disturbing and hard to blend in the movie. After a while, we got pulled in the movie somehow and enjoyed watching it except some cliché love dialogues here and there.

It's got what it takes for a movie, good acting, coherent scenario, no surprises with a good guys win ending.

I am sure action lovers will definitely love this movie and others would enjoy it. Recommended.

This is one of the most yawn inducing movies ever. I mean forget about the unknown cast but the story is so uninteresting that i fell asleep during the anti-climatic battle and had to rewind to see what happened. Gerard butler the biggest star in the movie couldn't even salvage it as he was hardly in the movie and though he is supposed to be an Egyptian god and he could hardly let go of his Scottish accent. The acting was bad, the script was poor, the action kinda sucked and it was really uninspiring. This movie is best reserved for a guy that brings a girl home and wants to bang her and doesn't know how to fill up time before they start to enjoy themselves

review_title: a well made film with messages
I liked it better in Thor(2011)
A Visual piece of no story
review_detailed_main:
At first i was actually excited for this film, saw an interview with Gerard Butler, where he was trying to say this was going to be his "Gladiator" and then i saw the trailer. The trailer shows what you are expecting, and that is a visual spectacular of the mythological gods and cities of ancient Egypt. It also alludes that there film is based on some story. That is a lie.

I don't usually do negative reviews. Unless the film is really terrible, and even so i like to talk about the positive aspects of that film too. So I will start with the positives. The film has some pretty cool visuals for most parts, and I do mean for most part, there are moments where it looks like you are watching cinematic clip from a game that is equivalent to PS3 graphics. The rest of the film is filled with colorful and what i'm hoping for is expensive CGI to make the film stand out on its own and bring people into the cinema to get their money back. Because honestly neither the story or the acting would do that.

Story: now i'm not really sure who wrote the script, and where was the script supervisor during production. The story was all over the place, and just to give you an idea of what i mean. Why is that gods can die? why are they bigger then humans? and if only gods are bigger then humans to showcase that they are gods, then what about their big guards? are they demi gods? why do they bleed gold? why do they not get stronger from the prayers of mortals. Why is one mortal has the speed of a god, and the strength to withhold a gods mighty punch??.. So, there are a lot of questions and plot holes to ask and cover. That's why i choose to skip over it. its simpler like that.

Acting: I really have to say that acting was pretty terrible. Not just from new comers, but even from A-list'rs like Butler,Rush and Waldau. But it wasn't as bad as the new faces that played the love couple or the actress that played the love interest of Horus.

Overall this film fails, not for it's lack of originality, but for trying to be too original and skipping over a lot of important information and key turns in the film, for allowing the film to have scenes which looked out of place and felt like they were made on Windows 97, and for really bad use of Green screen. The ride through town on the chariot is a perfect example.

I guess that's a Hollywood thing. The statues where also not correct in the introduction. I found it to be just a lazy production. I also felt the screening was wrong. At times it felt like the camera shots where framed to far at times. East Enders in Africa is how I would describe this for friends. The narration should have stopped but it drones on seeking to save more money on actual screen play. you may find a few miss matches in sets due to mixing scenes like a day time TV feel show then back again.

There is NO excuse anymore for Hollywood and the amount of the budget spent in this movie. This is the type of movie that even a 15 year old could not stand to see. It is awful, full of CGI and no dialogue at all. I think the writers were drunk or something when they composed this ''masterpiece''. So you thing that the big stars would 'save' some of the movie but NO. In the whole movie their acting is below the average + their useless ''humor'' adds nothing to the childish scenario. I really hope that you didn't spend any money to the theaters to see it. I could even say this : someone is trying to make us more and more stupid and this someone is Hollywood's blockbusters.

review_title: Dear Critics: Where Is Your Imagination?
review_detailed_main: In a world where the evening news breaks your heart or makes you angry every single night, we turn to movies for entertainment...we look to them to escape reality for a couple hours. Even with drama, when we're watching it, we forget our own problems and worries. Gods of Egypt is a movie that does what movies are supposed to do. Gerard Butler has always said how much he loves telling stories, and this is absolutely a story. It's a whole other world. It's the definition of imagination. Yes, it may be silly to some. Sure, it may not be as accurate as some people would like it to be. But it's fun and thought-provoking and intense and beautiful and dream-like and diverse. Really, though, it's the type of movie where you really do need to see it for yourself. Go ahead and see it. Let yourself be immersed in this fantasy world for a couple hours. Be entertained. Let these actors tell you a story.

review_title: Was putting off to see this movie, but.....
review_detailed_main: I hardly wanted to see this movie after reading all the negative reviews but then again, I hardly believe reviews anymore. A lot of people hated it but I was surprised at how lighthearted and entertaining it was. CG was excessive and not all that good at some points but never too terrible. Its not a box office movie, sitting in the cinema through it isn't all great but will be highly enjoyable at home on Bluray lets say. So yes, it doesn't accurately portray Egypt and takes a massive dump on fact and history but it was enjoyable, plot straight forward, characters likable and some i hated, plenty of action and overall a watchable movie. Some people hate particular fruits, colors, smells....some don't, its the same with movies, some might enjoy movies that others bash into the ground....like this one.

review_title: Don't give it a chance...it doesn't get better
review_detailed_main:

The attractive the cast - and the female lead is stunning if you like your women all soft and dewy, inspire zero empathy and after a few minutes you find yourself paying more attention to the pizza topping if you are lucky enough to have that distraction.

Gerard Butler is wafer thin as the bad God, and Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau has a more interesting name than his performance as the hero God with the funky eyes in this.

Maybe all the money went, or more accurately was wasted, on CGI instead of on the script, editing, cinematography, direction, and in fact everything else.

The only way to get any enjoyment is to turn the sound off and pretend its a visual effects demo

Most of the fighting scenes were absolutely abusing rotating cameras, to the point it was annoying. Also the diealogues were quite cheesy and the story quite predictable and full of cliches. As a balance of the movie, I've got very beautiful landscapes and designs in general, kind of likeable characters and a lot of action, but it's definitely not to be taken too seriously, besides the fantasy, it's quite silly.

A fun movie that doesn't try to be anything more than that. The cast is good, the characters are fun and the directing is decent. Gerard Butler is hilarious as Set but the other characters are fun too, especially Geoffrey Rush as Ra. An entertaining film work that does not take itself seriously and thus gives us an escape from reality, and that is the primary purpose of the film. The effects are good, and it's especially fun to see Ra fighting Apophis. The 3D effects are also not bad and make the movie more fun to watch. In short, decent entertainment with good visuals and interesting and fun characters.

This film has the dubious honor of being one of the few I have not been able to finish; no idea way it has such high marks here. The plot, if any seems to be written by a teenager; transformers seems a piece of art next to this low level work. I sincerely recommend people not wasting time with this movie. The opening of the movie in Egypt seems quite messy, and the battle that ensues makes whatsoever no sense, from my point of view. The CGI is not enough to mask what is lacking in other departments. As I said, I have not finished the movie, and have not whatever desire to come back to it again in a near future. It is a shame, because I do actually like films related to Egypt mythology, and the film had so much potential and background to draw on, that was wasted.

I just saw Gods of Egypt with my 5th and 7th grade boys on 3D Imax, and we loved it! An original movie for a change, not a sequel, or prequel, or reboot, or franchise, or comic book adaptation, or spin-off film. This movie had very striking visuals, sweeping music, fun acting and action sequences, and engaging characters. It moved along very briskly, despite its slightly long run time. We had no difficulty following the plot (which is certainly no less plausible or linear than Episode VII!) or understanding who the somewhat unfamiliar Egyptian mythological characters were as some reviews suggested we might. There was a nice character arc for Horus, and even a thoughtful message from the gods to humankind at the end. Ethnically inaccurate casting choices--yeah, it would have been nice to see a more authentic cast, but these actors got the job done, and that is no reason to skip the movie if you like this sort of film, in my opinion. Give this film a chance, you may enjoy it much more than you expect!

review_title: If you can overlook that racist injustice, the movie isn't that bad.
review_detailed_main:
'GODS OF Egypt': Three and a Half Stars (Out of Five)

Big budget action-fantasy flick, from director Alex Proyas (the man who also helmed such beloved fantasy hits as 'DARK CITY', 'KNOWING', 'I, ROBOT' and 'THE CROW'). It was written by Matt Sazama and Burk Sharpless (the duo that also co-wrote such other mythical fantasy flicks as 'DRACULA UNTOLD' and 'THE LAST WITCH HUNTER'). The movie notoriously stars a mostly white cast of actors, as Egyptian gods and mortals: that are battling for all of Egypt. The cast includes Gerard Butler, Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau, Brenton Thwaites, Elodie Yung, Courtney Eaton, Geoffrey Rush, Bryan Brown, Rufus Sewell (who also starred in 'DARK CITY') and Chadwick Boseman (the one cast member of African decent). Despite being cheesy, and over-the-top, I mostly enjoyed the film.

The story is set in a fictional Ancient Egypt; where the god Horus (Coster-Waldau) is about to be crowned the king of all of Egypt. Then Horus's vengeful uncle, Set (Butler), kills Horus's father, Osiris (Brown), and steals Horus's eyes; while taking the throne for himself. He plunges the peaceful Egypt into a world of darkness; where citizens must pay their way into the afterlife. A mortal thief, Bek (Thwaites), teams with Horus; to stop Set, and restore Egypt to it's past greatness.

Proyas is a very talented director, and he doesn't disappoint here; the script could have used a little more work, but the movie is still a lot of fun. It's entertaining, action-packed and filled with colorful visuals. The performances are all decent enough, but it would have been nice to see a lot more ethnic diversity (if the studio would have just banked on more minority actors). Proyas has listed many reasons (why it was financially safer) to cast the actors he did. If you can overlook that racist injustice, the movie isn't that bad (it's mostly entertaining). Fans of the genre should get a kick out of it.

Watch our movie review show 'MOVIE TALK' at: https://youtu.be/8JsPKeI7y6U

review_title: Stay Home. Pet a Porcupine. Do anything other than see this movie.
review_detailed_main:
I'm going to keep this short because I don't want this movie to waste any more of your life than it has to.

Garrish, oversaturated, blindingly horrendous CGI effects. It's so bad a cartoon would seem more realistic.

Much of the acting is less than stellar with wooden delivery at times. The story is tired, cliché, boring and predictable. It never feels as though there is anything at stake. The characters were poorly developed. Not only did I not feel any connection with them, I didn't WANT to have any connection with them.

I loved some of Proyas' other films (Dark City, The Crow) and really wanted him to succeed. It was only out of support for him I went to go see this film and had extremely low expectations given the negative reviews. Unfortunately, after seeing it, many of these negative reviews gave him way too much credit. It's obviously not the worst movie ever made, but it's so difficult to sit through I don't care about the difference.

review_title: White Egyptians and perfect annunciation ruin the illusion
review_detailed_main: I thought this was quite a good movie in the end, however, there were certain things which you had to get past and, for many, that was probably impossible. Firstly and most ludicrously, 99% of the cast is white and just didn't work, on any level, for a movie set in Egypt. Secondly, everyone has a ridiculously overdone generic English accent. What Americans don't seem to grasp is that (a) less than 0.1% of English folks just don't talk like that (b) English is not about pronouncing every single letter in every single word, perfectly. Even the poshest of folks don't speak like that - I think THAT is the movies biggest problem. The actors seem so preoccupied about perfect annunciation that they forget to act naturally. The black fella, Chadwick Boseman, who played 'Thoth', is especially guilty of this and his dreadful attempt at being English ruins his character's credibility; if he'd spoken with an American accent, no one would have noticed as much. The CGI is fabulous and the story isn't a bad one. The casting was a bit off and it did come across a bit like they'd spent so much on cgi that there wasn't enough for some more proper actors. I couldn't put my finger on what was wrong at first and then it dawned on me. It was as ludicrous as casting white folks in 'Roots' and asking them to do African accents. Once I forgave the actors for this I really started to enjoy the movie. Please, please, whoever made this movie; if you are thinking of doing a sequel, fix these major issues! Because there were no indigenous Egyptians and no attempt was made to even disguise the actors to look like any, you just never buy into the movie 100%. It doesn't feel like ancient Egypt and you have to work really hard to get your head around that. We have among others, Danish, American and Australian actors - who's idea was it to make them all speak in this ridiculous fashion?? Anyway - try to ignore this and it's quite a good film.

review_title: A feast for the eyes, a nightmare for your ears.
Don't be in de Nile! You know, damn well, this movie wasn't good. However, it's not as bad, as people make it out to be
Above Average but good story line

CGI/special affects definitely should have been better but script and acting made it acceptable. Even had decent romance and quality morals to the story.

I hope I don't have to see him in another movie ever again! WHY GERARD, and WHY NICOLAI, WHAT DID THEY BLACKMAIL YOU GUYS WITH???

Well.. The thing is that this might work for small children. They are more forgiving, what confuses me is people writing good things about this. That cannot be possible in any level at all.

They should have killed the bad CGI with good setting. Turned on some old INDIANA JONES skills and actual creating some of the scenes instead of making hopless scenarios you can never relate too..

Since when is a movie not black enough? There were blacks and whites in important roles here. I ignored the bigotry of other reviewers and am glad I saw it.

This is a remarkable entertaining movie.

The cast, scenery and effects are beautiful.

The 3D is fantastic here.

The script is linear and heart touching.

This movie lets us experience what the people of ancient Egypt imagined of their gods. It is the best movie on this I've seen.

review_title: A fight among the gods, for the Egyptian empire.
review_detailed_main:
I like this director, but this is not his best work. I think the Hollywood fed up with Greek stuffs, now they're looking at the ancient Egypt. Where's the next stop? India? This film was not a bad idea. I liked the story, a mission based concept, but I did not like the CGI. Visually, it was okay, though those CGI characters felt like they're from sci-fi. I think they inspired by the ancient Egyptian arts. Other than that, this film is enjoyable.

At least I knew about Greek deities, I learnt a few words and names about Egypt mythology through this. Gerard Butler in a negative shade was good and the other actors too decent. I was not interested in this film, but now somewhat I enjoyed it, that mean they should stop it here, no sequel please.

I had no issue with the casting, it is a marketing strategy. You can't just put a new foreign face in front of the camera and make money out of it. Cinema itself means fake display. Age, skin, death, everything is fake. So people must learn to accept it similar to when a black, Malaysian or Indonesian man says he's a mooslim, but genetically he's not, just converted to.

Well composed stunt sequences, especially bloods with liquid gold, totally got the PG13. Least expected film of the year, but got entertained better. It got the mixed response and mostly negative feedback from the critics, but who knows you might have a good time like I did. So you could try it if you want in your free time, because it is not worth to spend your valuable time.

6/10

review_title: Waste of time and heavily disappointed
review_detailed_main:
One of the worst movies of year! Pathetic.. no flow.. things just happen randomly. Felt sorry for the actors as they really worked hard to create the atmosphere. They actually seemed out of place. Gerald Butler should have stayed away from this movie - it will haunt him.

Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau was not the right person for the role. The character development happened faster then he could up.. I blame the script!

CGI is pathetic. Quality of effects could have been achieved in the 90's. CGI reminded me of Captain Power and the Soldiers of the Future from my childhood :D

Should have been a direct to video.

Conclusion: Waste of Time.

It's adventurous and very entertaining. Seeing the low rating I thought the movie was bad and hadn't watched it for so long. Today I simply gave a try. And wow! It's kinda underrated. The CGI is good, story is average. But the adventure is really cool. It entertained the kid in me. I din't even feel disappointed. It's a pretty cool movie.

Who wouldn't love a good fantasy action adventure flick? It turned out much better than I expected. Those few good movies which are underrated but are pretty good. This is one of them. It's very satisfying!

Sometimes you've to ignore the rating and just watch the movie so that you'd know you'd like it or not. Not every movie has to be incredible. Not every time the rating is gonna help you out with picking a satisfying flick. That's what I learn every now and then. Watch and enjoy. Cheerio!

This is my review of Gods of Egypt (spoiler free)

* (1/5)

Cast: Brenton Thwaites, Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau, Gerard Butler, Courtney Easton, Geoffrey Rush.

Plot: Mortal hero Bek (Thwaites) teams with the god Horus (Coaster-Waldau) in an alliance against Set (Butler), the merciless god of darkness, who has usurped Egypt's throne, plunging the once peaceful and prosperous empire into chaos and conflict.

I just want to start off by saying this film is abysmal in fact it is worse than abysmal. As far as summer blockbusters go this is by far the worst. Gods of Egypt is one of those rare films were the mortal is the hero. Director Alex Proyas concentrates on making this film action packed and look really pretty rather than focusing on an actual plot. This film is completely packed with CGI and it does look astonishing it's that that the story makes it a worthless experience.

This film packs in a lot of action mainly caused by Set (Butler) whose character looks very bad-ass but that is all that is working for him. This movie could have been a lot better if not for the idiotic story kind of like Clash of the Titans. This is probably going to be the biggest flop this year which is a shame because the hype was so high, and made on a budget of $140 million that money just made the movie look pretty and the actors in this were just cannon fodder.

Another thing is that this movie contains some of the biggest stars in Hollywood for example Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau whose known for playing Jaime Lannister in Game of Thrones. Although Gerard Butler hasn't done anything good since 300 (2006) just a matter of an opinion. The one person that has gone down in standards is Australian actress Courtney Eaton previously known from last years action masterpiece Mad Max: Fury Road.

Here are some points as to why this is the worst summer blockbuster:

Plot: As said before the plot is just non existent see normally films that have the main character as a mortal and he becomes a hero are well paced and a delight, but this is far from that with this your brain will just melt because of the stupidity. Essentially the plot of this movie should say witness my action and my pretty because that's all it's good for, just a poignant mess.

Acting: Now the acting is very complex sometimes it's good and sometimes it is not but most of the time it is just, just an added feature. While choosing the casting they just picked who thought would make this movie good they were picked at random, sometimes a good thing but in this case it is to be avoided. Some of the actors in this film are prestigious legends like Geoffrey Rush who is known for The Kings Speech (2010), the Australian actor made that film good and watchable, but for this even with his performance I was begging for it to end.

Other than that this film is exceptionally gorgeous but this summer could been without it.

Verdict: Very good looking, stupid and quite frankly doesn't even feel like it should even fall into the so bad it's good. It is eternally bad and should be forgotten.

2/10 dreadful and an absolute mess.

review_title: It's a fantasy movie, not historical fiction
review_detailed_main: Don't take the movie seriously when you watch it, it's fantasy and should be taken as such. Anybody complaining about "whitewashing" has misinterpreted what sort of movie this is. Admittedly, the first time that I tried watching this, I shut it off within the first ten minutes. I decided to take a chance on it this evening, and thoroughly enjoyed myself.

review_title: This is the Reason why Mytho's should stay Mytho's
review_detailed_main:
Gods of Egypt is a movie directed by Alex Proyas and written by Matt Sazama and Burk Sharpless. It stars Gerard Butler, Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau, Courtney Eaton, and Brenton Thwaites

Mortal hero Bek teams with the god Horus in an alliance against Set, the merciless god of darkness who has usurped Egypt's throne, plunging the once peaceful and prosperous empire into chaos and conflict.

Mythological stories were often told to teach a concept that was too elusive to be understood otherwise. For example, the story of Echo and Narcissus, was meant to define what narcissism entails and explain what reflections were. Like all mythological stories, Gods of Egypt, teaches all aspiring writers and directors, how not to make a fantasy movie.

There's little to nothing good about the monstrosity movie seems. With that said I did reap some enjoyment out of this senses- assaulting trip to Egypt. This is a film that I can definitely say will become a cult film one day as it is a true train wreck in every which way. But, like in all train wrecks, it horrible, tragic, yet irresistible viewing.

Perhaps the most entertaining part of this circus freak show, was the script. Everything but coherent, Gods of Egypt's two writers seemed to have truly thrown in the towel in this endeavor as each line progressively sounds like it was ripped out of a poorly made X- rated movie. This 'style,' if I may call it that, is complimented by the overly convoluted story that fails to engage the audience past its first few scenes. Rather I found myself focusing on how many times Gerard Butler tries to imitate Nicolas Cage. Moving past the laughable dialogue, Gerard Butler delivers a villainous turn as a man who wants to freeze Gotham city, Mr. Freeze. Wait a second.I think I got the wrong movie. Though Butler's over-the-top performance was far from good, he stands out as the rest of the cast seem to be completely blasé towards this 'epic' fantasy movie.

To add insult to a mortal injury, the direction in this movie feels overly stilted and scattershot. This is particularly annoying since I used to be a fan of some Alex Proyas' early works like Dark City and The Crow. In this movie he has fully demonstrated that he cares little about the craft of filmmaking as he opts to film eye- wateringly ghastly CGI beasts duke it out.

Gods of Egypt is an unwatchable mess that will one day be appreciated for its laughable content and execution. Gods of Egypt gets a D or a 1.8/10.

So they forgot the tanning splay like in the old days. People should give it a rest and just enjoy. I was sceptical in the beginning. But ten minutes on and I got involved with the story. Special effects are really good. Don't expect it to be historically accurate. It just entertaining.

Full of famous and half famous actors. The story makes it worth watching once. The CGI (almost every major scene. ) is like most CGI garbage and looks fake. Really this movie could have been a solid 7 or even 8 if they actually put the effort into making it a decent film. But Hollywood is obsessed with CGI, probably because it's cheap, but it ruins more movies than it helps. With that said I gave this film a 6 because the actors were good and the story was unique and entertaining. It's not gonna win any awards, though the costumes were really cool at times, but it's not going to ruin any careers either. Worth a weekday couple of hours to watch once.

review_title: A two-hour epic of bloated CGI and total cinematic nonsense
review_detailed_main:
Many movie buffs may know by now that the first three months of the year consist of some of Hollywood's biggest letdowns of the year, even big-budget epics starring a few A-list actors are immune to failure. When it comes to the action-epic genre, however, the last thing we need is a fantasy adventure that descends on the level of "so bad, it's good" or just laughably bad. This Epygtian mythology-based fantasy epic directed by Alex Proyas who directed by criminally forgotten 'Dark City' and the surprisingly entertaining 'I,Robot', may fit in this category but it doesn't escape the ridiculously messy, CGI-crowded train wreck this is. The most difficult task to endure while sitting through this flick is spotting a single redeeming quality during the two-hour mess. This film stars Gerard Butler as Set, the god of darkness in ancient Egypt who grows jealously over the sun god'a position as King and decides to take over the throne, leading the formerly peaceful empire to plunge into chaos. With the empire gripping in fear of his reign, young thief Bek (played by Brenton Thwaites) sets out to defeat Set and save his girlfriend Maya (played by Courtney Eaton) who is held captive, with the help of Horus (played by Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau), the powerful god of the desert fighting by his side.

It is difficult tell whether this is supposed a parody of big-budget epic flicks or just another fantasy flick tainted by unintentionally bad script. Either way, this movie fails miserably. Whethers it's the horrendous visual effects, the stunted acting, the painfully incoherent plot, or the overall lousy script; this movie seems to have no idea what it's trying to be. The film begins a shiny bird's eye view of the Egyptian empire that is nice to look until the camera pans down for a closer view of the environment. With the villages looking like sets we may find in a high school play and the bloated use of lightening, results in a painfully unconvincing production design representing Ancient Egypt. The rest of the time, we are left with settings consisted with cheap green screen effects and dull CGI. And it certainly doesn't help that the cast along the extras are populated with Caucasian actors, leaving an absence of any Egyptian actors. I mean a movie that takes place in Egypt and features no actual Egyptians? Come on now! And sadly, that's not the worst part. The worst past comes from the horrendous performances the cast displays. Brendon Thwaites plays the main character and throughout the entirety, never seems to bring his A-game here, either does Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau as the supporting character. The biggest actor on screen is easily Gerard Butler who plays the villain, and even his role falls short of appeal. Those expecting him bringing the powerful energy he brought as Leonidas in '300' are in for a major disappointment. The only thing we get out of the acting instead, is insanely laughable dialogue that incite more laughs than anything worth taking seriously, even during the scenes that supposed to dramatic.

When going into a epic fantasy adventure, one can easily expect to experience some flashy special effects, solid characters, and a decent, if not groundbreaking plot to keep the film moving. None of these is found here. The plot to begin with, is vastly incoherent and in the end, makes no sense. When the film is not feeding us tense action scenes, it tries it's best to develop the plot through the characters arguing constantly, when it's really just trying to fill in a two-hour runtime. Yes, Set, the main villain is trying to take over the Egyptian empire but before the first hour, we are given almost no reason to care. In brief summary, it's just boring.The action sequences along with the battle scenes are supposed to fun. In contrary, these scenes are painful to watch. It's bad enough there is lazy acting and ridiculous spiraling camera work associated with these scenes, but the special effects are plain awful to the point looking like effects seen in a B-movie. The visual effects aren't too solid either, especially with the bloated use of CGI. The computer-generated creatures may not look too inept, but they're pretty unimpressive, especially considering this generation's technology that's capable of making superior animation in video games than this. It's hard to believe how a $140 million dollar epic consists of such bad effects.

Gods of Egypt is an epic disaster leading up one of worst films of this year so far. This film fails at just about every aspect in terms of writing, narrative, and technicality; and the worst part, it more than likely has made itself a wide target for the Razzie awards. With this film, slacking as both an epic and unintentional parody, If you hadn't seen this movie, don't worry you're not missing anything.

review_title: Well, I gave it a go
It was better than expected, but still not great
review_detailed_main: I went to this with a friend because she loves Gerard Butler and I love Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau. So we thought it was be worth it just to see them without shirts on! Like I said, it was better than I expected with the story line, but there was SOOOOO much CGI. I get that it needed it because it's based on gods, but I KNOW there is better computer graphics out there. It was just so obvious. I did love the music though, I love the ancient Greek theme type instruments. I only paid 6 bucks for it though because of a special at our theater, but I think if you're paying full price, I would wait and watch something else. Might be good on DVD, but not really worth it in theaters. Unless you REALLY love Gerard Butler (he is a bad guy however)

review_title: You'll need Horus' Eye to spot out the good parts
Ray Harryhausen would have loved this one!
review_detailed_main: As soon as I started watching this movie I knew it was a little different from the movies that generally suck like Scorpion King 2 or Immortals. We had over the top monsters and good actors hamming it up. Annoying but fitting music! I felt like a kid again watching Clash of the Titans or Sinbad and the Eye of the Tiger. I see some commentors went in expecting The Color Purple, lol. If you like Harryhausen films or Flash Gordon movies you'll like this movie. It's a movie for fun people rating poorly must not understand a film like this. You could tell Geoffrey Rush was having fun as Ra! Gerard Butler portrayed an excellent Set. The young lead actor was probably the weakest link. All and all over the top with creative effects and a romp

review_title: Stunning Visuals, Boundless Potential, yet Wretched Pathetic Scripting
not for me, low on everything I thought it should show
review_detailed_main:
I saw the trailer of this flick just before the superman vs batman flick. It looked great and have seen Immortals (2011) which I really liked I was looking forward for another flick about the Gods of Egypt. Sadly it wasn't my thing at all. Not that I was bored or whatsoever but it was clearly made for everybody. No gore or nudity to see.

I mean, in the beginning there's a murder going on with stabbing, you can see the knife going in the flesh but no blood, when he wipes his knife clean there's no spot of blood to wipe. And we do have a love scene and the so-called queen is indeed undressed but it's all filmed without showing a thing.

Further the CGI used is really good but not that superb because sometimes you could easily spot the key used to fill in the picture. Also the Gods are shown on a strange way, some faces are correct with history but Ra sitting on a ship and stuff like that, just look at Egypt itself. Where is the dessert?

For me it was more a story like the old Sinbad flicks or even the Clash Of The Titans flick(s). An immortal helping 1 God to fight against his brother God and yes, there are monsters around to defeat.

So if you think it's truth to history it isn't, it's a pure fantasy flick.

Gore 0/5 Nudity 0/5 Effects 4/5 Story 2,5/5 Comedy 0/5

review_detailed_main: Gods of Egypt is perhaps the worst 2016 film in full year good films , Gods of Egypt is very bad, unfortunately the CGI is dominating Hollywood , and this film is virtually 100 % CGI , and even CGI weak, the script of the film is full of errors , weak dialogue , the film tries to catchphrases , more misses in all , the direction the Proyas , which is not a bad director, more in this film he is bad , the film has some good things , the story it is good , the more the writer can not write it, the Egyptian mythology is fascinating, and with a good script and a great direction, would make a great film, which is not the case of this film , the soundtrack is good, cast is also good, plus the acting is reasonable to poor , the only one that is reasonable is Nicolaj ( and look there ) , Gods of Egypt is a bad movie with a bad direction, a poorly written script, a soundtrack to good , a story that could be adapted better.
