review_title: Egyption Mythlogical tale with humor, emotion & solid effects
review_detailed_main:
When we go to the movies, we are expecting to be entertained, based on the expectations we go into it with based on movie type, actors , TV spots and our overall love of certain genres.

Ancient Egypt is a fascination for a lot of people , not only its spectacular architecture, but because of the tales of the same sorts of things we go through in this modern era, spun from the point of view of Gods intermingling with humans.

Betrayal sets the scene for the story of fathers and sons, friends and lovers and the often hardships they go through amidst in this case, a towering city of Gold where Gods govern among their human counterparts.

A solid musical score sets the tone for very decent effects, supporting a tale of love surrounding jealousy, immortal battles , teamwork & a clash of good vs hatred.

A world not unlike what we sometimes find ourselves in, will whisk you into a fantasy world , drop you into a bittersweet tale , and leave you with a few questions.

Egypt whether ancient or current era is a fascinating topic, and this move portrays a tale from a ancient past in a positive light with a fantastical twist that most users will enjoy.

There are a few scenes that parents ( some adults) will want to be cautious about , so ratings apply as always, but overall they found a decent balance between the depiction of graphic violence ( not gratuitous )and telling a story of love , jealousy and ultimate triumph, all through the lens of a place in time we've all come, rightfully so, fascinated by.

Worth watching.

review_title: Alt Title: How To Burn $140 Million.
review_detailed_main:
First, the good. There are a few scenes that are fun to look at.

Other than that, this is one of the singularly most horrible films I have ever watched. The script sounds as if it was written for a high school drama class (by one of the students), and some of the actors (Thoth) appear equally qualified.

You can tell the producers are big believers in effects, as you could probably count on one hand the number of scenes that weren't green screen or cgi. As is usually the case with this type of production, the effects became the story rather than serving to help tell a story.

George Clooney keeps a poster of his Batman movie up in his house as a cautionary tale to what can happen when you pick bad scripts. I can only imagine the leads in this film, all accomplished and capable actors, have a "Gods of Egypt" poster similarly hanging in their home offices.

If you never watch this movie, you've missed nothing.

review_title: Completely mangled story that makes no sense
Thrilling and Exciting Movie that Still Got it ALL WRONG
review_detailed_main: Oh God, yet ANOTHER movie about a WHITEWASHED version of Egypt. Based on ancient Egyptian mythology, Gods of Egypt features the epic journey of a mortal named Bek to save his true love from death and rescue Egypt. Along the way, he is assisted by the god of the air, Horus, who is fighting against Set, the god of darkness who has proclaimed himself the rightful ruler of Egypt. This film has everything an eager movie goer could want: an out-of-this world plot, special effects, an epic setting (who doesn't like Ancient Egypt??), romance, thrill, humor, and sweeping music. YET...it is about as accurate as watching an ALL BLACK version of 300 (Spartan movie) or Gladiator. Hollywood would be in an uproar. I'm sorry but as much as I liked the movie, I couldn't feel at ease sitting and watching a BOLD-FACED LIE. The whole time I felt like I was in some sort of DELUDED Caucasian/Asian FANTASY of an Egypt without African roots. There were just too many subtly insulting scenes in the movie to mention, but the overall feeling I got from the film was a sense of European ego-centrism. The only significant black character is Thoth, the god of wisdom; couldn't even make one goddess a Black woman even though they were often the rulers of ancient Egypt. No, the actress playing Hathor, the goddess of love, only serves to propagate racist, mainstream standards of beauty (non-black beauty), even if she's NOT blond haired and blue eyed. The idiot producers in Hollywood haven't figured it out yet (or they have and just don't want to ADMIT it)! The ORIGINAL ancient Egyptians were NUBIANS, Africans and people of color. It wasn't until the Hittites and other Caucasian peoples completely invaded Egypt that it became the diluted Egypt of today (Read The Destruction of Black Civilization by Chancellor Williams). That's why there are these delusions with some Arabs/Asians having the audacity and arrogance to somehow assume they ONLY are the true Egyptians (or denying Africans are). Look at movies like The Mummy, etc. Some may dismiss this as an Afrocentric rant and say that color doesn't matter and all that BS. But as a person of African descent, it's a little annoying to constantly have OUR history INACCURATELY portrayed by people who don't really wish to acknowledge us in the first place. STOP hijacking our history and projecting yourself into EVERY area of history you think you can do so!!! Hey Hollywood and SUMMIT ENTERTAINMENT, get a clue from DREAMWORKS and have some historical accuracy. Look The Prince of Egypt, Joseph King of Dreams, and even La Reine Soleil (produced by Cinemon Studios). They got it right, and those are ANIMATED movies. Oh but why wouldn't they want to use an all- black cast? Because most whites would never want to see it, as they LACK empathy for brown/black people, as proved in scientific studies. I wouldn't be surprised if half the people watching this movie wouldn't entertain the idea of a Black Egypt. No, not just one anomaly black pharaoh but a lineage of African rulers who spanned many dynasties. All- in-all, maybe the movie would be 10 stars if they got the BASICS right.

review_title: An unholy mess in nearly every way
review_detailed_main:
This feels like a film from an much earlier era, with an infantile script and dialog, some slapstick cringe, and uniformly stilted and wooden performances from the entire cast, some of whom, like Geoffrey Rush, are much better than the material.

This must have been deliberate direction, I can only assume in an attempt to introduce a mythic feel, but it's just grinding and irritating. Our spunky young mortal hero is particularly tiresome, and you'll quickly be rooting against him.

Most of the cast is strictly White European, but that's fair enough if we can have Africans in Asgard.

What's to like here? Well, it rattles along at a decent pace, and isn't over-burdened with long dialog scenes, a particular kindness given the awful script and performances. The scaling of the gods and mortals is kept generally (but not always) consistent. Sets are pretty good, although under-dressed.

Against that, much of the CGI and green-screening is awful, comically bad for a film of its era. The score is jarring and becomes increasingly overblown, and the plot is a series of (poor) CGI actions scenes stitched together with the minimum of narrative. In one astonishing gaffe a character jumps onto what seems to be an undisguised modern airbag

The very best thing that I can say about it is that there's plenty of toned and well formed flesh on display, but you can find that on adult video sites, and the scripts and acting are of about the same standard.

I really didn't enjoy this movie all that much. I thought that there were some parts that worked out, but there were way more that didn't, and unfortunately those weak points completely detract from the overall quality of the film.

First of all, the CGI in this movie is shockingly bad. I don't know why the film makers didn't try to polish the effects up a tad, I mean they had 140 million to work with, but for some reason, they chose to keep them as they are presented here. For a movie that quite significantly focuses on the CGI aspect of movie making, this is embarrassing.

The writing that went into the production is just as poor. It fell short on so many levels that I both laughed and cringed on multiple occasions. The acting from most of the cast (which is mostly British, weirdly enough) is sub par, and doesn't do much to add some humanity to the very lazy script.

The only things I can say I enjoyed about this movie are Nikolaj Coaster-Waldaus performance - which is the only performance that did so much as intrigue me slightly - as well as the depiction of the Ancient Egyptian setting.

This movie is mostly a complete miss, and I would not recommend it to anybody. Seriously, you'll wander why you wasted two hours of your life watching this.

Too ridiculous with the characters being white in Egypt. I love fantasy movies so I'm going to let it ride. It would have been nice to see actual brown people in these roles. The title is wrong should have been Gods of Greece maybe? I loved mythology growing up. It's the type of movie you can watch but walk out the room on or fall asleep and never finish.
What is exactly the point of this garbage? If they wanted to make movie out of something, they can just make up the stories. As an egyptian mythology enthusiast, I found this movie is just insulting.

review_title: A visual spectacle and fun to watch
review_detailed_main: Don't get swayed by what critics and biased reviewers are saying. If you have no hang ups and not concerned about societal issues, go watch this film. It is a visual spectacle that would grab your interest. It has some original stories, good acting, great stunts and fight scenes but most of all great visuals and costumes. This movie is good for the ordinary person who would like to relax and escape into a fantasy world. Do you like a movie with a grand depiction of ancient Egypt? Go watch this movie. Do you like to see good looking actors in an opulent Egyptian setting? Go watch this movie. Do you like mythical stories of gods, monsters and sorcery? Go watch this movie. Do you want to spite the critics who wants to shove gloomy movies of societal issues down our throats and don't like us getting entertained? Go watch this movie.

review_title: Ancient Egypt? No, not even close.

review_detailed_main: The effects aren't terrible, but there are just so much of them that it makes you wonder if the production had to balance on the side of quantity at the expense of quality. The thing that really let's this movie down is the dialogue. You can tell that the actors really struggle putting any emphasis or weight behind their lines. It's as though they believe in them less and less as the movie drags on. It starts as fairly promising but by the end its a CGI and script induced headache of a movie.

This movie was AWESOME! I loved how the movie portrayed the gods and their rivalries. The actors played the roles SO well, and obviously the script was different from the actual events, but it was still really good.

I think that the CGI could've been better, and sometimes I could tell that the actors were actually acting, not "being" the characters, but still, the movie is definitely worth watching, no matter what anyone else says. Trust me.

The script was sort of like "Calm, Calm, ACTION, Suspense, Calm, Drama, Suspense, Calm, BIG ACTION, Suspense, EXTREME ACTION!" And I loved it! I am very glad that I watched this movie!
A bloated CGI mess. A myriad of accents...overacting and hubris....Budget was better spent on a real script .....avoid.

review_title: cheesy story, well, a little at that, but really good CGI ...
review_detailed_main:
Yes, one might say this kind of myth is kinda cheesy, but well, most myth are so after all, aren't they? :-)

so, to me at least, what makes a DIFFERENCE (and a HUGE one at that!) is how the makers of such movies get a little more 'creative' than their competition and turn an otherwise 'childish and simple' tale into something truly entertaining and worth watching, 'wasting' at least 90 minutes of your precious time/life on that ... and this movie is more than 2 hours long but i enjoyed most of it, at least 99% of it that is! (i was already very tired and sleepy when i started this on Roku free movies + ads at around 01:30a last night and was about to fall asleep involuntarily a couple of times near the end but did manage to keep awake trying not to miss a moment ...)

i'll probably watch it again if i do get the time later ... preferably on a larger screen (mine's a 40" old TOSHIBA flat screen placed about 12' from where i was sitting) and i may as well even buy a copy for keeps as it is truly worth it ...

again, forgive the not so realistic mythical storyline plus its somewhat mundane wrappings (as we ought to do in most similar cases anyway!) and just enjoy the VFX and SFX and lovely music in addition to some beautiful characters ... and you'll most probably like it just like i did! :-)

review_title: One of the poorest movies ever
review_detailed_main:
1- The story is inconsistent, it extremely deviated from the original story. In the original story Horus was born after his father King Osiris was killed by his brother. Horus had been raised away from his uncle. When Horus grew up he struggled for his throne, he killed his uncle, lost one eye , and won the throne. This Americana version of the story is very poor. 2- Cinematography was truly funny, gods height was ridiculous. this variance of height between gods and humans affected much on the scenes joining both specially drama scenes. 3- There are many ridiculous visualizations of ancient Egypt, and the worst visualization prize goes to Set's high tower. It's taller than empire state 4- Editing and sound are rather good

Finally , I do not recommend to watch this movie

review_title: A film about African Gods, but where few of the Gods looked African

review_detailed_main: Wow this was awful. The CGI is even worse than Birdemic and the acting. The writing was bad, the acting was bad, and half of the characters are pointless. What is Chadwick Boseman even doing in this movie. His character is not needed. He does absolutely nothing in this movie. Nothing even looks real. It's not even funny bad, it's hard to watch. Gerard Butler is bad but not as bad as everyone else. This is worse than Clash of the Titans. At least that had alright effects. This is one of the worst movies ever. Nothing happens in the movie. The effects are so bad it's hard to watch anything. Brenton Thwaites is terrible and just can't act in this. This is the writer's fault. They didn't make half of their budget back. That was bad.

Despite the snobbish critics reviews I thoroughly enjoyed my relaxing afternoon in the theater watching Gods of Egypt. I remember when the critics were all panning Raiders of the Lost Arc, and look how many viewers enjoyed the escapism of that movie. The story moved along at a good pace and the 2 hrs passed quickly. Yes, it is a typical movie of its genre, but what is so wrong with that. Not all movies made are Oscar worthy, but they are still filling the category of "Made for enjoyment". I watched the movie in IMAX 3D. If your looking for an afternoon to escape our current political climate go enjoy Gods of Egypt.

Not bad. Just not great. Whoever made this mess of a movie, please keep trying. God's Dad's dad is a "Tighten" or a "Titan." God's Dad self-confessed is about "Good." "Good" attracts all sorts of a-holes. As a result, God's Dad's Dad needs to "tighten:" Tighten resources, access (reduce inclusion), praise. That's what THOSE Gods in this movie should be. Tight. About everything. Loads of grumpy grandads. Tie this into the other mythology. Our whole solar system originally was one gigantic Titan potatoe before it got smashed into pieces. One giant tight potatoe. Maybe it helps. Secretly, I enjoy all mythology flics. I'm just tight about it.

Ya know, it's bad enough history whitewashes everything to death do we really need another movie to lie to us while being absolutely trash? Whoever liked this movie is easy and should have a remote with one button straight to nickelodeon. Great actors who decided to read and memorize this script.. i guess they needed the money really bad.My other issue with this movie is the same as with most movies like this, the accents.The CG for me wasn't as bad as some said for me it's the story and the way it's being told from beginning to end, and i get that it's an action adventure but get the history right at least. It plays more like Aladdin the animated version i mean writers try harder next time the public is a lot smarter than the stuff you guys are putting out. I'm done venting please Hollywood stop making garbage like this.

Horus (Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau) is set to rule Egypt from his father Osiris. Set (Gerard Butler) steals the throne killing his brother Osiris. Set defeats Horus, takes his eyes, and his bride Hathor. Set kills anyone who opposes him and enslaves humanity. Bek (Brenton Thwaites) is a mortal thief. He steals one of Horus' eyes but his love Zaya is killed. He makes a deal with Horus to return Zaya to the living after they defeat Set. With Hathor, Goddess of Love, and Thoth (Chadwick Boseman), God of Knowledge, they set off to answer the riddle of the sphinx.

This is overloaded with CGI flash and grandeur. It's fun visually for awhile but by the end, it becomes more of the same. The climax becomes sound and fury that signifies nothing more than waiting for the end. The story is simple good versus evil. Gerard plays evil for all it's worth. Horus is selfish at the beginning. Quite frankly, Bek is also selfish. Bek and Zaya are not more than puppy love. There is no development. They are simply in love. The good guys aren't that compelling. The whitewashing controversy doesn't help either. This is not the worst but it's not worthwhile to defend either.

review_title: Gerard Butler steals show in old-school action adventure tale
Computer graphics are outstanding, story not

review_detailed_main:
Big CGI, easily identifiable characters, name-drop a few Egyptian gods, more big CGI, and there you got it. Nothing about this movie is particularly good, but nothing is particularly bad either.

The plot is easy enough for a 7-8 year old to understand, and the casting appears to be done to please the eyes of teen. The movie is honest in the way that it doesn't try to be anything more than a children's movie - which it is - and should therefore be watched as one.

With that in mind it does a fairly good job of entertaining. If you want a fast paced CGI fest set in an imaginary Egypt, about love and morals, this movie might just be right for you.

review_title: Better expected, shinier, more colourful Clash of Titans

review_detailed_main: It's rare to find any art so irredeemably awful in every possible level that you come out feeling deep sympathy for the people who made it. If you genuinely enjoyed this biblical flood of trite cheese and laughable dialogue, good luck with the rest of your treatment.
Good movie. Entertaining and at Times funny. Made me read some about the gods of Ancient Egypt and I sant mote!

review_title: Very informative movie! GIANT SPOILER ABOUT AFTERLIFE!
Read the Reviews not the Rating
review_detailed_main: At the time of writing the rating is 5.4. which I think is far to low. I agree with the positive reviews. Yes it has all the cliches and inconsistencies you would expect from such a CGI festival of ancient myths, but above all it is an enjoyable movie. I don't generally watch the marvel/star wars type movies so I was tempted to give this a wide berth however I have an interest in Egyptian mythology fully expecting to turn it off after ten minutes or so. The special effects are spectacular and the humour is unexpected. I can understand the critics rating of a measly 25 I wouldn't have expected anything else from them, but this film is also better than the current 5.4

Take out the cgi and there would be a hollow shell. With it there's the same poor script, poor acting, bad casting and a whole load of visual nonsense. This is an object lesson in how to waste $140,000,000. It's amazing that it took two writers to come up with this rubbish.

review_title: How to spend a lot of money to make something look so cheap.
review_detailed_main:
Why did i even watch this? If you think a cruise ship style dance show is fun, this might be up your sleeve. It's a shallow and ridiciously overstylized Ancient Egypt fan fiction. Story-wise barely above a B-movie-level and that reflects in the acting. Gerald Butler with his heavy accents is never believeable as any kind of ancient egyptian. He doesn't even care, he is just having fun.

Visually this probably most reflects a Las Vegas slot game. Gold, gold and more gold, it's gratuitous. The CG is competent in some moments but aweful most of the time. It's simply overused, the whole movie turns into a reality ignoring motion ride far too often.

It's so bad that it almost makes the jump to "so bad it's good"-territory. Almost.

review_title: Ancient Gods of Ancient Egypt fight for the survival of the world.

review_detailed_main: No expectations sitting down to watch this; I watched because of some of the actors in it. Watched the entire film; not bad but certainly not a hit either.
I have a problem with this movie already bcuz of the casting ... I'm good on this

review_title: Not sure why the bad reviews!?
review_detailed_main: I really enjoyed the film. I love Egyptian mythology and mythology in in general. Really interesting movie about the story of the Egyptian gods and how they lived amongst mortals. The movie keeps you engaged throughout, the CGI was good and the morals and lessons in the story were more than satisfactory. I highly recommend this film if you lie action, mythology, fantasy and hints of romance too. Great film with a happy ending.

Well, being desperate of inspiration, the last decades the movie industry turned to ancient Greek, Roman and Egyptian mythology several times to make movies. Nice special effects, a debatable sense of humor, and overall products that do not match their promise. Is is the screenplay, is it the actors? I am not sure, but every time with these movies, I tend to laugh at the wrong moments (strange dialogue, weird plots) and am generally underwhelmed. So many flat characters... Despite a budget of 140 million dollars, as entertainment it does not even come close to for instance The Mummy movies.

review_title: Slow start but worth a watch...

review_detailed_main: How can this be about Egypt when every body has British accents? It us absolutely absurd. The who cast including Egyptian kinds talk like Londoners. Omg.

It was supposed to introduce gods of Egypt, but it just tells a story about Horus. Also, It does not have acceptable visual effect especially, in battles and transformation. All in all, it could be better than it as a movie about the greatest gods in Egypt.

They may as well have made a sequel where Moses fights his way out of Egypt with a light saber and Scooby Doo captaining a star ship shaped like the sphinx.

For three centuries past scientists, historians and Egyptologists have devoted their lives and intellects to uncovering the splendor the myths and legends of Ancient Egypt. All to come to THIS atrocity. Ignore the history of the ancient society, ignore the mythology, ignore the morality tales and turn the whole thing in to an ugly, slap bang, poor cgi fest, failure of an action movie that is so inaccurate and cringe worth it is literally painful to watch or hear.

This simply makes me sad

review_title: It's hard to get more hapless and stupid than this
review_detailed_main:
Obviously some American decided that he would take it into his head to rewrite stories over 2 millenia old, from that unique perspective.

But it was too complex... so he ditched the narrative, ditched the story (though he kept the names - catchy!) and wrote a new one, probably on the back of a Hard Rock Nevada napkin during a weeklong bender in Las Vegas.

Then he hired a drinking buddy to do casting, and he banged it out over the week (who cares if there's no Egyptian - or almost anyone with middle-Eastern blood anywhere in the cast? Americans won't notice and we can always get a couple of pretty mixed-heritage girls for cheap - yay gender inequity!) before getting Gerard really drunk, forging his signature on a contract and leaving it beside his passed-out head so he thought he agreed to it. And hey, lets keep them doing LA accents because those foreign accents are just too hard to understand!

(Author's note: yes, this tongue-in-cheek sarcasm isn't the real story... I think. This movie is just such garbage I couldn't give it a real review)

review_title: No matter how much you spend on CGI you need a good story
review_detailed_main:
Gods of Egypt reminds me of the ridiculous popcorn mythological adventures of the 90s like The Mummy Series, Scorpion King. CGI fight scenes aplenty, adventures to exotic places, hero in distress, woman who dress in as little as possible to excite the 12 year old boys in the crowd.

And if you were a twelve year old you would be entertained and look past the strange ways the somehow superhuman Gods seems to be so dim witted and trusting all the time (so as to get themselves killed by being stabbed in the back), the cheesy dialogue, how the characters travel from one place to the next in a couple of scenes.

Ultimately leave your brain at home and kick back and enjoy the CGI popcorn crapfest that is Gods of Egypt.

I am a fan of actor Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau, that is why I felt empathy for him being associated with such a bad film. The amount of CG used in the movie was staggering, even taking into consideration that the world was mostly make believe. No effort was taken to use any tangible locations. I do have to give a little credit to all the actors, considering they most likely spent day after day filming in front of a green screen. The amount of CG was one thing and the poor CG quality was another. Coaster-Waldau, although solid, could not carry the entire film. The rest of the actors were indistinguishable and generally poor. The plot was uncomplicated, predictable, and bland. The premise of the movie was sound, it just wasn't executed competently.

"Gods of Egypt" offered a visually spectacular journey into Egyptian mythology, earning a 6/10 in my view. Its strength lay in the breathtaking and imaginative visuals, bringing ancient Egypt to life in grandeur. The cinematography showcased impressive world-building and epic set pieces. However, the film's weakness became evident in its often cheesy dialogue and occasionally over-the-top acting, which detracted from the immersion. The music added some gravitas to the epic moments, but it wasn't particularly memorable. Overall, while the film provided a visually captivating experience, it struggled to strike a balance between its awe-inspiring spectacle and narrative depth, resulting in an entertaining yet imperfect cinematic adventure through the world of gods and mortals.

The trailer for this movie is rather amezing and interesting. And that is where you should stop watching, the trailer. The movie is slow, confusing and don't seem to have a real struktur.

There is some amezing CGI... But only in the scenes used in the trailers

review_title: Definitely a watch for real fans of action fantasy
review_detailed_main: So there were apparently a ton of critics looking for a home-run in terms of plot and character development. That's a lot to expect from a 2 hour action movie seeking to tell an entire story. Though I sound like I'm saying it's bad in these aspects, I thought they did a great job of explaining the characters and creating a clearly understandable story. It's not as there is a narrator walking you through the events. If you pay attention to the actual depiction of the story rather than something ridiculous such as an actor's accent in a story where gods roam the Earth, all the events will be clear to you. Somehow, critics have the magical power to ignore what an author portrays by trying to nit-pick all the clichés and tiny inconsistencies. If you become immersed within this movie and accept what might be normally odd in the modern world, the story will transcend being simply a cgi thriller. The cgi is in fact extraordinarily well-done, but the purpose is to make this impossible world come to life. The characters portrayed their roles excellently. There were only 2 parts which were rather silly, but after each of these events was a scene that was rather reconciling. The fight scenes also don't look like mindless exchanges of punches, stabs, and pointless movement, but was rather well choreographed and you could trace each action. Both the beginning and ending were great, and I left feeling thoroughly satisfied. Even my mother who normally despises action movies felt that it was terrific.

review_title: Gods of Egypt - When Marvel Invades the Land of the Pyramids
review_detailed_main:
Hollywood's take on ancient Egypt is like slapping a spoiler on a donkey cart: it makes no sense, but you can't help but chuckle. Gods of Egypt kicks off with Osiris about to hand the throne to his son Horus-until Uncle Seth crashes the party like a drunk relative at Christmas, killing everyone in sight. The result? Chaos engulfs the kingdom, and Horus gets his butt handed to him. Nothing groundbreaking here, except for the CGI-packed battles that feel like a glitchy DLC for Assassin's Creed Origins.

To save the day, Horus teams up with Bek, a mortal thief. Why? Apparently, even gods need an intern for their rescue missions. Bek is like a less charismatic Aladdin with a questionable accent. But hey, he's good at climbing walls and loves his girlfriend, so we let it slide. Their partnership delivers action scenes that sit somewhere between Prince of Persia and Fast & Furious in slow motion.

The gods? Think Avengers on steroids. Shiny armor, ridiculous animal transformations, and battles that could make Thor blush after a night of heavy drinking. Alex Proyas goes all-in on special effects but seems to have misplaced the script in the process. Special shoutout to Gerard Butler's Seth, a villain with a Scottish accent who looks like he wandered onto the wrong set. Even Butler seems confused about why he's there.

As for Egyptian mythology? Don't expect accuracy. This is full-on freestyle mode. Pyramids crumble, gods bleed gold (or is it acacia honey?), and mortals seem to have better survival odds than public transport during a strike. But hey, it's flashy, fun, and you'll walk away with some random party trivia-like "Seth was kind of a jerk."

This isn't Gladiator, but Gods of Egypt gets the job done. Sure, the pacing stumbles, and the plot is as predictable as an episode of Days of Our Lives, but you can't help but enjoy the cosmic chaos.

Gods of Egypt is like a kebab at 3 a.m.: greasy, overstuffed, and a bit of a mess, but undeniably entertaining. Proyas delivers a fantastical epic that fully embraces its kitsch, with blinged-out gods and gloriously absurd battles. Watch it once-with a beer in hand and your expectations firmly in check.

This is a movie which I actually was worried by the trailer. It looked rubbish. Finally watched this and oh my it fails badly and its 2 hours 7 minutes of my life I will never get back. I can see why it bombed. This looks cheap and tacky and I ended up half reading and watching this movie This is a real "Alan Smithee" movie if ever I saw one. I know that I have to write more and to be honest I'm struggling. The special effects are dire the acting is worse. Having all white cast where blatantly they wouldn't/couldn't be. It actually reminds me of an episode of stargate SG1 where they ran out of budget and ideas. And apparently this is meant to have a sequel. Worrying.

review_title: Pray to the Gods of Egypt that no one drags you to this movie.
review_detailed_main:
He was said to be born of a virgin and his birth came to be celebrated on or about December 25th. As a baby, he was depicted in a stable scene, lying in a manger, with the image of his mother beside him. He was considered the light of the world, an avenger against the power of darkness and, as such, the savior of mankind. According to many historical sources, including the writings of former Catholic priest Joseph McCabe, this was the mythology surrounding the ancient Egyptian god Horus in the centuries before the birth of Jesus. Horus is the central character in the CGI-heavy fantasy film "Gods of Egypt" (PG-13, 2:07).

The film, however, focuses more on Horus' deeds as a god than how he was worshipped. The plot is very loosely based on ancient Egyptian mythology, particularly the story "The Contendings of Horus and Set", and takes place at a time in Egyptian pre-history when it was believed that gods lived among humans. These gods aren't omniscient, omnipotent, or immortal, but they can live over 1,000 years, they bleed gold, they can be resurrected if killed, they have special powers (like turning into the birds and animals that symbolize them in ancient mythology) and they're about three feet taller than most adult humans. Naturally, the humans serve these earth-inhabiting gods. In return, they protect Egypt and its people.

As the movie opens, the god Osiris (Bryan Brown) is about to crown his son, Horus (Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau) God-King of Egypt. The other gods have turned out for the ceremony, along with all the puny mortals, including an arrogant and self-righteous young man called Bek (Brenton Thwaites) and his girlfriend, Zaya (Courtney Eaton), who is sporting the dress that Bek stole for her to wear at the coronation. But, alas, this coronation was not to be. Seconds before Horus was to receive the crown, Osiris' brother Set (Gerard Butler) shows up to totally spoil the party. Tired of ruling the isolated desert regions of Egypt and unhappy with being passed over for the throne of all Egypt, he stabs Osiris, gouges out the "all seeing" eyes of Horus and claims the throne for himself. He then presents the crowd this choice: worship him or be enslaved. What a jerk! The noble and selfless warrior from "300", Set is not.

Life in Egypt really goes downhill for both humans and gods with Set in charge. He kills other gods who get in his way and he forces the people to work on his massive construction projects. Zaya ends up working for the mean and nasty Urshu (Rufus Sewell), Set's chief architect. Zaya, who still believes in the power and basic goodness of the other gods, convinces Bek to go find Horus and convince him to come out of hiding and help Egypt. But it's not that simple. First, there's that whole blindness thing. Bek breaks into Set's vault, survives enough booby traps to impress Indiana Jones and is able to make off with one of Horus' eyes. Secondly, Bek has to convince an exiled and bitter god to help the insignificant little humans. Bek accomplishes that as well, but with only one of his eyes, Horus' powers are limited.

Horus and Bek are going to need a lot of help. Horus prays to his grandfather, the sun god Ra (Geoffrey Rush), who transports Horus and Bek up to his space-based solar barge from which he battles the powers of darkness. Ra chooses to stay neutral in the power struggle between his son and nephew and does very little to aid Horus. Back on earth, with only Bek at his side, Horus has to try enlisting the help of Horus' former lover and now Set's wife, Hathor (Elodie Yung), Thoth (Chadwick Boseman), who is the God of Wisdom, not to mention Anubis, the lord of the underworld. Even with the help that he's able to gather, defeating Set looks to be nearly impossible. Now, I won't tell you how the movie ends, except to say that the last scene sets up a possible sequel – but not likely, considering how poorly this movie did.

"Gods of Egypt" isn't the grand fantasy epic that it clearly wants to be. The quality of the CGI is mostly pretty impressive, but some of the visuals (like Ra's aircraft carrier-looking space barge) border on the laughable. More importantly, overblown special effects are a poor substitute for a good story. The film's plot points are alternately confusing, non-sensical and silly, as is much of the script's dialog. Take the character of Bek for example. While the gods helping the people and people standing up to the gods is indeed part of ancient mythology, the attempt to put modern phrases into Bek's mouth feels out of place and his attitude probably should have gotten him squashed like a bug by any self-respecting deity.

It doesn't help that the actor playing Bek lacked the charisma to sell this silliness. He's not alone. Most of the acting was of poor quality and the glaring omission of actual Egyptians in the cast made things even worse. This movie is all style and little substance. Pre-teen boys may like it, but if you're outside that relatively narrow demographic, you should probably pray to the gods that you don't have to spend two hours with this highly-fictionalized cinematic interpretation of ancient Egypt's rich mythology. "C-"

review_title: Entertaining and a visual feast, but the storyline is not that good
review_detailed_main:
I personally watched this movie's trailer first and pretty impressed by it so i decided to go and watch it in theater.

Generally speaking, i didn't get bored. The visual effects, visual of mythological legends and familiar faces in leading roles makes this movie at least fun to watch.

But i really think that it could be better, at least story-wise. The movie has such a great idea in itself and in my opinion they didn't use it so well. If they would, there could even be a series of great films. Storyline was so simple and we've seen so many films like this before.

You wouldn't regret watching it, but don't get so hyped. 5/10

review_title: Not the best acting or story here, but the action scenes are worth a look.
review_detailed_main: The person who had the most fun making this movie was probably Gerard Butler. He loves playing the villain. Unfortunately, no one else seemed to have a good time making the movie. The movie is only really worth it to see the first 10 minutes and the last 10 minutes. Otherwise you are better off skipping the rest. Those 20 minutes of the movie though have some pretty imaginative battles with the Gods being shape-shifters. The VFX are composited well sometimes and other time they simply drop the ball. There are some very awkward shots with the giant gods and tiny humans side by side, it just looks terrible compared to something like Lord of the Rings which was made long before this film.

I can't think of anything worse to say about an action fantasy thriller than that it put me to sleep. The action was boring and predictable, the fantasy was hideously taped together from bits of real Egyptian mythology, and the, um, thrills were what put me to sleep.

The acting was okay, but it's actually pretty easy to spout line after line of horrific dialogue in a convincing way. Special effects? Not overly pathetic, but CGI is not my cup of tea even in good movies.

The romance, drama and (attempts at) comedy were also all incredibly predictable. At least I don't feel badly about falling asleep, because I know I didn't miss much.

Jeez, even Pacific Rim was FAR better than this. And Pacific Rim was spectacularly awful.

Sadly, I knew people would dislike the movie, ever since the first trailer popped in, and it got all the negative comments.

First of all, about this "white washing": ancient Egyptians were not black. Not white either, but not black. And does it really a problem? Did the performance of Laurence Olivier as Othello (a character who IS black) bothers anyone? No. The director of Gods of Egypt is Alex Proyas, who was born in Egypt. I guess he was well aware of his country's history when he made the casting choices. And he has the right to choose anyone he wants. He is the director. Not the director of a documentary or a drama that's based on a true story. He is the director of a fantasy movie. Yes, the mythology has been around for thousands of years, but it's still a fantasy movie where Horus and other gods exist. None of this happened, so no one should look for historic accuracy. Let's move on.

I felt this movie is like Clash of Titans or Prince of Persia. It's not flawless. It's absolutely forgettable. It's 15 minutes longer than it should be. The CGI (when Horus and Seth transformed) is cartoonish. BUT: It's entertaining! The production design and the cinematography is great! I've always loved the Egyptian myth, and I was glad to see this movie's world was creative and visually great to look at. The music is solid. I liked the actors and their characters. For me, Chadwick Boseman had the best part in the movie. Minor role, but I loved every second of it. And I liked that neither of the main heroes is a comic relief.

Yes, the script was not the best, but I've seen some blockbusters in the past one year (like Mad Max: Fury Road, Furious 7, etc.) that were loved by critics and viewers but had no superior script.

Once again, GODS OF Egypt is not for everyone, but it is for some. I didn't regret I watched it.

It should have been so bad it's good and it is in places but the majority is too poorly filmed (especially the action) with the cg going from decent to terrible frequently. A disappointing film that should have embraced how bad it is more opposed to taking itself so seriously.

review_title: Not pleasing to the audience gods
review_detailed_main: While I appreciate that this movie isn't a sequel or part of a franchise, Gods of Egypt is a bit of a mess. I don't even think the filmmakers knew what this movie is supposed to be. It's an odd mix of clichés, CGI and cheesy dialogue with a small dash of Egyptian mythology. It's also interesting how a movie full of fantasy action still manages to be boring. This offering is not pleasing to the audience gods.

Australia, USA, China & Hong Kong eh ! Those were the days !! I can't imagine how this film cost $140 million, considering it was mostly a CGI production ... and as always , the evil / bad guy is British ! It gets even more childish when the combatants start flying around (sic) destroying the virtual studio ...

review_title: a waste of talent and time and extravagant dollars
review_detailed_main:
Gods of Egypt is meant to sell itself primarily on the visual effects spectacle - not unlike, going back some generations, to those dopey but entertaining special effects extravaganzas with work by Ray Harryhausen and featuring a stock of memorable creations amid a sea of lame-to-competent acting and direction. But now it's 2016 and with this movie, not even the CGI on 1990's XENA TV series (if you've ever seen that and know what I mean) was this cartoonishly awful. If it had been a SyFy channel movie I might accept it. As a 100+ million dollar extravaganza, it's almost a nightmare - too long (at 127 minutes it feels like 187), and it's got story turns and characters that... wait, what characters? This is the kind of movie that gives a major talent like Geoffrey Rush little to do but spout platitudes and be set on fire shooting at things.

Some of this is so stupid I found myself laughing - a lot - but not in the places I'd think Proyas half expected people to do so. And no one, not even poor Gerard Butler, can get enough energy to possibly ham or camp it up, but the serious delivery doesn't allow for many rewards for the viewer looking for good OR bad movie fun. Most motivations are weak and things involving how this world works can sometimes turn on a dime and not make sense anymore (it'd take too long to go into some of the things that are not nitpicks but glaring, holy-s***-how-did-anyone-let-this-pass flaws), and despite a consistency to the look of the world and the characters, perhaps the director's only strong suit in coralling so many elements together, it's all for a story and heroes/villains/Gods/side Gods/hot-Goddesses that is dead on arrival.

What have you lizard people done with Alex Proyas?

review_title: It's not bad but still yikes somehow.

review_detailed_main: It's sad to see so many people disliking this movie...but throughout the movie i found the action,comedy and love story to be awesome! The gods had beautiful and epic costumes. I can see some scenes at time being unrealistic, yes, but this is mythology! If you want a down to earth movie, then this is not for you. As for the actual characters, I was surprised at how some gods were so weak. The actors matched the characters they portrayed aside from the fact that some looked so old when as a god, I don't think they needed to look that way. Battle music could have been an addition they could have done. The transformations were super cool. I would highly recommend this movie. It is one of my favourites and will probably be wanting to see it again in theatres.
I can't believe Butler got involved in this. This isn't in the same league as 300. One of the worst dialogues I've ever heard. Cringe worthy at best.

review_title: Mortal hero Bek teams with the god Horus in an alliance against the villainous Set.
review_detailed_main:
Many people, including myself saw the trailer for Gods of Egypt and automatically concluded that this film would be not so good. It had a negative controversy/reaction due to the casting choices. Especially since it takes place in Egypt. The CGI didn't look all that impressive, and overall I believe it didn't receive a fair chance. I decided to give it a fair chance, and I wasn't all that impressed.

Obviously, this isn't a representation of the real Egypt. This story is pure fantasy. What you have here are The Gods of Egypt getting together. Things don't go according to plan, that a$$hole Set, played by Gerard Butler (300, Olympus Has Fallen) has to have complete control over Egypt, and take over everything. Set kills, and even takes out his own nephew Horus. If Set weren't bad enough, he has to dig into Horus' face and pull out his eyeballs too. One day Horus meets Bek, played by Brenton Thwaites (Maleficent, The Giver). Bek and Horus work together to stop Set. Will Horus overcome Set's cruel rule over Egypt? Will the land of the pharaohs regain peace once again? Only time will tell.

No out of all the controversy this film has gotten, Hollywood can keep this silly ass Egypt for all I care, because I sure as Hell don't want it. This movie is not good; it's Egypt on acid. The plot is loose, the history is to fantasized, and the characters are just white yogurt and plain as you can get. Call me crazy, but I think Jupiter Ascending is more scientifically correct and accurate than Gods of Egypt. They emphasis the CGI over story, which I will never understand why they do this. CGI should be used to enhance the story. The actors really do try, but the source material isn't there for them to work to the best of their abilities. Also, why is Gerard Butler the only man in Ancient Egypt with a mixture of a British and Scottish accent? (TONIGHT WE DINE IN KEMET!)

I know it sounds like I'm over writing about the CGI, but I've seen video games that look more realistic than this. I've read children's books with more character development than this. 140 million dollars went into this film, and I've seen movies that go straight to the Chiller and Sci-fi channel that look far superior than this. This film is directed by Alex Proyas (director of The Crow and I 'Robot). I personally enjoy those films, and yes they are also visually stunning. But they had a compelling story around it unlike this film.

So these are my final Bitchin' Buddha thoughts on the movie Gods of Egypt. I know it sounds like I'm ranting, but if you haven't seen this film, you can skip it. It's way too much CGI, the Gods are weak, it's sexist, characters are boring, the story is loose, the characters are paper thin. The actors do try; sadly they are the only ones I believe put some effort into this project. I believe it's bland, and made for a quick dollar. I found it to be funny, even though that is not the tone. It's some bland B.S. I believe that Gods of Egypt earns a

3/10.

This review is brought to you by Boogie Buddha, and remember, don't just get down, but get Boogie. Thank you for reading and or viewing, and I hope you have an amazing day as always. :)

I went into this film thinking it was going to be of a semi 'serious' theme. Oh boy was I wrong. The acting was terrible and so was slot of the overused CGI! No personality and a cut and paste Disney plot. Ugh.

This film is an insult to any fan of the spiritual tradition of Egypt. There is nothing worse than humanizing the gods and trying to profit from it, since the result can be as tragic as this movie. The motivation of all the characters is ridiculous and the only ones trying to put some dignity on it are Geoffrey Rush and Gerald Butler. You can see they are trying to convey some emotion. Other than that, his work is terrible. Nobody is saved. The excess of cgi is boring especially at the end. The film does not offer an adequate closure, it is sweetened and leaves bitterness since there is neither passion nor intrigue. Bad.

review_title: Fun escape from the real world, highly recommended
review_detailed_main:
Watching this movie was fun! Isn't that what going to the movies is all about with this genre of film?

I did not expect a documentary, or academic deep dive into who, what and why ancient Egyptians (whoever they were, Nubian, black, white, rainbow) believe in their gods. I did however enjoy myself and had a laugh, and squirm on the way.

Effects are pretty spectacular to say the least, and the story is told in a way that that mandates you chill and switch off from the everyday.

After reading some of the trash reports, I suspect people are too full-on about everything these days, too ego centric... Lighten up people, it's a blockbuster, it's a bit of this and a bit of that, and a bit of something new and old.

Damn fun if you can unplug from the politically correct madness of Hollywoood at the moment. We're all people, we're all equal, and fantasy is fantasy. Loved it!

review_title: Everything wrong with Hollywood in one film
review_detailed_main:
OK, lets not mice words - Gods Of Egypt is garbage. It's cringe after cringe of the worst sins a film can commit, to the point where one wonders if they have tried on purpose to make the worst film they could.

The Good:

The costumes are gorgeous. If these costumes had been used in any other setting, they would really have helped in making a great film.

More Leonidas than before. We can't get enough of that one character Gerald Butler played in 300, so we get a second helping here.

The Bad:

Massive CGI overload. It's not "bad CGI", but there is just so much of it, the eye notices more. Also, there's just more detail on screen than there is in the same objects in real life, making it super obvious.

Horrible acting; the actors don't even attempt to fit the characters, aside form Butler, they just read their lines, which results in half the cast sounding like they just got out of Jersey Shore, and half trying to ham it up (FORGIVE ME FATHER, I HAVE OVERACTED !!).

Despite what the title implies, AND the multiple mentions of Egypt, Gods Of Egypt is not set in Egypt, nor is it set in the past, but rather, this is a completely fictional film set into some parallel world with a limited resemblance of Egypt.

The director seems influenced by small screen film, such as music videos; i find it hard to believe it's the same guy who directed the excellent Dark City.

The script, worst guilty party in this film, tries to cram as much garbage on the screen as it possibly can .. i haven't seen something this bad since Episode I.

The plot isn't as horrible as the rest of the film, but it is however overshadowed by the rest of the garbage piling up on top of it, such as, for example, the dialogue. One scene can have comedy, tragedy, action and violence, sadness, amazement, all crammed into the same 3 minutes.

I suppose that, after all, Gods Of Egypt does have a few things going for it, some scenes are visually impressive, mostly due to the sh*tton of money they have thrown at the screen, but i can't count one which isn't spoiled by something, be it greenscreen, some actor chewing the scenery, horrible dialogue, or simply the constant, relentless abuse of CGI.

So, Gods Of Egypt is garbage. If you are no older than 15, and you want to see a 2-hour video game cutscene (and also have very low standards for acting), then this film is for you; if you are older, or simply want to watch an actual film, properly made, then i suggest you skip this monstrosity.

My vote: 4/10 - revolting.
