review_title: Felt like I was swimming in gold.
review_detailed_main: I read the mixed reviews on this board and came close to not seeing this one. I checked all my expectations at the door and just decided to allow my brain to soak it in with a blank slate and pretended that I hadn't read any reviews. One of the opening scenes has the camera sweeping in from a distance to a bustling and thriving Egypt during the early times of the Pyramids. I thought okay, that was cool but I purposefully kept my expectations low for the time being. To my surprise the visually stunning cinematography didn't stop there. The movie presents each and every scene up on a golden platter with an eye for opulence and bejeweled detail. The storyline, while not bad takes a back seat to the non-stop sensory overload of what you're seeing. It imagines the unimaginable and takes you there in a good way. The unearthly spectral realm is treated with due respect and given a realistic authenticity. This movie dresses you up in gold from head to toe then dangles you out over a ledge. The story and acting didn't really affect my opinion either way. This movie is an experience to be enjoyed like a roller coaster ride. If you try to reason with any aspect of it then you'll probably miss the boat.

First of all, this movie is not correctly categorized by IMDb, as it is an animation movie. Most of it looks like a Space Jam or Mary Poppins kind of movie but without the acting. Live actors play on animated (not even cgi! to me) backgrounds and wear animated armors. What annoyed me most was that all backgrounds were vague, something like bad photoshoped skies or desert sands.

It's a pity they made it like that. It could have been a better movie if they had used more solid backgrounds, real scenery and more slow pace. The casting (although more Nordic than Egyptian) had great names that could have taken the film to satisfactory levels, if there was any dialogue that is! I think the 1st time the actors actually acted was somewhere in the middle of the movie and then words faded away again, leaving their place to foggy cgi.

There was however some good material, like some traits of production design, a couple of action scenes and a couple of Courtney Eaton's assets, but other than that, the movie is as alive as the 2 pita-soulvakis I ate watching it.

review_title: Even the blind would have issues with this film
review_detailed_main:
A popcorn frothy movie for himbos in which a bunch of white guys donn English accents and pretend to be Egyptian. It's pure cringe.

Set deep into an appropriated ancient culture, stand-in-every-white-boy Bek loses the love of his life, only to team up with the God Horace (played by a Danish actor) to rescue her and set things right in their world.

The film is infested with terrible CGI, a hack script, and pivoted forward on a flimsy plot that would have made for a better video game.

Smoke some before going in and you might just enjoy it. Otherwise, if you're looking for intelligent and respectful action films, keep this off your list.

Gods of Egypt

The upside to a bird-headed god is they're easily appeased with a bucket of mice guts.

Mind you, the falcon-faced deity in this action-fantasy movie would rather devour his nemesis.

When the immortal Set (Gerard Butler) assassinates Osiris (Bryan Brown), the King of Egypt, and declares a new tax on all souls passing over into the afterlife, the avian lord Horus (Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau) partners with a street urchin, Bek (Brenton Thwaites), who has intimate knowledge of his enemy's booby-trapped compound.

But, in exchange, for helping him, Bek needs Horus' aid in retrieving his love (Courtney Eaton) from the afterworld.

Inlaid with overblown special effects and abysmal performances from a fair-skinned cast, this whitewashed construct of an alternative Egypt is grossly inaccurate, insulting and inane all at the same time.

Furthermore, with all of their internal organs removed, Egyptians had plenty of room to store spare change for any afterlife tolls.

Red Light

vidiotreviews.blogspot.ca

Wow ok this will be short. This film is the definition of turn your brain off, grab some snacks, a beverage, and sitdown relax for what's to come.

This film heavily relies on CGI which maybe wouldn't be so bad if the CGI wasn't so trash. Story is bland, enough to keep your attention I suppose.

Acting is passable, Gerard Butler, and Nikolaj Coster-Waldau gave solid enough performances. Though Chadwick Boseman, and Geoffrey Rush are in my opinion the better actors of this film. Though even they cannot turn the terrible material that was given to them into gold.

Overall if you're looking for something mindless, and just want to relax you can do worse than this film.

3/10.

I could not believe that this piece of trash was directed by Alex Proyas, of the modern day classic, "The Crow." Evidently, he has gone down the same awful decline that Ridley Scott has of late.

I'm only about 1/2 way through watching this and already am hating it.

OK, without any spoilers, the pros and cons: PROS: - Nice graphics and fight scenes. (But then again, what movie these days doesn't have these? Well, at least the big budget ones with famous directors) - Good-looking actors, even if they are whitewashed.

CONS: Too long to list them all, but in short: - So whitewashed that you'll quite literally be blinded by the white. - Utterly predictable plot. I pretty much know already how this crapshow is gonna end. - Oh, and did I mention my obviously biggest gripe with this film? I probably did, but it bears repeating.

This is a fine movie to Netflix and chill with, but not much more. Go watch Stargate instead.

review_title: Don't listen to reviews and critics they are miss-leading
review_detailed_main:
OK this is the first time I am leaving a review and I just couldn't stand these bad reviews that are like for nothing. The movie is ABSOLUTELY great and you will not lose interest not even for 2 minutes since it's a major action-adventure movie with great actors and cast choice, following very awesome and interesting story line that will make you wonder throughout the movie how will things turn out to be. It wasn't very predictable even tho it wasn't complex AT ALL.

Some of these reviews make me wonder if people enjoy any movie without finding or creating the slightest reason to be dramatic and annoying, just like the reason most reviews I read here saying the actor choice is TOO white? Are you kidding me this is a Hollywood made, fiction movie about the Egypt and gods and powers and that's what bothered them really?

Anyways the movie is awesome and like I said don't bother reading reviews. thanks

review_title: Trash. Entertaining trash but still trash.
review_detailed_main:
Not as bad as you might have heard and it is entertaining but this is still not a good movie.

It's basically a 2 hour long video game cutscene or a 14 year old's sweaty fever dream. Alex Proyas directed this? The guy who made The Crow?.......REALLY???

I love fantasy movies so i'm fine with things being over the top and i don't care if everyone is white (seriously it's a movie, get a grip.) but this is just so overbearingly loud, stupid and cheesy. The characters are cardboard people and the main hero's girlfriend's awesome boobs have more personality.

Gerard Butler chews up and spits out the scenery and he was made my favourite part.

Some of the CGI looks pretty cool whereas at other times it looks really bad. Did they run out of money half way through or something?

It's trash, entertaining trash but still trash.

If you google 'Gods of Egypt' and click on the reviews available on Rotten Tomatoes you will find an amusing paraphrase of PB. Shelley's great sonnet 'Ozymandias' which reads: "Look on Gods of Egypt, ye filmgoers, and despair! Nothing beside remains. Round the decay of this colossal wreck, boundless and bare. The lone and level sands stretch far away." I have quoted these lines because to me they are an accurate description of this brainless, soulless, insipid film. Despite featuring a solid cast, 'Gods of Egypt' is a massive failure which follows the standard formula of a conventional and boring action film with uninteresting characters and careless dialogue and stupid fantasy sequences. It is a fatally flawed and creatively inept effort. I will never understand why this film has got at least a 5.4 / 10 in this platform, it really doesn't deserve to pass. It takes away the fun of the sophisticated and fascinating Egyptian pantheon of deities. Overall it feels like a video game, not like a film. Come one, just look at the poster, it is telling you: 'This is going to be a bad film'. The elaborate visual effects and its cast are the only merits I can see in this deeply flawed adventure movie. You can watch it if there's nothing else in TV, and you'll probably be entertained by its lifeless fun. But on the whole this is a godless vision of Egypt.

Grade: 2.3 / 10

review_title: Looks great but the storyline was poor. 5/10
review_detailed_main:
Review: After an epic beginning, I was quite impressed with this movie but the storyline was all over the place. The director kept on adding new elements, which spoilt the flow of the movie, which could have been much simpler if he would have just stuck to the good vs. evil concept. The main character, Bek (Brenton Thwaites), was quite annoying throughout the film but Gerard Butler was great as the evil Set. Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau also played Horus quite well and the extravagant scenery was well put together by the director but it did look a bit over the top in places. He certainly took full advantage of today's CGI abilities but the epic journey did seem slightly unrealistic. In terms of entertainment, it reminded me of John Carter, which also had a massive budget but it didn't really smash the box office, and I can just imagine how hard it must have been for the actors, who spent most of the time talking and fighting against objects that wasn't really there. It was good to see Butler back in 300 mode, and Geoffrey Rush was great as Ra but the storyline really let this movie down, which is a shame because all of the efforts which were put into the visual effects, was pretty good. Watchable!

Round-Up: This movie was directed by Alex Proyas, 52, who also brought you the Crow in 1994, Dark City, I, Robot in 2004, with Will Smith and Knowing in 2009, with Nicolas Cage. He's not one to take on many projects, because I can just imagine how long this film and some of his previous movies, must have taken to make. He definitely has a track record of using a lot of visual effects, so this project was a great choice for him but the writing really wasn't that great. It was written by Matt Sazama & Burk Sharpness, who also brought you Dracula Untold, The Last Witch Hunter and the upcoming Power Rangers movie, so judging by there previous projects, I'm not surprised with the way that this movie turned out. I was expecting it to make more money at the box office but it obviously didn't go down too well with audiences. The critics didn't put it down like they did with John Carter but it still seemed to come in and out of the top ten for that period, really quickly.

Budget: $140million Worldwide Gross: $146million

I recommend this movie to people who are into their action/fantasy/adventure movies, starring Gerard Butler, Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau, Brenton Thwaites, Bryan Brown, Chadwick Boseman, Rufus Sewell, Courtney Eaton, Elodie Yung and Geoffrey Rush. 5/10

Gods of Egypt (2016) Starring: Gerard Butler, Nikolaj Coaster- Waldau, Brenton Thwaites, Chadwick Boseman, Elodie Yung, Geoffrey Rush, Courtney Eaton, Rufus Sewell, Abbey Lee Kershaw, Bryan Brown, Emma Booth, Goran D. Kleut, and Emily Wheaton Directed By: Alex Proyas Review The battle for eternity begins When the film came out earlier this year I knew very little about it, just that it had to do with Gods, mortals and had Gerard Butler. I have been looking into sword and sorcery films as of late and am going to have a marathon for those types of films next once I own all the films I need but while I searching up the sub-genre on facebook I saw that Gods of Egypt was one so I decided to review it now because I'm mostly going to cover the 80s fantasy ones for my marathon. An opening voice-over states that according to a legend, Egypt was the birthplace of civilization. The gods co-existed among the mortals and created the flourishing land for them to share. The son of Ra, Osiris, ruled over the land, while his brother Set was relegated to the desert, to his anger. The time has come for Horus, the son of Osiris, to take his place as king.

A mortal young man named Bek (Brenton Thwaites) steals a dress from a vendor in the market to give to his beloved Zaya (Courtney Eaton). They are preparing to go to the coronation event later that day.

Horus (Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau) is passed out from a wild event of drinking with the gods the previous night. His beloved woman is Hathor (Elodie Yung), the goddess of love.

The time comes for the coronation to take place. Bek and Zaya, along with nearly the whole city, is in attendance. Osiris (Bryan Brown) and his wife Isis (Rachael Blake) bring their son forward and are prepared to pass leadership to him, when Set (Gerard Butler) arrives at the last minute with a gift for Horus, a battle horn. Horus blows into it, summoning Set's army to the front. Turns out Set is staging a coup against his brother and nephew. He demands Osiris to battle him, but he refuses. Set stabs Osiris in the abdomen, leaving him to bleed gold and die. Enraged, Horus transforms into his winged god form, while Set morphs into his dog-like form. They battle in front of everyone, but Set gains the upper hand and is ready to kill Horus until Hathor kneels before him so that Horus may be spared. Set orders all the gods and mortals to kneel before him, and he plucks out both of Horus's all-seeing eyes.

A year passes, and all of Egypt is under Set's rule. Those who do not follow him are either left dead or thrown into slavery, like Zaya. Bek frequently visits her in secrecy while her cruel master Urshu (Rufus Sewell) tends to his business with Set, which is building monuments in his honor. Zaya says that only Horus can save them, but he needs his eyes, which are kept in Set's vaults.

The plot is interesting and the cast is pretty good but when you get to the CG I mean it is just a mess It is a big giant computer your looking at when the Gods transform I mean you can feel the pixels coming off the screen. The adventure is grand in scale which is great. This looks like a great new sword/sorcery epic but with the lousy effects that's just one huge thing that brings it down. Along with a stupid decision or rather pointless made by Hathor. You'll get it if you some reason plan to see this mess. It didn't click with me because of how much it just looked like one big video game cut scene and I didn't or rather much couldn't get into the characters. Director Alex Proyas has made some pretty decent films in the past, I really enjoy I. Robot with Will Smith and I've good things about Dark City. But with this and Knowing he's become much worse. I'm going to be giving Gods of Egypt a two out of five its just terrible.

review_title: Could Have Been So Much Better
review_detailed_main:
The premise was scattered, formulaic & boring. A few scenes were well presented but only from an artistic/design perspective. Gerard Butler's Scottish accent was beyond the pale with generic acting - his overall look was more Hollywood model than an attempt to create at least a 'new' character-type. Everyone else at least fell into the fantasy hair style, costume look the audience is used to.

Unfortunately more laughs were induced in our audience of teens to forty-somethings - all in the wrong places. It's too bad because this could have been so, so much better either taking the subject more seriously or taking the fantasy into a more clever & intelligent path.

I went in with low expectation due to all the negative reviews but found it a fun romp.

There is one scene which is important to the understanding to the approach. The earth is shown flat as a pancake - Ra goes over the edge to go the "flip side". Thus this is not the Egypt we know in real life, but a fantasy one. Therefore all the hubbub about incorrect ethnic casting can be ignored.

This fantasy world is consistently imagined. Sure the plots are nothing special and some of the action seemed to have been lifted from other films or even video games. And the CGI was glitchy sometimes (edge of wings). But it is overall visually satisfying and I found myself caring for some of the characters (e.g. Hathor).

But I wished that they had shown that the body parts of the other gods survived the death of Set, and that the Architect found that his jewels were for nothing at the final gate since Horus changed the rules.

Some day the people who finance movies like this will learn that more-more-more is not necessarily the best philosophy--even for spectacles. Eight or ten fight scenes or harrowing escapes would be plenty. After that, the viewer's mind begins to numb.

The first 20-30 minutes were fine, to me, although the characters could have used more development. You can almost imagine the director saying, "We need to get through this stuff so the CGI guys can take over. That's what they want to see!" Even after the story is launched, the interludes where we get to learn more about the characters were too brief. Bek was an entertaining, Ulysses-like character with some great lines, and Zaya was endearing and a feast for the eyes. They might have saved the film with more time on-screen. But no, they disappeared in a headlong rush of CGI-driven scenes where there's no real feeling of peril, just raging gods and goddesses, collapsing buildings, strange creatures slithering around, and Geoffrey Rush imagining what he's going to do to his agent after he gets off work.

Don't get me wrong. I know it's a fantasy movie, and it is imaginary gods we're talking about. I also know that people who pay ten bucks for a ticket and fifteen more for popcorn and a Coke expect to go home having been entertained. But I think more focus on the characters, and a running length of 100 minutes, would have made this a much better movie.

I do get why people hate this movie. But i also understand why people love it so much.

It's ambitious, it's somewhat funny and it's just entertaining.

But...

The special effects are bad(horrific sometimes). The accuracy isn't that great either.

But seriously, the cast is what makes this movie better than it should be. The actors in this movie are top notch.

Soo, it's entertaining but not great. End of story

This movie had an amazing concept, like an Egyptian Mythology Clash of the Titans. But in the end it relied too heavily on CGI. This resulted with scenes that liked like something out of a video game, and not in a good way.

Once I caught a glimpse of the footage from the trailer for this blockbuster back when it just released, I immediately thought that it was definitely not worth the price of a cinema ticket. It seemed very uninspired and even cheap, which is generally not good for this type of movie. Unfortunately, this premonition did not deceive me.

The plot is not important. It's too generic! Here one god kills another, a son tries to avenge his father - it doesn't work out. Everything is bad. Mortals are slaves, just like other gods. A hero is found who takes the side of the exiled God, Horus. And a generic story about the noble rebellion begins.

It is clear that the script is not the best thing in the film. It's common for a blockbuster to focus on staging action... However, the CGI is somehow even worse.

It's funny that the Gods (Gerard Butler, Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) at least try to express a couple of basic emotions, which cannot be said about the "mortal" (Brenton Thwaites). The latter does not express any emotions when misfortune happens to the girl he loves... absolutely terrible acting.

As a result, Gods of Egypt is one of those films that you can still watch at the end of a difficult work or school day. There will be nothing special here, but it can serve as some kind brain fast-food if you're really bored or just want to turn your mind off for a couple of hours.

review_title: No, no, and just no good
review_detailed_main:
This movie is a CGI mess and a bit of a slog to get through. There's nothing endearing or really enjoyable about it.

Our young mortal lead is only the slightest bit charming, and that's where the charm ends.

Gerard Butler speaking with a clearly still Scottish accent while portraying an Ancient Egypt God is laughable, and truly was the only joy I got out of this film.

This movie really needed to look good to work, and it does not. The larger than mortal Gods does not work as a special effect here.

I cannot recommend this movie to anyone for any reason unless you need some background noise to fill the silence.

I love this movie, it is very good, spectacular and artistic.I liked the actors... Horus was very SEXY :)))) and Seth was very strong! Like them. I know the Egyptian mythology, because of it I think this is film is an absolutely entertaining film. The story is "built" very much from the mythology. I ask the director, and the actors and the team, PLEASE do not believe the negative reviews!! This movie is very good! Your work is professional. I would like more films in this topic :))) I see that the filmmakers thing that there are only Greek(Roman) or Nordern mythology... This is not true! There are more and more very interesting stories in the Egyptian mythology and in the ancient Egyptian history. I am looking forward the next movie, the next "episode" Gods of Egypt!!!!!!!

review_title: A spectacular meatloaf on the trails of Percy Jackson and the Gods of Egypt.
review_detailed_main: Messing around with myths, from Greek ones to Egyptian ones, is a cult in movies since the old glorious days of Cinecittà and the beginnings of Hollywood. I can't count how many Odisseus and Troy films have been made to these days, Clash of the Titans and so on. Being faithful to a mythological story is sometimes tricky when you want to make a good movie without being ridiculous but, nowadays, audience is more used to fantasy movies and fantastic stories so producer, writers and directors can be more bold. Maybe that's the fault, maybe a story based on a mythology (which means old funny religion) is a good ground for a stunning, eye candy, nonsense movie. The many discrepancies and anachronisms are often too much to allow this film to be called Gods of Egypt. The gods hierarchy is messed, the earth is depicted as flat (really??) while we know perfectly that Egyptians were perfectly aware of the roundness of our planet. and (once again after Stargate) gods (RAH) looks more like aliens (not that crap again) than deities. Worth a look but not the box of popcorn and, certainly, not the cost of the disc.

Great movies on ancient Egypt are always very interesting and quite captivating. I've always paid some kind of interest in mythology for whatever reason because whether you like it or not they are in a similar way to soap operas with a little bit more action. There was almost everything in terms of ingredients in regards to what one should expect from such a movie. A hot spice of betrayal, romance, adventure, some humour and action. In other words, something you would very certainly enjoy in couple or in family.

First, I have to say that Elodie Yung for instance is the real incarnation of perfection. She is unlimited with her beauty and I'm not sure of another type of profile that could embody this role. She is graceful and suits the role of a princess/goddess in a variety of ways and to perfection. She has a certain sense of humor, of entitlement, class and elitism that I really did appreciate.

On the scenario itself, it was interesting and actually did make sense till the end. However, the romance around Courtney Eaton became annoying after a certain time and I did feel that it could have been tempered a little bit. I understand that they love themselves and I also understand that in Greek mythology there has always been these kinds love struggles but I found that was a certain form of obsession for her. I know they love themselves, but that was becoming a little bit overbearing.

The action scenes were sometimes quite impressive to say the least though one could see that they were entirely manufactured through digital process but this was not enough to disrupt the overall good quality.

While there was some visible scenes of humour, I think this aspect could have probably been explored a little bit more with the characters. I think there was attempts but that trait was underused quite a bit. For example, the whole scene when they were on their way to meet Chadwick Boseman including the one where they were actually with him had some interesting sequences of humour which were not entirely pushed to their advantage. Knowingly, this was not a comedy but I did think that it brought a different perspective.

Globally, the main negative point is related to the animations of the gods when they transformed themselves. Like I had previously said, on some aspects you could see the computer at work. Some of them lacked fluidity and natural feel compared to the rest.

Finally, to continue on the environment, some of the landscapes did also lack a certain feel of reality for the same reasons. That scene with the horses for instance with Courtney Eaton, you could easily see the green background.

Despite these small technical detail, from an overall standpoint they were quite beautiful and there was a lot of variety into which the characters were placed. Generally, this is one aspect that I appreciate in movies related to mythology. You get a wide array of characters and unexpected elements that make them fascinating. This generally makes the movie extremely dynamic and interesting for the spectator.

I would say in general, this was a good movie that I would recommend.

King Leonidas, Black Panther, and Jaime Lannister get together for a slow CGI fest. I knew straight off that this was not going to be an 8 but maybe with the CGI and the promising cast something bloody and epic with good fights would come out of it... Eh think again. Standard Hero movie where the main is happy something bad happens and goes into hiding and then the movie es about the redemption to get back to his original happy place. I found it a bit too slow and the action or fight scenes we'rent that many or that great to really justify it. This is perfect background noise type of movie.

review_title: Think I understand why there are more movies on the Greek Gods than the Egyptian ones.
review_detailed_main:
Wow! this movie stunk. What a disappointment, and I herd they dump a lot of money into it.

Off the top, the CGI in the movie was so overwhelming, the movie should have been animated. I don't even understand why they just didn't. It would be one thing if it was good CGI, but it was bad CGI. I think the movie suffers from the fact that they were doing something new with the Egyptian gods being bigger than man and having to match that up (of course that does not explain the other effects). Definitively nothing to brag about, just made my eyes water.

Not fully familiar with all the Gods of Egypt and I was hoping this movie would change that. I don't know if the movie was using a actual tale of the Gods or was this an original story starring the Gods of Egypt. Either way the story was bland. Most of this had to do with both heroes of the movie, Horus the god and Bek the mortal by his side, being so uninteresting.

I thought the supporting cast was a lot better. Chadwick Boseman as Thoth was amusing and so was Gerard Butler as Set (but I don't think that was the plan). The two girls that are in the movie are beautiful, but forgettable in their roles, plus Geoffrey Rush was kind of a waste of time.

I have to say skip this one, definitely. There is not enough positive elements in the movie that justify going to see it.

It's a real snooze.

review_title: I've played video games with better plot
review_detailed_main:
First of all, for all the morons whining about the cast being too white, just Google "Egyptian actors" and send me a call if you find ANYONE who is NOT white in the first 2 pages, because I had a hell of a hard time myself! But I won't have any argument for the British actors in the middle as well, but, to be fair, Gerard Butler as the arrogant, egomaniac, evil overlord of chaos and wastelands was the most perfect choice I could've though of. But casting issues aside....

Visually, it was amazing. The special effects and designs were stunning, representing the Egyptian gods in new, yet very adequate ways, except maybe for Horus who looked like a golden Iron Man, the rest of the characters looked gorgeous. And the monsters were also amazing. The backgrounds made me wish I could jump inside the screen and live there, just so surrel and marvelous they were designed.

But the plot....was that a gameplay I was watching? Seriously, I could pretty much tell what was a bossfight, a sidequest, a NPC talking, a RESPAW, an upgrade, even that moment of Set and the pieces of other gods felt like an RPG character and his inventory! Brain of Tot, wisdow +5, wings of Nemphis, agility 10+, eye of horus, Accuracy +20. WHich also made this movie completely TRAMPLE the Egyptian mythology. Oh yea, the gods of Egypt do have their OWN story and it's much better than this movie's. Whoever wrote the script really had a lot of ideas, but simply wasn't fit for a movie. If they adapt this movie into a video game, it will be better than the movie.

review_title: I Enjoyed Gods of Egypt So Much I Want to See It Again!
review_detailed_main: This is a really fun and positive movie! Gods Of Egypt has very hot guys and gals so no matter what your sexual preference is there's somebody who will get you excited. The acting is excellent. There is real chemistry between the actors. I identified with many of the story's characters. That made me feel good. You don't need to know anything about the Egyptian Gods to understand what is going on. The story is well balanced, it has a solid beginning, middle and end. The Gods of Egypt keeps your interest from beginning to end. There's a lot of variety. So much is going on and that's one of the reasons I love adventure movies. The cinematography and the CGI are fantastic. You really enter another world without hesitation. This Is Pagan Friendly Film About the Egyptian Gods! There's no camp here. The Egyptian Gods are respected and feel quite real. This is a story about love, hormones, real courage and dare I SAY SELF-SACRIFICE! Yes! There is a really positive spiritual message in the Gods of Egypt.Wow!

review_title: I just vomited in my mouth...
review_detailed_main: You know the action is amazing. Costumes amazing. Set amazing. Story line great. Cinematography amazing. What gets 1 star? Why oh why is this whitewashed yet again??? But damn.... Don't get me wrong I love the actors in this and in other roles they played. They all did a great job, but did they look the part?!?! Why do I feel like I'm watching another movie from the 50s? Am I watching cleopatra? Ben Hur? No but I might as well. Why oh why is this movie white washed?! From the opening credits it's like, "lies lies lies". So sad. So disheartening. Just more appropriation. I watched it when it first came out. Tried to rewatch it and it makes me sick to my stomach. Do better directors and produces and financiers. DO BETTER!!

I honestly could not get past the fact that they used so many White people in this movie (and I'm white). Like they really wanted me to buy into that when Egyptians were black. I'm an Egypt buff and so this movie was painful to watch and I almost shut it off.

This one reviewer left such an ignorant post I had to respond. She states people who claim the cast is too white need to basically chill. Then she used some example of Star Wars being too human, or something to that effect. Guess that made sense in her privileged head. I ask if you watched a "Fairy Tale" movie about Queen Elizabeth and it was an all Asian cast, or Jack the Ripper with an all Black cast, would you still sit down and enjoy the movie without nitpicking? I digress.

Regarding the movie...

The special effects were neat enough to keep my kids (ages < 7) attention. However I found myself disinterested. I walked out the room to multitask during the apex battle of the movie; which should tell you something. They could've stop trying to remotely pull this poorly written plot together and cut 30 mins off the movie. It felt like someone read a couple paragraphs regarding Egyptian history on Wikipedia, then just took off with their own interpretation. I get it's fantasy and we're supposed to just let everything go, but it turns into a CGI fest where you'd rather see special effects than see any dialogue whatsoever.

I wouldn't suggest this movie, but it is something to have on the TV while you're doing something else productive.

I wondered why I knew so many Australian actors in this movie. Then I realised it's an Australian movie! Australia has created some incredible movies with incredible stories and incredible acting performances...this monstrosity is not one of them. This is CGI drivel with a script my 10 year old could write.

It is baffling how atrocious Gods of Egypt is. Every on screen turnout piles up blunder after blunder, that as the credits of this overly long crap roll, I felt mocked and cheated for the time wasted. It is simply an offensive mishmash of uninteresting & annoying characters, poorly written screenplay and cheesy dialogues that tries its hardest to be humorous, failing miserably. Its heavy reliance on seriously flawed & cartoonish visual effects for its flare and climactic scenes, was a mistake, as its cheapness was glaring and disengaging. The cinematic acting of its lesser named, yet gorgeous stars is another irritant, mirroring soap opera actors, where talents are foregone for eye candy's sake.

Gods of Egypt then, is definitely in play as one of the worst 2016 has to offer. It opens our eyes to the reality that not all filmmakers who dare venture to ancient epics, are Zack Synders. Some are Alex Proyas' whose offerings resemble B movies at most.

I really enjoyed this movie; the cast, dialog and effects. I didn't go see the Gods of Egypt for a lesson in Egyptian history (it's science fiction), I went to be entertained...which in my opinion this move does quite well. When reading some of the negative or poor reviews, it bring me to the truth that I know that there are some people that are just too up tight, or just like to put other people's work down. To each their own.

If you enjoy a good, clean (I don't recall any bad language in this move), action and adventure move, go see this movie on the big screen and enjoy it. If you are looking for an accurate account of ancient Egyptian history, find a documentary on the History channel to watch.

Gods Of Egypt Is one of the worst movies I have ever seen u don't care for the characters that action does nothing the pacing is horrible Also the dialogue is trash What I don't like there is no story and we are in the action for no reason I don't have a lot to say it is boring everything went gone So I give Gods Of Egypt an F.

review_title: An extremely flawed Egyptian version of "Clash of the Titans."
review_detailed_main: What could have been an Egyptian version of Clash of the Titans (2010) suffered from way too many flaws. Right from the start, the dialogue was awful, the characters were woefully miscast (none of them even came close to looking like they were Egyptian), and the CGI was unbelievable at best. In fact, it almost tries to make up for it through the sheer amount of distracting cleavage, which accounts for exactly 1 star of this review.

review_title: Poor and all over the map flick
review_detailed_main:
Greetings from Lithuania.

"Gods of Egypt" (2016) is basically a bad Transformers movie set in Egypt. I know that doesn't make sense, not does this flick. It is so badly written, so overproduced that it started to drag in like first 15 opening minutes. Performances, if there were so, are just OK for this material, while Chadwick Boseman gave the best performance in this disastrous poor flick. Even the visuals in this movie were poor and not engaging, not involving. There is one nice action sequence during the whole damn movie, and it's the one with two some sort of huge snakes in the desert, everything else were just plain poor.

Overall, "Gods of Egypt" is a very poorly made nonsense. I know it is a popcorn flick which you need to see with some beer and popcorn and some friends - but even that didn't help me to like this movie. Poor, poor flick.

review_title: Gods of one of the Idiots who directed this movie

review_detailed_main:
I'm truly divided when it comes to reviewing this movie. First of all it's not a good movie, the acting was cheesy, the characters are beyond annoying, 80% is CGI/green screen, the story/script is half baked and the tone of the movie jumps from comedy to action to drama. But damn what did I have a good time watching this. Now LET ME EXPLAIN!!

Most of you all know that I'm a man of nostalgia. I love things that can pull my nostalgia strings  and boy did this movie do that and in spades. Why you may ask? Well let me tell you. Movies these days, good or bad, have become too serious and gritty, which isn't a bad thing. However, because of this I've noticed that a specific genre of movies have been dying out. Namely, fun adventure movies, or fun action flicks or just fun movies. How long has it been since you've seen an action movie in the vein of demolition man, commando, or (to stay in the theme of the movie) the mummy. Movies that can take you on an adventure and not take itself too seriously without emphasizing the humor.

DAMN Henny you're OLD!! That may be the case, but let me ask you (everyone older than 25 :P ) don't you miss fun movies? Movies with one liners, adventures with ridiculous plots, a basic message like "be good", and just have a good time watching it? NO? Hmmm . Well I do miss it and this movie brought me back to that time when these movies were the standard and not the exception.

Gods of Egypt hearkens back to a time of simpler movie making. A homage to the times of old. However, the question remains if this was the intention of the director. If it is I find it surprising that Alex Proyas, one of the founders of gritty and serious movies like The Crow and Dark City would make something like this.

Now let me sum it all up and quickly end this review (since everyone thinks that my reviews are too long).

The story: The movie is about the Egyptian gods of old and during a coronation of the god Horus (aka the protagonist) his uncle staged a coup d'etat and took the kingdom and his eyes away from him. After that we follow a mortal boy named Beck (sidekick) whom steals the eyes back. And together they go on an adventure to take revenge.

The bad: I've already summed up most of the bad in the introduction. What I do want to add is that the movie is too long: 2 hours. It was hard to keep my attention. I would cut 30 minutes from it. The movie also wasn't balanced, switching from a slow pace to a fast face. They should have cut some of the action and spend more time on character development and MYTHOLOGY building.

The good: It was fun for the most part but it is a shame that they didn't make the script more compact. I truly liked the cinematography (even though it was mostly cgi). But I especially liked the design of the movie. I thought it was original how they have given the mythological creatures form. And I truly liked the cheesy performance of every character (except the sidekick).

Three-Act-Structure: The movie has a fun interesting beginning, lazy middle, and an acceptable ending.

So should I recommend this movie? Absolutely NOT. If you truly want to visit the good old times just re-watch the old movies. This was fun for me since I had nothing better to do but it isn't worth your time.

I'm feeling generous today and I'll give this movie a: 5.5

review_title: Absolutely Beautiful, lovely women, epic fantasy...don't miss it

review_title: Gods of Egypt is miscast but has some OK special effects

review_detailed_main:
If Denzel Washington were cast as the emperor of Rome, that decision would be rightfully assaulted on every platform of social media. Yet this, and every other film about ancient Egypt casts a white actor as the ruler of Egypt.

"Europeans" of Egypt is yet another demonstration of "liberal" "inclusive" "progressive" Hollywood's propagation of white supremacy. They even included the typical token black character as they often do to ease their hypocritical, liberal conscience. Now that I know (according to Hollywood) Europeans ruled Egypt as Kings, Queens, and Gods; and they created the universe, my indoctrination is complete.

It is extremely unfortunate that due to their inherit racism, Hollywood glorifies all things historically white such as Greece, Rome, and England. I can't count the amount of movies based on these three sick and depraved civilizations. The extremely rare occasion Hollywood puts money into a period-based, non-white civilization, they cannot resist themselves and must use even those civilizations to glorify White Supremacy by inserting Europeans into the roles of leadership, royalty, and Gods.

I am sorry if this reality stings a few toes, which is not my intent. I am just sick to my teeth of Hollywood liberals preaching inclusiveness and diversity, when their films are anything but inclusive beyond the typical token-black character. When it comes to rubber meeting the road, and non-white actors getting lead roles, their White Supremacy propaganda films are anything but inclusive. This film, Europeans of Egypt, is additional proof of their "progressive" hypocrisy.

As to the story, the overall imaginary premise gave this film potential. Unfortunately the dull writing, clumsy plot, and cartoony CGI fails to meet any mark. Europeans of Egypt writing and imaginary effects reminds me of the writing and effects of the 1930's sci-fi series, Flash Gordon.

If you just want to see a movie with special effects and cartoon-like CGI, you will love this movie.

"Liberal" Hollywood is still one of the most powerful racist institutions in America. They introduce one new African American talent for every three-hundred new white up-and-comers. They voice the need for diversity and inclusiveness, but appear to be referring to diverse height and hair color among the majority European cast. Hollywood has become slightly more subtle with their overly-blatant racism compared to the days of their greatest creation, the late actor "Stepin Fetchit" (look him up) as well as the TV show called "Beulah" (look this up on YouTube).

Europeans of Egypt had a lot of potential and could have even evolved into a franchise, but Hollywood could not overcome their century-old nature of exalting members of the European culture over the historical culture of the region. They attempt to shove a racially inaccurate round peg into a square hole every time. Ever notice how they never exalt black rulers over Greece, Rome or England? Blacks in the movies are always slaves, servants, or a supporting role (aka token).

The writing is bad, the CGI is the worst. As a matter of fact, it's perhaps the very worst CGI ever. Anyone giving this film a pass, has nothing respectable to say. At least it's not as bad as The Last Jedi.

I have heard a lot people complaining about this movie, claiming that it's one of the worst movies ever made. With all that hoopla I thought I might give the movie a watch.

The first thing that I noticed was the overwhelmingly white cast. I don't know why Hollywood continues to paint a wrong picture of historical events as they pertain to Egypt but this is done deliberately. I'm normally not much of a social justice warrior but this is something that's just disrespectful. I mean, have you ever seen a movie about the history of China that was cast almost entirely with white people? I don't think so. Then why the exception with Egypt? I digress.

The movie starts out with a fair share of CGI effects which kind of gave me an idea as to what should be expected. The CGI wasn't very convincing so it seemed a little cheap at times. Especially the "transformations", they were quite goofy in my humble opinion. Nowhere in the hieroglyphs does it say that Egyptian gods are Transformers so I really don't get why they decided to go this route.

Storytelling-wise the movie doesn't have much to offer. It's so one- dimensional that even a child could predict most of the occurrences beforehand. The deaths that occur during the movie are what I'd call "premature death scenes". Instead of waiting until some sort of emotional bond can be established with the viewer the characters just die way too early. So early indeed that no one really cares. Even the other characters in the movie seemed totally apathetic towards the deaths of their "loved ones". I call that bad storytelling.

Towards the end the movie gets actually interesting. But unfortunately that's not enough. The negative points clearly outweigh the positive ones (of which there are few to begin with), I'm afraid.

It's not the worst movie I've ever seen but I wouldn't recommend it either. The movie has a strong cast, weak story, and mediocre VFX.

It is difficult to understand why people write negative reviews when it comes to entertainment (movies, music etc) and EVERYTHING is subjective; as if their opinion is the most objective- it is impossible to have objective opinion when you are a person reviewing things created by other persons - ALL IS SUBJECTIVE AS PEOPLE ARE DIFFERENT. Stop reading any reviews. See the trailer and go see the movie so you can judge it for yourself. For me this one was very entertaining because I treat it exactly for what it is supposed to be - a fiction fun movie destined to ENTERTAIN ; I should be CRAZY to start an analysis of every minute of it trying to influence others for some stupid reason just to show how many things I know about an imaginary history

review_title: You lost me during the credits.
review_detailed_main:
You lost me during the credits.

I have never expected nor particularly desired much historical accuracy from a Hollywood movie having to deal with ancient Egypt. The film is mildly entertaining and has some interesting art direction and costume design but for the huge amount of money they spent one could expect something more.

This is a very mediocre movie. The CGI is horrible, the acting even worse. I don't have a problem with how inaccurate the movie is, but poor acting cannot be forgiven. The storyline isn't great either. They could have done a better job at making the story more compelling. The shoddy acting just adds to the already shoddy storyline, and the CGI is the final nail in the coffin.

review_title: A fantasy-adventure movie that should have instead been a fantasy-adventure videogame
review_detailed_main:
On the one hand, filmmaker Alex Proyas isn't wrong: the setting here is not ancient Egypt, but a newly invented fantasy setting that borrows elements of ancient Egyptian mythology, and Egyptian culture. From the moment it begins there could never possibly be any confusing the world of this 2016 picture - swirling together sword and sorcery with science fiction - with, you know, Actual Egypt. On the other hand, that doesn't make it okay to appropriate said elements of real-life culture and mythology, and it doesn't completely excuse the casting of predominantly white Australian or European actors as figures who are very plainly not Australian or European. The actors themselves are generally fine, sure. The feature benefits from swell modern production values. The visuals are rich and dazzling, including sets/environments, costume design, hair, makeup, props, and weapons. Then again, outside of pure animation even the very best of computer-generated imagery grows tiresome, and looks worse the more we see of it. For as much as CGI is employed here, even before twenty minutes have elapsed, 'Gods of Egypt' very swiftly just becomes rather gauche before it really has a chance to get on its feet. Factor in the somewhat dubious conception, and it's no wonder that this flick floundered so completely.

Ancient mythologies can be ripe for adventure storytelling, whether we're looking to Egypt, Scandinavia, Greece, India, China, or any other culture. And so they have been, from Ray Harryhausen classics like 'The 7th voyage of Sinbad,' 'Jason and the Argonauts,' and 1981's 'Clash of the titans,' to 'Xena: Warrior princess,' to videogames like 'Immortals Fenyx Rising' and the 'God of war' series. Given the proliferate CGI and the visuals that aim at all times to stun, awe, and impress, and given the plot of a mortal thief becoming a hero worthy of an immortal pantheon, maybe those latter points of comparison, celebrated titles of electronic gaming, are the real, meaningful kin of this movie. Maybe if 'Gods of Egypt' had been developed not for cinema but for console and/or PC gaming the project would have come off a tad differently. Maybe if there were fewer pixels, polygons, and paltry pretending, and more actual stunts, practical effects, and tangible creations, the film would have been more interesting, engrossing, impactful, and successful. At its best the digital wizardry looks really neat, offering up visions one wishes they could explore inch by inch; at its worst, one is reminded of the gawky opening moments of '3000 miles to Graceland,' Jan Kounen's 'Dobermann,' or Darren Aronofsky's 'Noah.'

I think there are a lot of genuinely terrific ideas in Matt Sazama and Burk Sharpless' screenplay. Against all odds there are some nice poetic flourishes in the dialogue, and the scene writing and narrative are ripe for an epic of fantasy adventure. The entirety does quite come apart in the details, however, for despite excellent thoughts, a lot of the storytelling is blunt, clunky, and graceless, not unlike the worst of the CGI. Too much of the dialogue is, in fact, decidedly awful; characters are not written well, the women least of all. It's debatable how well anyone in the cast comes off, though certainly some (such as, in my opinion, Élodie Yung, and in a much smaller part, Chadwick Boseman) find greater success than others. Among those "others," Gerard Butler is once again basically just chewing scenery for two hours - although, bless his heart, the least that can be said is that this so-so blockbuster, questionable as it is in too many ways, is superior by astronomical leaps and bounds to his best known disaster, '300.' I really do feel sorry for all who participated in this creation in one way or another; their contributions in and of themselves range from fine to splendid, but the best that we might say in a spirit of generosity is that these contributions were guided to unfortunate ends. Once again, in all earnestness, I can only express regret that the script that became this motion picture wasn't instead shopped around to game developers, because there are no few aspects that would feel right at home in that format.

It's not totally rotten. I can honestly say that I was entertained in at least some measure. The overwhelming phoniness does mean, however, that no matter how cool This or That might look, and how much potential there may have been at large, the viewing experience is generally a sadly empty one, and frankly longer than it should have been. There are no real thrills to be had; it's a flick that we can "watch" without actively engaging, and at its worst, maybe it's ideal to only leave it on in the background. Wherever Sazama and Sharpless try to weave in some comedy, it only occasionally meets with any success. The flaws that all too heavily define 'Gods of Egypt' are far too evident, and its worth struggles to keep its head above water. If you do happen to come across it there are worse things you could watch; regrettably, there is so little reason to watch in the first place that I don't really even know who I'd possibly recommend it to. What it comes down to is that this is a middling, somewhat ill-advised title that should have found itself in an altogether different medium. I'm glad for those who get more out of 'Gods of Egypt' than I do, but I'm not so sure that this was a wise way to spend two hours.

Given the ratings, I was a bit nervous about spending money on the movie. However, I was pleasantly surprised. The plot gives the viewer the gist of the Horus vs. Set myth, while still differing enough to offer surprises to people who are familiar with Egyptian mythology. To some degree, the path that one of the main characters follows (to avoid spoilers the character will remain nameless) is a bit predictable, but that doesn't make it bad!

Now, of course, we come to the racial controversy. I need to take a point off for some questionable casting roles. The reasons I don't take off more points are a) we don't know what color Ancient Egyptians were, and b) there was diversity, even if there should have been more. Ancient Egyptian art depicts people with varying skin tones, some light, so it would be difficult to narrow down one particular skin tone and say that this is what the actors should be. The main cast is composed of Scottish, Danish, Australian, Cambodian/French, and African American actors. Overall, there should have been more diversity though, because the bulk of actors are Australian. Which, in no way is bad, it's just that Australians tend to have light skin and, while some Ancient Egyptians may have had lighter skin than people think, the hieroglyphics depict it darker than most of the actors. Even though we can't be sure what skin tone Ancient Egyptians had, the cast should have at least included more people with African descent, given that Egypt is in Africa. If we can't narrow down a skin tone, we can at least be sure of country of origin.

All of the actors did a decent job playing his/her respective character, but I have to say that some choices seemed odd. Geoffery Rush is an amazing actor and he will forever be the one of the best pirates I've ever seen on screen. He wasn't as memorable as the sun god, though. For Ra (and maybe I'm a bit biased, being a fan of classic lit.), I'd expect someone to ooze majesticness. Rush's performance seems a bit more surly. I mean, hey given what he has to do every day, I could see a bit battle-worn. But I never get the feeling of awe I'd expect from the head honcho of the gods. Gerard Butler makes a very attractive and powerful Set and I feel bad about discounting him on something he can't control. However, his Scottishness made the choice of him as Set seem a bit odd. Hearing a Scottish accent in the voice of an Egyptian god causes a bit of confusion. Honestly, I would have chosen different actors to play them. I can't narrow down one for Ra, but Peter Mensah would have made a great Set.

Anyway, I loved the movie and was extremely entertained even if I disagreed with some of the casting choices.

Alex Proyas's return to directing following a 7 year hiatus couldn't have come at a worse time. Just as the film industry was up in arms about the #OscarSoWhite debacle, Gods of Egypt arrived in cinemas boasting a near-all Caucasian cast despite being set in Africa. The demand for diversity in Hollywood duly followed, and rightly so, but the questionable casting isn't even the worst thing about the film. Gods of Egypt is a bloated, garish and nonsensical piece of trash, the cinematic equivalent of Raheem Sterling's bathroom. Is this really the same visionary who brought us The Crow (1994) and Dark City (1998)?

Sadly it is, and it completes a steady quality decline in Proyas's output which began in 2004 with his middle-finger to Isaac Asimov, I, Robot. On paper, the big-budget tale of Gods living amongst humans battling it out for the throne may seem like the perfect the opportunity for some campy, brain-on-auto-pilot fun. However, it fails to even offer any sort of camp appeal due to a cast either gobbled up by the video-game cutaway special effects or so utterly devoid of charisma. The main offender is Brenton Thwaites, a young actor who looks like he's been custom-built to appeal to any teenage girls in the crowd. He plays Bek, a human living in a thriving Egypt governed by ten-foot Gods, and sadly he is our protagonist.

Bek, along with his pretty girlfriend Zaya (Courtney Eaton), witnesses the handing-over of the crown from the abdicating Osiris (Bryan Brown) to his dashing and popular son Horus (Nikolaj Coaster- Waldau). The coronation is rudely interrupted by Osiris's uncle Set (Gerard Butler), who feels that the time has come for him to rule, killing his brother and ripping out his poor nephew's eyes in front of a terrified crowd. With the Egyptians forced into slavery to satisfy Set's greed and vanity, Bek, a talented thief, swipes the plans to Set's vault in the hope of stealing back Horus's eyes and assisting him in defeating his uncle. But when Zaya is killed after the successful theft, Bek strikes a deal with Horus to help guide him through Set's pyramid in exchange for returning Zaya from the underworld.

The main question lingering over the head of Gods of Egypt is why was this film made? For a modern blockbuster from a talented director, the film lacks maturity and brains. For a film possibly designed to appeal to fans of explosion-heavy sci-fi/fantasy extravaganzas such as Michael Bay's Transformers franchise, the CGI is often embarrassingly bad. And for anybody hoping for a throwback to the kitschy B-movies of the 1950's and 60's, where giant monsters and grotesque gods mingled with us puny humans, you will find more charm in one frame of any movie involving the work of Ray Harryhausen than you will for the entire 2 hours of Gods of Egypt. The whole thing just feels oddly out of place, paling in comparison to even the most sickly of recent CGI-fests. Re-telling essentially the exact same story told a thousand times since Homer put ink to paper, this could be re-titled as A Simpleton's Guide to the Hero's Quest. Utter tripe.
I wanted to like this movie. I couldn't! I hoped I'd dislike it less watching it again few years later... but I didn't! What a shame.

White Egyptians??.... I'll say that again...... WHITE Egyptians?? Why does Hollywood continue to cast inacurate depictions of people within countries of color. It's ridiculous and it's obviously fake. Nobody in their right mind believes Egyptians were white. Hollywood has no shame! Then the overuse of CGI. What a mess. I feel bad that Geoffrey Rush was cast in this wreck. This is far beneath his talents. Wouldn't recommend this crap to my worst enemy.

As a movies lover, this "Gods of Egypt" thing just made me sick. This 2 hour torture session will make you leave your sit and hope you were just having a bad dream. The entire Egypt population has been whitewashed and turned into blue eyed blondies. It's OK, if you put history aside and just enjoy the ride, the problem is, this isn't even the biggest issue that makes Gods of Egypt such a flop. The CGI were just UNBEARABLE and it makes me wonder how any human being (or even gods) could think that this was OK to be released to public. If the visual effect supervisor ever get another job, it would be nothing less than a miracle.

It was impossible to like any of the characters, also. I couldn't care less about those guys with such a bad acting on screen. The comic approach they've tried - maybe taking a hike in Marvel's successful action-comedy-light movies - didn't work here at all.

In the end, established names as Gerard Butller and even a decent actor as Chadwick Boseman (Black Panther) will eventually look back and think, "why did i ever do this?"

Do your brain a favor and run away from this.

OK, I though I would give it a go without any high hopes.. just to waste a couple of hours.. There is a reason for the low rating. The only reason it hovers around 5* is because so much money was spent on CGI and it fails even in that.

It is a true wonder how people can spend so much money (140 mil budget) and come up with this..

I will not go into details.. it's pointless.

If I could choose again, I would not go again although I am a fan of comics-like, CGI rich movies.. Furthermore, the director did I robot, which was a great move..how was he content with this production is beyond me.

It's definitely a movie to watch in a cinema or a big screen, if this is your movie genre i promise you, you wont be bored watching the movie, quite the contrary, you'll be Amazed and entertained, this is the future of adventure and action movies if the hating people can't accept the change then don't watch simple as that, the negative reviews just make me mad be cause they make no since and talk about things that don't even relate to the movie "the money spent in this movie could go to the people of Egypt".. review_title: Lots of gods. It's not divine. It's not Asylum either. Thank God.
review_detailed_main:
"A gift from someone with great assets, and someone with very few. But when both die and are at the Final Gate... What is its value? I say we are equal."

I thought this would be something similar like "Exodus: Gods and Kings". A historical story set in Egypt with immense scenery's and an abundance of special effects. Well, it certainly is situated in Egypt. And the bag of tricks, full of kitsch and console-game-like special effects were exploited to the utmost. Only, now it's not about a biblical figure but the mythological world of Egypt. Ancient Egypt where people and gods live alongside each other. It sometimes resembled "Gulliver's Travels" since all those gods of Egypt have an imposing figure compared to the ordinary mortals. Ultimately, it's a kind of historical "Transformers". So, full of exaggerated action and impressive transformations into imaginative creatures.

From the opening shot, it's clear where the biggest amount of money was spent on. A gliding flight over the Egyptian landscape and arriving in a busy shopping street of Egypt. I thought this was already a delight to watch. We get to know Bek (Brenton "The Giver" Thwaites), a kind of Aladdin and a petty thief who succeeds in stealing a (probably in those days) fashionable gown for his beloved Zaya (Courtney "Mad Max: Fury Road" Eaton). And this leads us to the second, unavoidable story : the idyllic love affair. An Egyptian couple with a bright future in front of them and who'll ultimately be victims of the core story. Eternal love, divine adoration for each other and languorous glances, are the obnoxious symptoms we are witnessing. Granted, it wasn't overly annoying. And also this story introduces the most eye-catching prop of the entire movie. That heaving bosom of Eaton. I am almost sure that it does not comply with the usual proportions of that era, but it was the only thing that could distract me from all the other epic violence.

Obviously you should watch this spectacle movie without thinking and let yourself be overwhelmed by the lavish fantasy world. The only thing that bothered me was that they tried to cram the entire Egyptian mythological world in this film. As a result, the pacing is scorching high. You've only just put yourself down in your cozy chair and two over-sized gods are already rolling all over the city center. A sort of re-introduction of "King Kong vs. Godzilla". And so one action-packed scene after the other passes by. The fascinating situation about Anubis and the Underworld, two giant snakes writhing over a huge maze or some "Tomb Raider" platform stunt-work in the temple of Set (Gerald Butler). You won't get bored. The most fascinating and crazy part was reserved for Geoffrey "Barbossa" Rush as the god Ra who's pulling the sun with his floating spacecraft around a disc-shaped earth. I instantly wanted to reread books by Terry Pratchett.

Concerning content you shouldn't expect too much. And sometimes it's quite illogical. Of course those gods always tend to have an easy solution when a problem occurs, which is an advantage for the subsequent course of the story. You can predict the outcome already from an Egyptian mile away. That's no surprise either. And also the CGI wasn't top notch sometimes in this sword-and-sandal. But this film is mainly judged based on the trailer (which I obviously haven't seen because I try to avoid them studiously) and therefor is ripped to pieces by critics. Yet I find this somewhat exaggerated.

Well it's true. At all levels it doesn't contain any profundity. But what do you expect of this type of movie? Highly intellectual conversations and thoughtful screenplay? You also don't expect in a movie such as "Schindler's List" diabolical fright moments or exciting car chases with stirring music? "God of Egypt" showed what I was expecting. Over the top spectacle and action which is digitally displayed in a partially successful way. It effortlessly transcends the level of any Asylum movie. Thank God.

More reviews here : http://bit.ly/1KIdQMT

review_title: Great CGI, interesting plot and atmosphere but terrible writing...
review_detailed_main: Dissappointed... the idea had potential but it was ruined. Everytime I felt like I could enjoy it something ruined it.

It's pure fun! I don't get the negativity,this movie is very enjoyable. Solid story, good music, very good 3D. Loved the costumes! There was a bunch of interesting ideas.Action-packed,and it teaches us a lesson about judging a person's worth.Critics are morons.So in my humble opinion,this was a wonderful sci-fi fantasy movie with gorgeous costumes, rich artistic design and a fun story. If i want to watch a historically accurate, highly praised composition,i check out a documentary channel,but for Saturday afternoon with friends,it was perfect.By the way,my friends enjoyed it as well! :)

Gods of Egypt is directed by Alex Proyas, written by Matt Sazama and Burk Sharpless, and stars Gerard Butler, Nikolaj Coster-Waldau and Chadwick Boseman among others. The film tells the story of a mortal named, Bek and the god Horus coming together to thwart the plans of Set, a merciless god who usurped the throne of Egypt turning the once peaceful empire into one of chaos and destruction. Released in February of 2016, Gods of Egypt was met with negative reception from both audiences and critics, leading the film to struggle at the box office which barely turned a profit during its theatrical run.

Going into Gods of Egypt I was expecting the worst, given the reputation of the film, however, while the movie is certainly bad I didn't hate the experience while watching it. That may be due in part to the adventure the film takes the viewer on, although it strikes every trope in the book and feels like a culmination of every fantasy adventure story ever, there were moments along the way in which I felt entertained. Some of the visuals the filmmakers tried going for were nice and almost felt atmospheric, however much was held back due to how poor the special effects were. Gods of Egypt relies very heavily on CGI, with almost every scene packed full of effects that do not look too impressive. This overabundance of poor CGI severely hurts the quality of the film, while the effects are not the worst ever, the film's dependence on them really brings it to the forefront and it's noticeable that Gods of Egypt could've spent more time in the oven better developing the effects as to not hurt the quality of the movie and more severely date the film; as this is a movie that will negatively show its age in ten years similar to that of Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace a movie that was over-reliant on CGI, however that's only if people even remember Gods of Egypt.

As I stated earlier, although aspects of the journey can be entertaining, much of the story comes across as a greatest hits in terms of the fantasy adventure genre, resulting in a film that is quite forgettable, at least to me. This left me questioning why this film was even made, it's certainly not the first feature-length to be about Egyptian gods and the whole aesthetic felt like a PG Immortals with worse special effects. It's certainly not going to be a film that will stick with audiences after seeing it nor will it be as entertaining while watching as the filmmakers probably hoped it would be.

Gods of Egypt is more or less a messy film, although it was something that I didn't hate as much as I thought I was going to, it undeniably has issues. From the reliance on poor CGI, cliché ridden story and long-winded run time make for a film that surely isn't great. Gods of Egypt has its moments of tolerability, however, it definitely isn't a film that I can recommend and for that reason, I am giving Gods of Egypt a 3/10.
Too much computer graphics makes this lmovie looks more virtual than real destroying in some way the history of itself.

Though it creates a dazzling visual experience the film maker fails to establish matter and substance in the film.

The mythology is perfect but the story lacks energy from the actors and a foundation of a story that would keep the audience in awe besides the visuals.

Acting was poor. No strong emotions.

Overall - 2.5/5

Awesome costumes, great CGI. Everything else is terrible. From the script to the plot, the acting, just dross. Set as a mean-spirited, burly Glaswegian is quite amusing, I was half expecting him to open up a six-pack of Tennants any minute. Some of the other Gods look and act like they've come from the set of Vikings. I mean they could have attempted a slight bit of realism in the casting process, especially when they went to so much effort in the costumes and scenery, which were really cool. The acting is cringe, not from one particular person, but all of them, combining to put on a cringe masterclass and an instantly forgettable movie.

The movie is hilariously bad. As in, I laughed out loud 3 or 4 times. I watched it to see epic CGI battles between Gods, but the film's plot is as childish as it is embarrassingly hollow. The screenplay must have been written by a 12 year old kid.

The battle scenes were extremely disappointing. These allegedly redoubtable "Gods" are supposed to have awe inspiring powers, yet they seem to die very easily, and hardly put up a fight... What's more, there's next to zero creativity in the fight sequences. This movie will be as quickly forgotten as all those names of your friend's friends at a party.

There was potential!

I mean, I wasn't expecting a masterpiece, but neither was I expecting such a laughable asinine mess.

3/10 is being nice.

2016 has been a crazy year for movies for better or for worse. We've had a stunning continuation of both Kung Fu Panda and Star Trek, an onslaught of superhero movies (two of which had the heroes fighting each other), film adaptations of several video games like Warcraft, Disney remakes getting critical praise, and a terrifying return to Japanese cinema by Godzilla. Amongst this plethora of treasured entertainment is one stinking turd under the name "Gods of Egypt". Whenever Egypt is brought into American movies or even TV, the focus is usually on just mummies, pyramids, and booby traps and that's about it. This is why I appreciate the filmmakers for doing something different by delving into the actual mythology of this ancient civilization and much of it is quite fascinating. It's just a shame that none of that can make this movie any good.

When god of the desert Set (Gerard Butler) murders his brother Osiris and steals the eyes of his nephew, sky god Horus, he begins his ruthless rule of the world with an iron fist, killing anyone who defies him be it man or god. A thief named Bek takes it upon himself to help Horus reclaim his eyes in exchange for resurrecting the woman he loves on an "epic" quest to save the world from Set's arrogance and cruel rule.

On paper, this seems like a fun adventure, but its execution is lackluster. Very few of the characters are the least bit interesting with the exception of the likes of Ra (Geoffrey Rush), the god of light whose whole character and concept is pretty interesting, and Anubis not only has a cool design but is thankfully NOT portrayed as a villain so much as a guy who is simply doing his job managing the afterlife. I can't give the same credit to the rest of the cast as they are all just flat out boring. Seriously, I care for nobody here, especially Set, whose accent is not only distracting here, but the actor seems like he's got nothing invested in his role and the evil plan is clichéd and full of holes. There's also the issue of "White-washing" in an Egyptian setting. I can see why people would be upset by this and I agree with them with the humans, though it's established that the gods can take on any form which is passable at most (still, they could be more ethnically accurate too).

Many of the visuals have some cool designs, but it's all generic CGI. Almost nothing is physically present in front of the camera, not even the water the characters waddle in in one scene. THE FREAKIN' WATER! While not inherently bad itself, CGI is already overused these days and I found myself easily bored by the same illusionary trick within the first quarter of the film. The story is a tad needlessly complicated and too damn long. Somewhere in the middle, I was thinking to myself "Is this mess gonna end anytime soon?" The music also sucks as I don't remember a single musical note, which really says something. The action is okay with a couple of nice twists, but nothing truly spectacular. Batman and Superman fighting each other for just eight minutes is much more engaging than all the action "Gods of Egypt" had to offer.

The best way to describe "Gods of Egypt" is a waste of time and money. To paraphrase "The Mummy": Compared to this, the Ten Plagues were a joy.

review_title: Were people watching the same movie I was?
review_detailed_main:
I could have gotten over the sub-par acting, but when in multiple scenes there are obvious and easy to fix mistakes in the editing and the cgi I just cant except that. This is a movie where there are some huge stars and they couldnt even make the backgrounds look believable? Avatar did it so I think this movie could have too. Also a scene where Gerard was about a FOOT away from hitting his enemy? AND THEY LEFT THAT IN? COME ON! Obviously money was the only think on everyones mind. Awful. Completely awful. I know NO ONE who liked this movie in the least.

I have NO idea how someone could give this movie a 10. That should be reserved for gems like the godfather and the like. I dont think people understand how reviewing a movie should work.

I was thrilled to see this movie because I am a fan of mythology (Egyptian, Greek, Norse), and in addition, this film is somehow the adaptation of the animated movie of 1998 "The Prince of Egypt" by the DreamWorks studios. I found the film rather good but too long (2h31 min) for a story that most already know.

Gods of Egypt wasn't the movie I set out to watch, last Saturday, but, boy, am I glad that my first choice was unavailable. Otherwise, I would have missed this striking, action-packed, energetic and flashy movie. I had a blast, and plan to see it again. There was something for everyone; great special effects, romance, action, danger and humor.

While it did not adhere particularly closely to Egyptian mythology, that's probably for the best. Some of those myths can get pretty disturbing. What it did do was deliver lots of fun and eye-candy. I did not leave my seat, glance at my phone messages or remember my popcorn, once the movie began. When you stop chewing and forget where you are, you know you're having fun at the movies.

The characters were enjoyable (especially Horus, who came across as grumpy and hung-over, at first, but eventually got himself sorted). Set was genuinely villainous, and Ra's flat Earth, Sun-towing scene a real treat. I found myself really liking Hathor, as well. The two kids, Bek and Zaya, were cute, reminding me just a little of Aladin and Jasmine. Yu genuinely cared about Zaya, on her journey through the frighteningly bleak Egyptian underworld. About Hathor, too, actually, but I won't spoil things and say why.

Personally, I rate this movie on par with Avengers: Age of Ultron, and above the last Star Wars movie, which I saw just once. Go see Gods of Egypt. You'll be glad that you did.

There are two movies I truly do not understand why was made. The first one is 2001: A Space Odyssey. The second one is this one, Gods of Egypt.

Why?

There is absolutely no sense at all in either movie. Nor is there any value in either.

Total suckage, brotato chip. Awful CGI and a complete waste of Christian Bale's talent. I want my money and my 2 +/- hours back. If I could beat the producers of this monstrosity within an inch of their life, I would do so with a clear conscience

review_title: Excellent visuals and great actors, that's it
review_detailed_main:
This movie kinda of sucked. I would have given it two stars, were it not for the visuals and the actors Butler and Waldau. Forget about the whole mostly-white-actors-in-a-movie-set-in-Egypt, forget about that.

Something that irked me, almost more than what I am to talk about later, were the lame, "witty" jokes- the comments down the road, the whole trying to take a break from action by pausing a few seconds just to say something "funny", even though it was in the midst of the heat of all of it. And the thing is, it was darn corny and stupid! I couldn't even laugh, it was just really distracting!

Now for the main part, I HATED how they progressed so easily, so quickly- NO effort. The problem solving was so straight forward, no struggle at all. This took away the excitement, the thrill- no blood pumping here, just my neck aching from having to drag myself through this movie. The lines the poor actors had to say in this movie, I mean- who wrote this? Seriously? I cringed whenever something dramatic was happening, I would rather hear them do the boring "journey talk" they did during some points in the movie. Actually, I cringed over how casually they said anything in the movie, except for epic Gerard Butler, as he was mostly like he was in all his badass movies.

And bad fights, like wow, bad. Only visuals saved them from me just shutting off.

Enough ranting now, for short:

Good:





BAD:









By the way, I kind of don't like how people give more stars to off- set the bad reviews from other reviewers, JUST because they want to defend it from critique with mostly white actors for characters from Egypt. People can say it had a bad impact on their experience of the movie, since after all- the setting was Egypt and Egyptian gods, hence they can rate it from that point on. But to give it MORE stars to off-set the bad reviews on the non-logical casting of the movie is plain moronic, you ruin the whole rating system because you do not review based on the movie, but on what others have rated it as- and no, I do not care about the white actors at all. Actors are actors, as long as they do great, I don't care!
